[h3] Pros: [/h3] [b]üåü Charming Art Style[/b] Dinkum boasts a delightful art style that brings its whimsical world to life. The colorful environments and character designs contribute to the game's overall charm, immersing players in a visually appealing experience. üé®‚ú®

[b]üéÆ Engaging Gameplay Mechanics[/b] Players can enjoy a variety of engaging gameplay mechanics, including platforming, puzzle-solving, and exploration. Dinkum offers a mix of challenges that cater to different playstyles, ensuring a rewarding experience for players of all skill levels. üïπÔ∏èüß©

[h3] Cons: [/h3] [b]üîÑ Limited Replay Value[/b] Despite its enjoyable gameplay mechanics, Dinkum may lack long-term replay value due to its linear progression and relatively short playtime. Once players complete the main storyline and solve all the puzzles, there may be little incentive to revisit the game. üï∞Ô∏èüîÅ

[b]üîä Soundtrack and Audio Design[/b] While Dinkum features a pleasant soundtrack and sound effects, some players may find the audio design lacking in depth and variety. A more diverse range of musical compositions and immersive soundscapes could enhance the overall audio experience. üéµüîâ

[h3] Other Drawbacks: [/h3] [b]üåê Technical Issues[/b] Some players may encounter technical issues such as bugs, glitches, or performance optimization problems while playing Dinkum. These issues can detract from the enjoyment of the game and may require frequent updates or patches to resolve. ‚ö†Ô∏èüêõ

[b]üìñ Narrative Depth[/b] While Dinkum offers a charming and whimsical storyline, some players may find its narrative lacking in depth or complexity. Additional character development and storytelling elements could enrich the overall narrative experience, adding depth and emotional resonance. üìöüé≠

This game is something special! Writing this review as something of a thank-you to the devs of Dinkum.

My mom is 76 years old. She wanted to play Zelda (after watching me play), but the combat was too difficult. I'd tried to get her hooked on games like Minecraft and Vintage Story, but... those games still have too much in terms of combat or complex survival mechanisms. Then, at some point in time, I got her Animal Crossing. HUGE hit! Unfortunately, she's had probably 10+ islands and has grown very bored with the game.

Fast-forward by about a decade, and here she is, loving the absolute crap out of Dinkum! Logged 24 hours in the first two days she played! 

Dinkum is great because: 
- the simple graphics, large icons, high contrast colors, and crisp sounds make it easy for you to see and hear what you're doing. It's great for the older players (like my mom!), but also for us who are visually impaired. I have glasses, but a lot of games simply make their UIs too small. 
- combat is present, but largely optional! For the longest time, my mom was scared to go out at night because she didn't want to get "killed" by scary things like tarantulas (flashback to ACNH!). But in Dinkum, a lot of the enemies can be avoided! Crocodiles can be outrun, wary mus lose interest, and even bush devils can be avoided with enough quick thinking! There are alpha animals (boss-like variants), but those can be avoided by simply not taking on their quests/staying away from their area. 
- the multiplayer is AMAZING! Seriously, 10/10. I have been the server owner for SO many games between me and my bestie (500+ miles away from me), struggling to get our games so we can play together. But Dinkum is great because it's a 2-button click and we're connected! My mom and I can play on the couch, or my bestie and I can play from our separate countries and it's the same quality, regardless! No server, no having to worry about strangers joining in, no nightmarish fiddling with the command box in windows. It's just click and play!
- the game is content-rich. It's early access, but there's a real treasure trove of stuff to do. Lots of items to build with, animals that interact with you (but also, importantly, interact with one another! Making the world feel like a living, breathing place!), clothes, character customization options, bugs and fish to collect... I could go on! 
- combat is easy, but not utterly boring. There's cues to watch for when you want to strike without getting hit back. 
- there's a selection of awesome vehicles you can get and ride around on with very fluid movement. 
- you can do it all or focus on one specific area. You can be a jack of all trades or you can focus on one task and maximize the heck out of it!

Stuff I think Dinkum could improve upon:
- for a game seemingly inspired by Animal Crossing, I'd like to see Dinkum's npcs do a bit more in the world. Change their clothes, decorate their living space (or HAVE a living area, even), catch bugs and fish, etc. 
- OPTIONAL hard mode for players who want more challenging combat
- more npc dialog/backstory
- ability to give better weapons to npcs to help you fight (when "hanging out")
- more animals/animal varieties 

All in all, I think the game is an absolute STEAL at the current price ($23) versus Animal Crossing which is $79 (and a lot less content). 
It's a game that brings my mom happiness at close to 80 years old, but able to be enjoyed by more "hardcore" gamers like myself. How cool is that? 

NOTE: My mom, specifically, would like to make a suggestion to see the days progress a bit slower. I think the pacing is alright, but a slower day wouldn't be bad, either.

[strike]This game has a a bunch of good things (Exploration, farming, gathering, crafting, housing, questing) going for it, but as it stands now, it's not worth the $20. There's far too many bugs, not enough replayability and not to mention the horrible combat which for some reason is part of the game.

TL;DR: Wait for early access to end.[/strike]

Dinkum: the game where you're dropped into the Australian Outback with nothing but your wits, a sense of adventure, and an unhealthy obsession with collecting every single thing you see. This isn't just a game; it's a virtual trip Down Under, minus the giant spiders and sunburns.

You start off with big dreams and a small patch of land, and before you know it, you're farming, fishing, and frantically running from emus. Yes, emus. Those feathery speed demons are no joke. You haven't experienced true terror until you've had a pixelated emu hot on your heels.

The animals aren't the only stars of the show; the NPCs have more personality than a kangaroo has hops. They're quirky, they're chatty, and they'll have you rolling your eyes and chuckling at their antics.

And let's talk about the crafting. Oh boy, if you love hoarding resources for that 'just in case' scenario, Dinkum will be your digital paradise. You can craft everything from a cozy hut to an empire of chicken coops. Why? Because why not!

In all seriousness, Dinkum is a charming and addictive life sim that captures the rugged beauty and whimsy of the Australian wilderness. It's the perfect game for when you want to relax, explore, and occasionally run for your life from the local wildlife. A fair dinkum good time!

I bought this game expecting to be bored within 2-3 hours of game play like any other animal crossing/harvest moon look-alike, boy was I wrong. I purchased this game for myself and a friend and we are loving it. Expect a grind because you'll get one, and don't expect things to come easy to you in the beginning. This is a trial and error game, that requires you to do the work and figure things out. I found it had an old school runescape feel in the sense of grinding materials and levels (which take a ton of time later in the game). You have a ton of base building, and gathering time to fulfil many hours of the day with a taste of that satisfying completion at the end. 
You also have townsfolk that appear, you want to do tasks for them to receives new random recipes, which makes the game even more rewarding with a RNG rewards system. 
I highly recommend this game!

Note to the developer; one thing that wold make this game a 100% better... include a guide, or some kind of intro to each game mechanic as they're unlocked.

HEAVY Animal Crossing influence. There is quite a bit of familiarity with the Animal Crossing I played on Switch during COVID. There are also some additional elements that are a bit of the flavor of games like Minecraft or other farming sims so it's a mix of it all. If those sound like a family you'd like to be a part of it's probably worth poking around, especially if on sale since it's still early access and bound to change.

The main takeaway is that this is not a really narrative driven game. This is purely gameplay loop. It is exploration, customization, collection, completion, etc. It's a game you play to decompress without thinking too much.

This game is similar to Stardew Valley but different enough to be worth playing too. While there's no romancing, you do have to build relationships to grow your community and gain residents (and their accompanying shops). Super fun.

Having put over 2000 hours into Animal Crossings I was having trouble finding a replacement.  FOUND IT.  Love this game.  I like that that day is not in actual time.  When I leave the game, and return, it's not progressed.  Meaning I don't miss out on events like fishing or bug catching and I can live my life outside the game without missing anything.  The map is HUGE giving so much area to play and build on.  Transportation vehicles like motorbikes and boats makes navigating it not seem like a chore. Having farm animals, crops and collecting natural resources means there is always something to do.  The learning curve was spot on and it did not take me long to figure out the controls, although I swear every time I play I find something new. This game has a lot to offer and I would definitely recommend it.

This game already outdesigns Animal Crossing: New Horizons in every possible way, and for this the developer has my kudos and my respect.

What really makes the game not as compelling and succesful in my opinion are two major problems:

1. the whole Australian setting is not appealing for most players I'm sure: the harsh and arid red is everywhere, and the land doesn't seem a welcoming and chill place to explore and settle in;

2. the characters' design is really lackluster in terms of personality: they look like bland persons without interesting traits.

Those two issues contribute to a world that isn't colorful and interesting to log in and interact; despite these two major issues, the rest is truly worth of respect IMO and the developer did a really good job.

I am just leaving a negative recommendation because honestly I do not feel compelled to play because of these reasons, and hopefully the developer can read about it.

It's an awesome game, a good mix between Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing with the slightest bit of Minecraft mixed in.

Some pros: Fun mechanics, Easy to play with friends, you can easily lose hours to this game, super helpful "side" items such as the books which make things easier, so many early game food options, the ability to book mark recipes so I know what I need to grab, and the fact that you don't pass out when it's late.

Some cons: Its really tedious/difficult to level up farming, the fishing mini-game has a delay that makes it nearly impossible to play with only a mouse (I use my touch pad and it works great), some of the money scaling is a bit far-fetched, and the dirt/ground movement/placement is super annoying especially if you're into terraforming. 

Some things I wish it had: More player customization, visible milestones for further town advancement/clearer hints (so I know what I need to do next so I'm not running around hoping I just come across and do what is needed) (had this issue when it came to using the ruby shards for the mines), ability to bookmark what's needed when getting materials for building, ability to bookmark more than one recipe at a time, ability to make own furniture (even if it's just simple furniture), and more house customization. 

I know this game is still receiving updates and I'm super excited for them! This is just the game I needed while waiting for the next Stardew update!

For those who played Animal Crossing: it's Animal Cross but in Australia. This game is very similar to Animal Crossing.

For those who had not played Animal Crossing: this game is a 3D adventure, farming, building, and managing game. In general, you come to an island, you hunt, fish, mine, and you create your own town -- at your pace. It's cute, fun, relaxing, and no commitment required - meaning, if you take a break, you can always come back to it without any issue.

If you like Animal Crossing you will probably enjoy this game as its very similar but gives more personality to the npcs and has a lot to do and not as bland in the ways you can make progress....if you don't like animal crossing's progression system its probably not for you. 

Easy to kill some time here and there unless you are a fan of Animal Crossing like games and progression system. Though the progression system in Dinkum is better than Animal Crossing as you actual feel like you are making progress.

Animal Crossing, with a distinctly Aussie flare to it. Enjoying it already a few hours in.

And with that experience I can say that I personally love Dinkum. The voxel style really sticks out to me and it makes the landscape unique, easy to change, and realistic - in a cartoony way. The vibe here is really unique and I think Dinkum is a worthy inclusion in a genre that has seen a lot of entries in recent years. I played a lot of animal crossing when it came out, and recently started a new island, but I struggle with the daily nature of things and the progress tied to real time. Animal crossing becomes such that it feels like a chore that I need to do every day. Dinkum has a lot of the charm from animal crossing (minus the animals), and many similarities, but it fixes this issue entirely by not locking the game to real time. Progress is still slow, but if you have the time to work through the days, you can keep making progress the entire time you‚Äôre sitting down for a play session. Dinkum won‚Äôt penalize you for missing a day. While it does need to be played in roughly half an hour chunks to get the most out of every day, it is a bite size piece that I‚Äôve been able to plan my gaming time around, and it works well. This game has a lot of characters, and it is always fun working towards that next villager moving in, or getting enough permit points for that new and exciting permit. 

Its systems are all competent. Fishing is unique and fun. Bug catching is almost second nature. Metal detecting is new and interesting. It is nice to wander around the forests just looking for fruit to cook, and running away from the scary lizards or Emus. Hunting is challenging but rewarding. Shoveling works realistically (at least comparatively).  Every little system here comes together as part of a greater whole. 

It is also worth mentioning that there is multiplayer support in this game, a game that‚Äôs fun on it‚Äôs own can only be more fun with your friends. I didn‚Äôt try it out, but it‚Äôs worth noting that it is there. 

As far as the farming/life sim genre goes, Dinkum is easily one of my favorites. I look forward to continuing to play days here and there, and for its eventual full release. That slow incremental progress day to day, and watching my community grow before my eyes is a truly rewarding experience. Dinkum has earned its niche in the genre.

The game's start may be a tad challenging, possibly due to a learning curve or initial setup, but don't be discouraged. As you progress and start developing your town, the excitement and enjoyment soar. It's like stepping into a world where fun is in the sun!

The town-building aspect of Dinkum is where the game truly shines. The creativity and strategy involved in constructing and managing your town provide a rewarding and entertaining experience. Whether it's designing layouts, managing resources, or interacting with virtual residents, the gameplay becomes incredibly engaging.

Dinkum is a delightful and engaging game that truly shines when played with a significant other. Its immersive gameplay, set in a beautifully crafted world, encourages cooperation, creativity, and fun. Playing alongside someone special adds a layer of joy and collaboration that enhances the experience remarkably. The game's mechanics are intuitive yet challenging, ensuring that both casual and experienced gamers can find enjoyment. The art style is charming and inviting, making every session feel like a mini-vacation to a whimsical land (that is also filled with things that want to kill you). Whether you're exploring, building, or just enjoying the scenery together, Dinkum has a unique bonding experience that's harder to find in other games. It's balanced, relaxing, and refreshing with engaging activities makes it a perfect choice for single players or couples looking for a shared gaming adventure.

I loved the first Animal Crossing when that came out back in the day, and a couple after. Really wanted to like New Horizons, but I got bored pretty quick. At the end of the day, it just seemed like your curating a virtual museum, and there's not a whole lot to do. Multiplayer was especially a missed opportunity. There really wasn't a meaningful way to interact together.

This game is different. This game has everything I would have wanted from a New Animal Crossing. I don't have a lot of time in it yet, but it feels more complex, and has mixed farm sim elements, which who doesn't love? I thought I was just going to play an Animal Crossing clone with my girlfriend, and that I'd only play to help her progress her Island, but I ended up loving it so much. I love that my progression/licenses carry over when I visit her Island. I don't feel like I'm playing two separate saves. Anytime I play by myself, I can still benefit both of us, and that's really freaking cool. 

I'm loving this game so far. It's the Animal Crossing sequel I've always wanted.

Almost 10 hours in at this point and I'm just scratching the surface. Fans of animal crossing will recognize a lot of the gameplay loop. In addition to resource collection there are townfolk favors, special events and a bunch of customizations that you gradually unlock as you progress. What sets this apart from animal crossing however, is the ability to affect the environment, as well as determine what development journey you wish to go down. I'm not much for farming, but so far I don't feel like I'm REQUIRED to go that route. I can explore hunt and mine if I feel like it.

This is my current obsession - is there life outside this game? Not sure. There are rumors there is but I think there are false flags spread by Sheila. 

Anywho. If you enjoyed Animal Crossings but really wished a crocodile would try to eat you while you were setting up your farm, then this is the game for you! If you liked Animal Crossings but instead of catching a shark that shark tried to eat you, then this is the game for YOU.   No but seriously - I LOVE this game. The farm animals are not your normal cows and pigs. It is a great twist on this type of game while still being playable for most skill levels.

The other thing I like is I only have to take motion sickness meds when I am going crazy with the bike trying to find something I lost in the wilds lol. I would have liked it to be more clear what I needed to do to convince people to move to the island instead of having to look it up (that would have saved some time lol) But I think that is really the only thing that I dislike. Most other items I have been able to stumble over figuring out.

 So over all in my long winded review 10/10 would totally recommend!

My critique (so far):

Great game!  Complex enough to keep me engaged and simple enough for my 6 yr old novice reader.   Some more pictures indicating item mentioned in missions and such would be helpful but thats my only suggestion.   Otherwise this is a win and a big win for parents to play with kids.

TL;DR: 10/10 - I highly recommend this game for some chillsome gaming adventure in a "cute" environment.

> Graphics: simple but also very powerful (if you take a closer look at the water for example). It has some Animal Crossing vibes but enhances on top of this. I really like the aesthetics of this game and how it looks.

> Mechanics: Sometimes the camera AND grid-based actions can be a bit annoying (shovel and wheelcart is the best example here) but mostly you can compensate this. The crafting and building, the progression and storytelling is sooo very well done! This is the main criteria that keeps me in the game. A friend of mine and I always play this game together and it keeps us wanting to play more.

> Storytelling: Yeah, some spots are a bit questionable, but if you look beyond that and let yourself get sucked into the game - it is so nice. Your village will grow, you will become more and more occupied with farming, with "zoo keeping" and lots more. There is so much to see and explore that it compensates the "thin" storytelling.

> Bugs: Well, there is a problem with saves and accountsharing (one PC, multiple accounts --> overwrites instances of your own saves) and another RAM exceeding bug (RAM consumption adds up after some time --> will probably be fixed soon) but we did not have anything else besides that. Nice, finally a feature-rich game that does NOT break if you blink a little too hard.

Overall rating: 10/10 - would buy again and I recommend this game. Feature-rich, no stupid cashgrabbing mechanics - and this is only the Early Access version. I am so thrilled for the future of this game.

Can't say enough good stuff about Dinkum!!

I delight in Dinkum. A cozy game par excellence (and one that doesn't simply hide behind that adjective as an excuse for being under-developed--we're looking at you, Calico and Garden Paws), it's a bit Animal Crossing, a bit Harvest Moon, and a whole lot of Outback.

Like Stardew Valley, Dinkum is a one-man-band situation; unlike Stardew Valley, Dinkum is 3D, meaning there's a lot more to have to do to make it go. The developer, however, is clearly committed and continues to roll out new content.

In fairness and full disclosure, it is still more than a little rough around the edges, with lots of planned content still not developed at the time of this writing--it is very clearly far from "done." However, the diligence and attention of the developer shines through the work that is present so far, and it distinctly lacks the whiff of "always an Early Access; never a release" that plagues so many games of a similar origin. I have quite enjoyed what I have played of Dinkum so far, and look forward to experiencing (and ostensibly enjoying) more of it as it continues to be iterated and expanded upon.

The Game Play:
I love the childlike side to this game, with the adult responsibilities. I love that you can put poo on your head and someone actually coded a fly to show up above your head. I love the cute dresses, animals, creatures, and attention to detail on their creations. I LOVE the peacock spider! I like that you can upgrade your abilities, hunting, mining, farming, etc.

Its like someone played multiple of these types of games, and took a lot of the things we hated, and made it better. :) 

I love the open world! I love being able to spend a day fishing, catching bugs, doing competitions, etc... And my farm chores are done so quick, I have time. Heck, the store doesnt even open on Sundays and its not open when I first wake up in the game. 

The thing is, I like so many features of this game, and I have watched no tutorials or YouTube videos on it. So as much as I like what I have seen, I have only been playing about 4 days... Which means, there is so so so much more then I have run into yet. I know I get a mine, I know I will be able to catch animals.. But there is still so much to discover... 

Thank you for this game, I really hope for future DLC and more to it. So I can never get bored :) 
P.S. I have a completed farm together game in my library, and I have collected almost every item on animal crossing, I do know a good farm sim game when I play it. ;)

I want to like this game. I used to like Animal Crossing and I like farming sim games, so I thought this game would give me all the things that Animal Crossing doesn't... When reviews say the game is grind-y, it's GRIND-Y. If you want a slow, grind-y Animal Crossing game, then this will be perfect (as most of the reviews say). I also think this game might be meant more as a multiplayer because I can see this game being less grind-y if there's another person also collecting stuff. I'll probably have a different review if I ever end up playing this with my bf.

Some things to keep in mind when playing this game (DO NOT READ IF you don't want anything spoiled):
[spoiler]- The start is random and the world you load into is randomly generated. I tested this because I was not impressed with the start area that I loaded into my first game, but I do notice you definitely begin in an area that's considered a starter area.
- Unlike most farming sims, you have to pay for your starter tools, which also have a limited time use, so you'll find yourself constantly buying your tools at the beginning as you grind materials you can't use yet because you don't have every ingredient for the recipes they give you. This probably isn't a problem in multiplayer as it can be in single-player.
- If you want to be efficient, you'll have to craft yourself multiple stations because everything can only make things 1 at a time (I suggest making multiple bonfires and multiple furnaces so you're not wasting your time waiting for something to finish processing).
- I was never a fan of how much everything costed in Animal Crossing... On top of things costing a lot, if your "town" (that you begin forming at the get go, so be prepared to need to traverse the land a lot since most people typically begin building their base at the start area) is in "debt" (any new building that gets put down becomes a debt), then you can't progress with another building until you've cleared that debt. Basically, be prepared to have only a couple people on your island at the beginning as well. At least it doesn't seem too hard to earn money, but it does feel tedious because you're typically grabbing the same things over and over. Again, probably less tedious in multiplayer.
- There is no boundary in this game--it's like Minecraft, monsters can spawn in your base area, so be prepared to fight each day. So far, I haven't found a way to keep this from happening (like torches does for Minecraft). My trick is using the bonfire because just walking over it sets you (or anything else that walks over it) on fire!
- You can build relationships with the townspeople. I don't know what effect this has yet, but since this game is in early access still, I highly recommend maybe giving discounts on things? I mean, it's not like we're trying hard to collect money to pay off a huge debt and also spending money to buy our tools that we NEED after all... (No. There isn't a way to craft the tools at the beginning that I could tell--you can craft your weapon...if you have the ingredients.) You build the relationship by doing tasks. So far, the old woman who begins all this has asked me to collect insects that I had no idea where to get them from (surprise! they're in other biomes!).
- EVERYTHING TAKES ENERGY. HAVE COOKED FOOD ON YOU ALWAYS. Swimming costs energy on top of the tools taking up energy. Apparently the tools are supposed to take less energy as you level that skill up, but I still find myself needing more energy. ALSO. You can only eat so much at a time. I think certain foods might take longer to "digest" than others, but I haven't kept too close of a tab on the 3-part pie indicator next to the energy bar (it's circular and you can only eat up to 3 things before being "full" and then you have to wait for it to "cooldown" before eating any more. This can become a problem if you're fighting something and trying to heal.)
- Food gives different buffs and different amounts of health/stamina. Remember, the bonfire only cooks 1 thing at a time! ALSO. Cooking station? Can't make anything at the beginning because I don't have all the ingredients. I assume I'll need better tools to collect some of the ingredients (for instance, a meat stick requires a stick from a tree that the starter tool can't chop down), but unsure when that occurs.
- I hate most fishing parts of these kinds of games. Either they're too boring because they're too easy or they're tedious because it takes time to go through the mini-game. This fishing is a little realistic; you wait for the fish to pull down the bobber (makes a QUICK splash) and then you hook the fish. Once the fish is hooked, it IMMEDIATELY gives tension, so don't be holding down the left mouse button or you'll have to start over and use up a portion of your limited time tool. You fight the fish until you reel it in or lose the catch. Fish are swimming everywhere in the water...aim does matter because the fish has to see your bobber in order for it to begin swimming towards it--so either you get fish or you waste some of your tool time.
- You don't use the shovel in the same way you would in any other sandbox-like game. You pick up what you dig and you place it right back down. Great for landscaping and its unique way of "planting" things, but do not expect to collect sand or dirt or anything.
- You can make a boat to traverse the waters without using energy... Default controls are inversed and you can end up beached--the boat drives into the land really quickly and you go a lot slower to get out of it.
- I love/hate how easy it is to relocate my furniture/crafting stations... A quick press of "e" picks it up, so if you're used to "e" being used for interaction, be prepared to re-place your crafting stations (or I guess change the keybinding if it bugs you that much).[/spoiler]
- This game is still in early access. Some of these things could be fixed and some of these things will just become this game's unique feature to distinguish itself from other games out there that are doing something similar.

Overall, this game has a cool appeal, it just needs more content and better-defined details, which may be what gets this game out of early access. You're thrown into the game like you are in Minecraft and Animal Crossing--figure things out! Just be prepared to be slightly annoyed by some small factors that could effect the overall gameplay.

As far an Animal Crossing clones go this is a pretty good one. Character movement isn't horrifically clunky, the townsfolk aren't annoying or insufferable, good variety of things to do, lots of customizability. But why I can't reccommend it is that in many places it's needlessly difficult, frustrating, or just irritating.

In the overworld hostile creatures are easy to avoid but in the mines they attack relentlessly and all hostiles in this game have way too much health and do way too much damage. Maybe you could keep on top of it with enough healing items but you are only able to use three consumables at a time before a long cooldown kicks in. 

You can both craft items and buy items but some vendors act as specialty crafting stations which require both items and a sizable amount of money to get an item. Money isn't too hard to come by but this still feels really bad.

Other things that just feel bad; I payed to build the mine, I gathered the materials, I put it where I wanted it but I have to pay a merchant who doesn't even work for the town for a daily permit to use my mine. It's not a lot of money but it still feels bad. {This one could be easily fixed by re-framing the mine pass as a belt that needs to be replaced everytime in order to use the elevator.)

Expensive and resource intensive items can be repaired either with repair kits or, if they're battery powered, with a recharge station. But if you use up the charge in a battery powered item it breaks. Why on earth would it do that.

There are things about this game I like, it doesn't explain everything to do you so you have to figure some things out. Fishing and planting trees are both things that took some getting use to at first, which is neat, but I also don't enjoy how fishing works and planting lots of trees is more tedious than anything in a chill Animal Crossing clone should be. As a counter to this the bug catching requires zero skill. You can't screw it up, you can't scare away bugs.

The one word I would use to describe my experience with this game is 'irritating'. There are so many little things that seem to exist purely to annoy.
Loved this game from the start. Now 177 hours in and still love it now. It just keeps getting better with the additional content and updates.

BOB

Very close to a yes, however the innumerable bugs and glitches alongside some truly bewildering choices on the part of the developer have given me pause. 

1. I've spawned in my house and fallen through the world.  

2. There's a persistent bug where your "take/action" key/button is forced toggled on so that you automatically grab anything you walk by (not bad, honestly and can be quite serviceable) however it also locks you into chests, signs, and other interact-able objects which is utterly miserable.

3. I get that money. "dinks" are a joke in this game, due to trapping, but having to pay 25k a pop to go into a mine I've built and paid for is blowing my mind. I also love that there are a host of apex predators living down... how exactly? This should have been a "smallish" iron rich cavern for players to mine without fear of being attacked, and which renews every so often. Not what it is currently... an infuriating combat slog with seemingly very little iron.

4. I've spent all day looking for various bugs people want me to find, in the zones they specify, and they never spawn. ALL. DAY. Nothing.

5. Making friends feels intensely grindy, and not in the normal way. Having to track down many of their wants can take you all day and you only see them once every other week, perhaps? 

6. Ultimately, there are only a handful of ways in which this game is different than Animal Crossing, and while those are pleasant discrepancies, I'm not sure those distinctions are enough to set it apart. It feels like a clone, honestly. Even the god awful garbled speech, which, thank the gods, there is an option to turn off. 

The good?

The multiplayer is meaningful. Unlike AC, you don't just feel like a guest playing on someone's island. You can do very nearly everything they can do and you have a sense of agency. Trapping is broken for "visitors" and does not work properly, and I hope the developer intends to redress this as it's the principle way most earn their living. 

The island is much, much, larger than AC's and it contains unique biomes which are a nice way of breaking up what is otherwise a fairly homogeneous ecosystem. 

Fletch is not Tom Nook. 

Being able to manipulate your environment to the degree that you can is intensely rewarding, much like Minecraft. I spent a long time moving dirt in order to obsessively lay out/flatten my town, part of which involved the building a massive berm that surrounds the village to keep out unwanted animals like crocs and other pests. The moment when I realized all of this labor quite literally paid off in the form of making my bridge the sole choke-point which I could then trap, was glorious.

This is a pretty narrow line between yes and no for me and if in the future the developer resolves some of these bugs, I would be happy to recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the genre, but in its current state, it begs the question, why not just play AC?

Ripper of a game I reckon.

Pros:
- More Strine slang than any game this side of the stump
- After the first day (tutorial), complete freedom to go about the whole game doing whatever you want.
- Lots of types of gameplay - can forage in the bush, farm crops, fish, mine ores, dig for treasure, raise animals, trap wild animals, steal emu eggs as big as your head from their nests and sell them etc.
- Lots of choice in how/when/if you build everything in the town
- Lots of vehicles ranging from wheelbarrows and gliders to helicopters and tractors
- Terrain can be dug up and put elsewhere, plants regrown elsewhere - the whole map can be rearranged, its hard yakka though
- Several methods of unlocking abilities - as well as skills, can also buy licences with "permit points" that give you access to buy/craft stuff
- Skills level up as you use things, as well as unlocking new tools etc they reduce your stamina loss when using tools so you can do a lot more
- No missable stuff if you don't do something "the right way" on a playthrough

Cons (nothing really bad):
- The option to pause the game in single player is not obvious
- No mid-day saves
- Quite limited space even in your upgraded house
- Too many items require specific bits of pre-disaster "junk" (old gear, old spring, keyboard, etc) which have to be found in random digging drops. Stuff like gears and springs should be craftable, even if by NPCs.
- The mine pass system is annoying (to have to buy a pass from the shop every time you use the mine elevator) - would be nice if a fully upgraded mining licence would let you have a permanent pass
- Clothing is completely cosmetic, would be nice to have some armour that reduces damage or clothing that affects stamina loss in heat/rain/etc
- Limited automation or delegation - you can unlock two types of sprinklers to water crops but would be neat to have more automatic buildings or be able to hire some NPCs to manage crops or animals.
- Lots of things are handwaved, like food lasting forever in chests, vehicles don't need fuel, buildings don't need power - not clear how electric lights and facilities work on an isolated island with no power plants. Even campfires and billies don't need more wood once built.
Not expecting Don't Starve level of difficulty but its defo a bludge. We're not galahs mate, give us a fair shake of the sauce bottle.
sUPER FUN GAME

Maybe it'll get better in the future but as of now, it's not enjoyable to play.
It's a mix of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, but doesn't have the charm of any one of them. 

What made AC were its characters and the passage of time. There were a lot of colorful characters in the game, and you would randomly get a set amount of them in your village, making each person's town different. And the passage of time was tied to your real life clock which made it even more immersive. It made the town feel lived in. You were going back to your town every day during set hours, talking with your neighbours, doing some daily chores and relaxing. With time some new activities would pop up but this was the most of the game.

What made SV were also its characters and speed. The characters are the same for every player but it's fine since they're all different from each other personality wise, and feel fun to hang out with. You could grow close to every one of them, and could even romance them. The size of the map is not too large and every day is only 14 minutes in real time. This meant you were racing to get the most of every day. The farming mechanics were the main point of the game so there's a bunch of strategy and variety involved in that as well.

Dinkum has none of these, and worst of all, has nothing to distinguish itself from the other games in this type of genre. The characters are all boring and lifeless, every single mechanic in the game is way too simplistic, it's somehow even more grindy than the rest, the map looks cool at the beginning but a short walk shows how empty it is despite being so large, time never runs out, and the energy system doesn't feel balanced. I fail to see the point of this game, there's nothing to strive for. 

Hope it gets better once it gets out of early access.

Dinkum is a game that truly has the potential to evoke positive emotions. However, I find myself unable to leave a positive review because, to my deepest dismay, Dinkum is objectively bad for me for several reasons.

[olist]
[*]The camera: I‚Äôm literally nauseated by how the camera is implemented in the game. The developer has created several camera modes, all of which are poorly designed, as if they skipped Unity engine lessons and made obvious mistakes. The most significant error is in the free camera mode where the focus point wanders between the character‚Äôs heels and feet, causing a feeling of swaying and, consequently, nausea. They also miscalculated how to calculate the vertical angle, and when the camera is parallel to the ground, it is literally at ground level and looks at the character‚Äôs heels. Naturally, the picture will be blocked by bushes and other objects. In the second mode, the free view is turned off, and vertical mouse movement starts to respond to camera zoom, and horizontal - to fly around the character, which is not practical. The second significant error is that in both modes, the character is in the upper half of the screen, so when running forward (up), the view of the terrain is severely limited. It‚Äôs easier to play with a gamepad because you can fix an acceptable camera angle with the stick, but there are some other consequences of camera errors that interfere with normal interaction with the world.
[*]Monstrously slow and boring introduction: This is due to excessively stretched dialogues. The problem is that at the beginning of the game there are dialogues in which each NPC sentence is given in turn. The lack of ability to quickly fast-forward conversations is annoying, but ideally, dialogues should be more concise and informationally saturated. However, graphomania is a common problem with indie games.
[*]Some difficulties with learning game mechanics: Since I‚Äôve played many similar games, Dinkum‚Äôs gameplay elements look familiar, albeit in some moments underdeveloped or overcomplicated. However, I see that the game lacks clear and precise instructions. Lack of knowledge will make the player appreciate the acquired knowledge and skills, as it was, for example, in Minecraft, which has almost no built-in training. However, I think that the description of the game ‚Äúcozy‚Äù is incompatible with how the game treats the player.
[*]Some moments with NPC quests: These essentially force boring grinding.
[/olist]

I understand that Dinkum can hook with its atmosphere and some features. And if you like it, you can endure the shortcomings, especially if you do not compare with other games. But for me, Dinkum is too toxic. A swaying and uncomfortable camera, boring dialogues, too contrasting color combination, the need to perform some repetitive actions - all this has exceeded the threshold of patience, for me it is definitely not cozy and not relaxing.

It really pains me to have to leave a negative review, but the game has one massive flaw that completely killed the fun for me.

If you play with a friend, the host decides a lot of things, too many things, in fact.

For example: If the client decides he wants to go in the mines, the host has to go too, or the client is simply unable to enter.

This restriction is incredibly annoying and made me stop playing.

If you compare it to a game like Stardew Valley where everyone can do as they please no matter what the host is doing, it's really not as good.

Again, this is the ONLY flaw with the game. Other than that it's very enjoyable. But it's too big a flaw to ignore as far as I'm concerned.

Hopefully this is changed, so I can play the game again later.

It deleted all of my progress.

There is a cloud save bug that, if someone plays Dinkum on a shared device under their own account, it overwrites your save with that player's character, and since it's based on slots and not uniquely named character folders or anything like that, all of your progress will be destroyed, just like that. Your cloud save will contain their character, not yours! 

I cannot recommend the game for that reason, alone. It really sucks to lose over 20 hours of progress.

- Breadth of things to do, craft, collect, and discover.

My nitpicks:
- I'd love it if I could pick a map before I dropped into the game. I restarted my save about 10 or 20 times before I got an island I felt I could work with.
- Could use more dialogue with townies, but I'm sure that's something in development.
- More options for camera angles. Sometimes it feels difficult to aim, or I want to get a different view than my two default options, but this is more a personal preference.

Dinkum offers a nice mix of relaxing music and fun visuals, creating a relatively laid-back vibe. Instead of focusing on building, the game leans heavily into farming, gathering materials, and forming bonds with local NPCs. Some players draw similarities between this game and another one featuring a raccoon managing the only store on an island. Fair point, they do share similarities, but there are some notable differences. You can venture beyond the map to explore other areas, including mines and islands. Crafting or buying upgraded weapons and tools is on the menu, and there's a dash of challenge with hostile mobs thrown in. It's spread out just right, allowing you to steer clear of them, if you prefer, but for those craving a bit more excitement, they're there, along with their own brand of bosses. Playing with up to 6 friends? Now, that's a game-changer; it's way more fun than flying solo. I run a Minecraft server, and I can vouch that after watching me play, 7 of our members hopped on the bandwagon and are still hooked on the game.

Full disclosure: I wrote my review and then asked Chat GPT to change redundancies and fix the flow of the review. It is my review, but polished by AI.

This was a surprisingly fun game that I didn't want to put down.  I definitely happily got my money's worth and recommend it, but it did leave me feeling like the game developer stopped writing the story halfway through. I wish there were more to keep doing!

Pros:  The game mechanics are really well designed and most of the basic farming/fishing/collecting you'll do is intuitive and enjoyable.
-Super easy to make money.
-The bad guys are easy to avoid until you actually want to engage them
-The NPCs don't want to marry you, they just want to trade.
-The digging up of treasure with the metal detector is a fun mechanic.
-Lots of options for getting around on the island that can be purchased to make resource gathering less grindy.
-Cooking has a real purpose in this game, and I appreciate that.

Cons:  -I have a feeling this game doesn't really end, and I kinda of wish there was more of a central story arc.  
-The story has this "You need a permit" and "Debt is awesome" mechanic that does help balance progression, but also kinda offends my libertarian tendencies.

So I started playing this game on 12-1-23 and ended up putting in 13 hours on the same day without realizing it. So if that doesn't tell you how enjoyable it is, idk what else to tell you.

The game is well done in general. But I quit out of boredom.

The "progression" of the game is not well designed. There's always a sense of "what do I do now?". Game doesn't do a good job explaining what you can do or how you can do it. You're free to do anything, but you don't know what to do.

Everyday the monotone NPCs give you a ton of chores to do that get boring VERY fast. Catch me this fish. Catch me this bug. Cook me meat. Trade me clothes.

I like farming, but how? I purchased Farming license, but no one teach me how to farm. I don't have the tools to farm and I don't know where to acquire them. Some days later a nomad NPC randomly came to sell me farming equipment and without any explanation I need to figure out how to farm. If you want tips you can talk with NPCs repeatedly and occasionally between the monotone NPCs trashtalk they will provide tips related to, well, whatever they want to at the moment. The farmer girl keeps teaching me where to catch bugs and fish, ok.

Next day she's gone and doesn't come back. NPCs rotate randomly every 2 days so if you mess up something you need to wait for a week or so for them to randomly come back.

Main NPCs tell me if I want them to stay permanently I need to increase friendship level and buy things. Which start another grind where I need to do the chores for randomly appearing NPCs until they decide to stay. It takes months. I'm into Winter and only got 2 of them to stay, and 1 of them is the woman who sell clothes I guess for showing off with friends in multiplayer.

Then I learned nowadays people don't learn about a game from inside the game, they need to alt tab to wiki, visit discord and forums to ask real human to learn how to play games that hava no explanation. Society engagement or some ***t. Well I don't have friend sorry. Gave up.

This is a great, no-stress game. There is a point a little after starting where things become difficult and confusing and it is frustrating. If you keep at it for just a little bit more, it opens up and things get easy again. This game does not do a great job of explaining in-game some of what is going on - particularly with machines and what they do. Once you get the hang of it, it becomes intuitive and easy. I would love to see a little more explanation in the game. Ultimately it is a great way to spend your time. It has elements of Animal Crossing, Minecraft, and Stardew Valley, and is pleasant, cute, and rewarding.

1st Post: I definitely recommend this game 100%! Multiplayer is more significant in this game than Animal Crossing. There are absolutely no restrictions when playing with others. You can build on each other's islands and explore the entire map together basically doing everything the Host player can do. I would like to see a pause button in multiplayer. It would make sense to add one only to whoever is hosting the island, so when they pause it automatically pauses everyone else. Fishing and farming both have very lovely mechanics! I love the fact that there are many different villagers to explore and bring to make the island more accessible and lively. I know a few people who want most of the biomes in a smaller area on their islands and will continuously restart the game for one, because of this I do believe that there should also be an easier way to obtain seeds of islands better. Overall, I can't wait to see what is to come later on!

This game is good, but is extremely shallow.

--You start with about a dozen meal recipes, and those are the same dozen you have for the rest of the game... despite there being tons of ingredients that have no use at all.  Why not add recipe schematics for more meals?

--There are only three farm animal types, and they aren't breedable.  You just pen them, feed them, and milk/shear them.

--All of the other "dimensions" have very similar loot to each other.  Each dimension may have a couple items that you couldn't get in the previous dimension, but they are rare, and 90% of the loot is the same stuff you have had access to all game.  Expect to get 700 buckets of paint for your 4 paintable objects.

--Building is atrocious in this game.  Nothing can be placed on top or underneath anything else.  You can't place a crate on top of another crate, or a pathway under a bridge, or sign over a chest.... you have exactly ONE LAYER of building space, and if you put something down, nothing can go on or below it.

Like I said, this game is decent, and good for about 60 hours... but unless you set some personal goals to catch every fish from every season or something like that, don't expect much depth.

I think this game is slowly becoming one of the best types of cozy but grinding sim games that the community has been thirsting for. So many games for this genre have come out and been complete trash money grabbers. OR for being literally made by big teams- just lazy attempts with no heart!! But with Dinkum, you can actually tell that the Dev likes these kind of games. Its very Animal Crossing meets Stardew Valley and a splash of MySims, set in a very Aussie theme. I think where its headed is lovely.

Plus, many games in this genre have very boring styles for the characters. Which honestly for me, shows how much they don't KNOW the community, yanno? Many of us LOVE customizing and when the characters are either very basic or just ugly- its a very turn off (for me at least but im a creator/artist)! But albeit not the cutest or nicest style, i still think its style is charming. This game is still obviously still being made and not completed but i think the substance that is here is very promising!! And its made by what i believe to be a very small team or just one dude!! Which to accomplish what big ass companies or bigger teams at least could not- wow!! As a beginner Indie Creator and Dev myself, i admire the work put into this game a lot!!

If you're on the fence about buying this game now, lemme personally say that its well worth it especially more so with friends!! I got the whole tism squad on this shit!! ITs very neurodivergent addicting!! And there's something for everyone in the friend group to focus on or hyperfixiate on! I think this unfinished game blows bullshit like fae farm or any of the many forced out crap in this genre, out the water definitely! 

There isn't a whole ton of customizing options but that's still being added to. And honestly i think what it does have is good. There are also POC hairstyles! Even if just a few and many hair colors and fashion to express yourself! Just be aware that its still being added to and only JUST reached the big summer update even though its about to be winter IRL but that's okay, it was worth the wait!! You can tell the dev really cares about making the updates and roadmap actually worth it and didn't just try to force it out for money!! Theres still a autumn and i believee- a winter update on the current roadmap still to be added. ITs obvious that the creator has many ideas still and takes note of what we want!! Which in THIS game economy!?!? RARE LOL

So yeah, I can go on and on breaking down the actual game but im sure mannnyy others did that! Just take this as a thumbs up from a Neurodivergent POC Queer Indie Creator game lover!

My ONLY complaints so far would be: Theres no confirmed dating as of yet but honestly i thought id be bothered more but the game is so addicting you kinda forget!! (me n the homies just pretend we have our hoes), I hope there will be a bit more variety to the things you can find out in nature and the mines, even more inclusive customization obv would be great, more exterior decorations would be nice, more calendar events too although again you don't really notice it too heavily right now with all the other grinding content Rn, and just more variety of everything but im sure most of these are planned!

As of now, my unbiased rating is: 8/10
my biased rating is: 10/10 
(for what is in here so far hehe!)

SO, catch this shit on sale or not- just support this wonderful project so it can get completed and become THE cozy/sim/survival/grinding game of the year already!! <3

Very cute and "animal crossing"-like art style. The "late" time mechanic makes the game very forgiving and is a great idea. It's practically as good as Stardew. The terraforming is probably Dinkum best feature. 

Minor complaint would be:
* Kinda of wish there was a headband and/or flower for your character to wear.
* There should be a cap on the money lost upon being knocked out. And there should be a distinction between being knocked out from exhaustion vs being knocked out from combat.
* Need more cooking recipes and better balancing. 
* Irwin shouldn't run in fear from crocodiles. 
* If Franklin doesn't show up on a semi-regular basis in the beginning, it really sucks having to keep buying and upgrading tool. Had like 30 almost broken shovel before he showed up D:
* I don't think John should sell potatoes or onions. Or if he does, it should be limited to 2-6 per day. Same with Sheila's green beans.
* Kind of wish John has a "item of the day" similar to Sheila's food of the day. But maybe only 1.5x $$$ and maybe only max QTY of 5-20. Same deal with clover, but for clothing.  Melvin for furniture. Thompson for bugs and fishes. It doesn't have to be every day -- "item of the day" was just used to describe the mechanic.
* Kinda wish for an umbrella... as in you select it in your tool belt and your character would hold an umbrella. It doesn't do anything, it's just for ascetics. It seems pointless, but... it seem like this games needs it because it seem very fitting.
* More hair style... but should be exclusive to Sally once you get her shop. Same with color; maybe multi-color? Maybe she should sell one random color paint (except gold and silver) every other day? I just feel bad that she doesn't have much utility compared to the other NPCs. Maybe she sell something that allows you to change your farm animal appearance? For example, a white chicken to a brown chicken.

Biggest complaint:
* There's a lot unnecessary clicking. Kind of wish there was a feature to hold-down to shake trees if you done it as the last action. Same with harvesting crops. Same with inputting items into grill/grinder/furnace/billy-can/keg. Maybe the dirt printer too? hold-down and it keeps printing until it reaches the current ground you're standing on.
* The "i want to chat" followed by the NPC "what do you want to chat about" followed by "lets chat" seems like it can be streamed-line. 

Overall, i think it's a 9/10 game.
Amazing game. Very polished and robust game for early access. I can't wait to see what comes next. Australia is a wild place!

I bought this game after watching a couple of videos and got hooked. I honestly wish now that I hadn't.

Bloomin' Spring Update - Yeah, I knew something would change that I didn't like. The friendship decay with the npcs is super harsh and I really hope it gets an adjustment/way to turn it back off. :( Will not be playing again until this is adjusted. Originally a thumbs up, but I have to change this to a thumbs down until this is addressed.

Also adding the second level to the mines (that are already not a chill experience) is very frustrating. It seems like the dev is going to start pushing more down this "adventure" road rather than keeping the relaxing farming game that people spent hundreds of hours designing cool towns in. 

I got this game because I didn't want romance or combat, I wanted a chill farm and design game.

Apparently the Dev is no longer paying any attention to the Steam forums or even the majority of his Discord area. He's only reachable by a "select few" who are putting bad ideas like the heart decay into his ear and he's listening. 

So even if I had Discord my feedback would be ignored. Guess what? There's more people than just on Discord. I bought this game on Steam, not Discord. (What even is the Discord age group majority?)

Yes, there are mods. No, I don't use mods. Why should I need to risk 3rd party stuff to "fix" things that honestly should be quality of life and/or toggle-able? Not everyone has access to being able to download mods anyway.

The whole point of early access is to work out bugs and listen to the customer feedback. It seems like neither of these is happening, which is a real shame.

I understand that the single dev has got a vision, but either get your "select few" to bug test and then release it into the world fully formed. Or use early access without changing the things that people actually fell in love with about your game. 

If I had waited for full release instead of early access I wouldn't have bought this.

Summer Sun Update - The friendship decay might have had a minor tweak, but it's still happening. Just talking to them should work, I shouldn't have to do more fetch quests, but of course it doesn't. Time to use the Console Commands I guess. I've basically retired my old island for the time being, started a new one using the Console Commands as a sort of sandbox mode to relax and do the things I want to when I want to.

Solo isn't bad so far, but If you are getting this game to play multiplayer, I say wait and come back. From what I gathered:
- you cannot learn D.I.Y.s together
- cannot help progress world together. 
- you have to make a whole new world if you want to bring your character over (good luck once you're done because you won't know enough  D.I.Y.s to be useful and wont be able to learn them in owner's world.) 

It's main person based so if you friend is hosting and isn't talking to Fletcher to knock out deeds, you aren't progressing. Also, the best way to play i guess is progress SUPER far with said character and join friend's new world where they can learn. Still having fun learning game with said friend.

I intend to come back to this game and give it another go but for now it's a downvote.  I set it aside because I got crazy bored because it was moving too slow.  I played for two hours, harvested some food, caught some bugs, sawed some wood and that was mostly it.

I didn't get to anything that felt like fun yet.  Some games seem to add pointless drag as if they are trying to pretend they have more content than they do.  For example, in this game when you harvest, the fruit falls to the ground, then you have to reposition yourself to pick up the different items of fruit.  That's just a really tedious mechanic and I don't understand why some devs build that kind of tedium into games.  Tedium shouldn't be a substitute for content.

I really love the life sim/farming sim genre but I like more a "My time at Portia" pace, where things move along fairly quickly and a lot gets done in a day.   The videos look really cute, but I can't imagine how long I will need to play till I get to the point that I can start planting, farming or even building paths.

There are also too many text boxes and they are ultra repetitive.  Selling items is incredibly tedious - there's a long string of text boxes every time an item is sold and there doesn't seem to be any way to sell multiple different items at once.  Again, inbuilt tedium masking itself as content.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game does many things. It's a relaxing but stimulating enough experience to enthrall you for days. I never played Animal Crossing which is the main game it functions like, also Stardew Valley. The villagers are varied and interesting. You grow to feel the diff personalities really add to the civilization. There is ton to do, even the challenges aren't to a frustrating level and one HUGE thing is that when the day 'ends' it says Late and you can do all your mundane things that don't take a ton of energy such as cooking, log splitting, smelting, etc. Or be crazy like me and take lots of fruits and do all you want all night while spacing out your snacks. Fishing is fun, catching bugs is fun. Animals are cute and farming is fun enough. It rains often enough that watering isn't torture though it would be cool if fertilized soil plots held water 2x as long. The only negative so far that I have... is the colors. It's based on Australian Outback so the colors are designed to be very contrasty yellow and reds, but those colors are very harsh on my eyes and so I wish there was a way to adjust the color just a bit. The dirt in the pine forest have a bit more brown like the mangrove dirt so it differentiates from  everywhere else a bit more would also be nice. Besides the harsh color palette that can't be modified naturally I have rarely enjoyed a game this much.
Definitely recommend for every reason whether want a new game, love sim games, or even as a therapeutic destressor.

After thirty hours in  Dinkum it is well on its way to becoming a great game however as it stands it only moderately a good game because there are some things that need to be fleshed out before its full release. 

The pros:
-Plenty of land to cover with lots to build and manage your town the way you would like it to be.
-Lots of fish and bugs to collect
-Fishing mini game is not that difficult compared to other farming sims
-You can dive along the ocean floor for certain sea creatures
-Lots of forage to gather and plenty of crafting opportunities
-Once you've earned enough license points and gathered the appropriate mining level you can then place the deep mine in your town for some fun and interesting mining opportunities.
-Fun NPCS that you can recruit to your island each with their varying personalities

Cons:
-You're promised farming in this game, but the merchant to get seeds may not show up until the end of the first month as the rotating merchants that come to your island are random and the seeds she sells may not be the ones you want. If you want to get a scarecrow you have to find a watermelon/pumpkin which I have not found out in the wild while foraging. Without a scarecrow the chance of keeping all your crops lessens.
-You have to buy basic tools from the shop, which becomes a problem in multiplayer when everyone wants a specific tool and may use it by the end of the day, the work around is having everyone buy up all their tools on their own islands before joining on a different island in multiplayer, which feels kinda silly.
-You can't craft basic tools just copper/iron tools, but you still need to buy a basic tool from John and convert it into copper or iron
-If you want to repair any tools you have to purchase a 30,000 Dink repair kit and a 60,000 repair bench which needs additional components before it can be built by a merchant named Franklyn that did not show up on my island until day thirty at the end of the first month.
-If you want to recruit Franklyn or any merchant you have to do jobs for for them increasing their hearts and spending an additional 190,000+ Dinks in their shops in order for them to consider to move to your island. You can never recruit them on the first visit and may have to wait an additional fifteen to twenty days or more before they show up again.
-There are roaming NPCS that show up randomly outside your town on your island, but are hard to find due to the size of your island.
I nominate you for steam awards!

I absolutely love Dinkum for its coziness, engaging story, and the delightful interactions with NPCs, all wrapped in charming cartoon-like graphics.
Developed by James Bendon, Dinkum is a life simulator game that draws inspiration from the likes of Animal Crossing, but it stands out with its own unique tweaks and improvements. The game's setting, a fantasy version of Australia, adds a distinctive flavor to the experience. Each quest in Dinkum feels meaningful, and the gameplay choices have substantial weight, creating an immersive world that's both familiar and novel‚Äã‚Äã.
The game's core is defined by its strong quests and well-paced story. The mechanics, including activities like cooking, farming, jetboating, and spelunking, unveil gradually, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging. This pacing ensures that every in-game day brings something new to discover and enjoy‚Äã‚Äã.
One of Dinkum's strengths lies in its flexibility. The game's clock moves faster than real time, allowing for a more dynamic experience. The inclusion of elements like complex fishing mechanics and the presence of dangerous wildlife adds layers to the gameplay. The combat, though simplistic, brings an additional challenge that enriches the exploration aspect of the game‚Äã‚Äã.
The game can be overwhelming at first, with a multitude of tasks and activities. However, as you progress, you find a rhythm in establishing your town, managing resources, and engaging in various activities, from bug hunting to mining. This progression leads to the unlocking of new features, tools, and abilities, keeping the gameplay rewarding‚Äã‚Äã.
While Dinkum's gameplay can be somewhat repetitive, especially for those familiar with life simulators, it's the game's potential for growth and addition of new elements that keeps it exciting. The developer, Bendon, plans to continuously update the game with new content, including seasonal events, characters, and items, which suggests a promising future for this cozy sandbox adventure‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã.
The game's graphics are uniquely cartoon-like, providing an appealing and engaging visual experience. This, combined with the variety of NPCs who visit your island, each bringing their own quests and interactions, adds depth to the game. These NPCs not only contribute to the game's narrative but also assist in various tasks, enhancing the gameplay experience‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã.
 Dinkum is a delightful game that combines the coziness of life simulators with unique mechanics and an engaging storyline. Its cartoon-like graphics and NPC interactions add to its charm, making it a game I thoroughly enjoy and recommend to anyone looking for a comforting and captivating adventure.

It is truly astounding that a development team of one person created this cozy gaming treasure. The developer's passion for this down-under haven has come across very clearly, as new updates have consistently occurred to this already-impressive creation since launch. In the spirit of Animal Crossing and other farm sim games you will find a chill, creative experience here, but with an Aussie twist. You can build, decorate, fish, hunt, mine, aid townsfolk, and farm to your heart's content at a relaxed pace.  No two people's game will be the same because of the enormous level of customization and creation possible here. When you want a break from more intense gaming offerings on Steam, this game is a welcome respite to replace any frustration with joy and any stress with relaxation. It's great to decompress after a long day at work or soul-crushing gaming session with a souls-like. Highly recommended and good value for the price point.

I'll update later, but seeing as I have 65+ hours after playing for less than a week, I figured I'd start this now. 

Imagine Australian Animal Crossing (NH), but you're being bossed around by a grandma, there are giant angry birds, and you have some kickass customization options. I love it, truly. It's a little buggy here and there, but it's honestly smooth for early access. 

-Graphics/performance: ACNH+Minecraft; the colors are SUPER vibrant, so if you have sensitive eyes, you may need to mess around with your pc's color/brightness settings, because I haven't noticed a way to do it in-game. Still running smooth with mods installed. 
-Music/Sound: the music reminds me so much of House Flipper, and I can't tell if I hate it, but I have the music turned down anyways, so potato potato. The thunder crash for thunder eggs makes me jump like a bish every time and I'm still salty. The animal noises are super cute & the villagers sound Animalese-ish. 
-Overall Story/Gameplay: the story is kinda cute. Grandma is a little bossy, but not condescending like a certain tanuki. The friendship system is pretty standard, although the neighbors sometimes have impossible tasks; it's not a game breaking occurrence, just motivation for more unlocks. Definitely grind, but the map is so big that I seriously never get bored of running around and hoarding. 

Overall: 8.5/10; I am absolutely obsessed with this game right now; some QoL features are definitely missing, but moddable. But for those who don't like modding, that could be an issue. 

I'll update later once I've progressed further

Loving this game. If you like Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley, or any similar games you'll get hooked on this. Looks like Animal Crossing but gameplay and progression are much more like Stardew with skill levels and tons of crafting. 
The developer is very clearly passionate about this game and I'm excited to see what is added. For being a single-developer indie game bugs have been very minimal. 
The online functionality is 10/10. Works perfectly to have one town a group of friends builds up and progresses together. Also works amazing to open your single player world up and show stuff to friends.
My only complaints are with farming and mining and they're very simple issues.
Farming takes SO long to level from 1-20. Far longer than any other skill takes to go from 1-20. You don't unlock sprinklers until 20 farming so you need to hand-water hundreds if not thousands of crops before you access sprinklers. (not to mention sprinklers are extremely expensive)
My tip for farming: Grow things like wheat to get XP from harvesting and processing in a mill. Once I switched to growing/processing wheat I started leveling much more quickly. 
The deep mine was very very frustrating before I had endgame tools and weapons. Bats SWARM in the deep mine. Even if you kill them, 5 more will attack you 15 seconds later. Once I had the jackhammer I could mine ore fast enough to keep running from the swarm of bats and devils and crocos. However, while I was using pickaxes I DREADED going into the mine and for the most part ignored it. It really isn't the worst issue but it would be nice to see the bat spawns cut back a fair bit.
My tip: Have Franklyn build a couple quarrys in the early game. This should give you a fair amount of ore while you work on getting a jackhammer and quarries will stay useful into the endgame. I personally wouldn't recommend deep mining without the jackhammer unless you want to spend half the day killing bats.

If you want to make absurd amounts of money fish in the Northern Oceans after 6:00pm in Spring/Summer/Fall. Barracuda are quite common, can easily be spotted, and are worth 16,000 each. I make 250,000 dinks on an average night but have made over 450,000 in one night before. If you are in Spring or Autumn yellowfin tuna can also be found after 6:00 in all oceans and are worth a whopping 25,000 each. Using a rowboat or jetski helps increase profits a ton and the fishing book sold by Theodore after donating enough fish makes locating the barracuda trivial.
