My favourite game in the Cozy Game genre.

Dinkum's main highlight is its progression system. You can unlock many new recipes, abilities and whole game mechanics through purchasing Licenses from an npc. The brilliance comes from how you earn License Points, which is by doing virtually anything in the game. License Points are unlocked via Milestone achievements in an adventure log. These scale up in number depending on how many you've completed, for example: catch 10 bugs, then 50, then 100, then 500, etc.

The great thing is, there is a milestone for doing virtually anything in the game. There's the typical ones you'd expect like harvesting crops, catching fish, etc but there's other ones like for just walking around, or breaking tools, there's even for taking damage. This really makes it feel like no matter what you do in Dinkum, you are constantly progressing and utilizing your time towards unlocking things. In a game that has so much to do the game makes sure its  rewarding you for simply playing and partaking in any of these things. From mining, combat, fishing, farming, crafting, buying and selling items, etc. It means that no matter what you choose to do in a day you feel like it wasn't wasted, which I think is crucial in these types of games.

This game has a little bit of everything! When I want to relax, I can explore, tend my garden, build lovely gardens, with bridges and beautiful landscaping, add more to my towns or just go shopping and find that piece of furniture or clothing that I don't have yet. Like beach combing? Take your trusty metal detector along and dig up treasures or just pick up seashells. If I want a little more challenge, I can hunt Alpha animals or go into the mines and search for treasures below.  I have over 200 hours in and I haven't even played after the summer sun update. It's a game I can go back to again and again. Love it!
Definitely worth picking up , even in early access

This game is fun and it makes me happy when I have a bad day. 
 I love how it's sunny all the time and I can play with my family. We can get lost in the game and forget about how bad things are for a while.  It's amazing and encouraging to think that this was all made by one person.

I did not like this game at first but after looking up how to do a couple things and discovering it was made by one person, I fell in love with it. It's finicky and not everything is explained as well as it should be, but there's an undeniable charm to it. It seems like it's inspired a lot by Animal Crossing and Minecraft, which is a refreshing change from the Stardew Valley analogs I usually play. I'm loving the thrill of sculpting the landscape of my little seaside village and I love that I can spend all day fishing and make a ton of money.

I have a lot of thoughts on what could be improved but my only real complaint right now is how to get enough copper ore to do anything. There's tin everywhere but it seems like almost all important recipes and buildings and tools require a lot of copper and it's NO WHERE TO BE FOUND. I can walk around all day and be lucky to find two veins of it. It seems really broken. I unlocked the mine but I can't build it because I can't find enough copper! 

Anyway, the community around this game seems really sweet and supportive, adding to my love of the game and thankfully providing a lot of guidance for the pieces that aren't explained and aren't intuitive. I definitely recommend this game but can understand it also probably isn't for everyone - it almost wasn't for me until I learned how to fish and realized it's my favorite fishing mechanic of all the farming sims I play! Dinkum is the kind of game that rewards you for sticking with it so if you give it a little love, it'll love you back!

From what I have played so far, I really like this game. It's very similar to Stardew and Minecraft and town development type of game. It's really cute and has great graphics. Controls take a little time to get used to, but you can use a controller as well. There are a couple of downsides imo. There is no borderless window mode so every time I pause the game I have to use the windows button just to be able to access my other monitor. The other downside is that is no major "tutorial" on how to do any and everything. While I don't mind using guides and such, there is no clear way of how to bury a tree seed. After doing it a few times it makes sense but it wasn't that obvious to me. 

I still plan on playing this game tho. c:

I want to say Yes I recommend this but honestly I also want to say NO. It's basically Animal Crossing set in Australia, there's no innovation at all except for maybe the fact you can fight the wildlife like crocodiles and random bush devils. Yes there are mechanics like trapping and going to the mines but the dialogue and chat system and museum thing down to it is all just Animal Crossing. There's no story although they set up some elaborate thing about South City being a drab place etc and it just feels like for people who wanted Animal Crossing but with worse decorating, uglier furniture and more crafting and fighting mechanics. Which isn't a bad thing but it just feels meh. I would say it's good with co-op but there's a bug where if your friend disconnects halfway they lose all their gold spent but don't get it back. So it's very annoying, at least even Stardew just saves their items. The art style also is kind of chibi but not cute enough to be attractive. I don't regret buying this for $15 but honestly I am not that impressed by it. Maybe if I slap some mods on it and like it more.

I don't have any NPC's in my town besides the starter, john, and the Museum guy who's name I don't remember. I did everything I could to get other people to join but they never asked. 

What's worse is they take ages to show back up again. Everything takes so long. This game is clearly inspired by animal crossing, which I have never played but if animal crossing is this slow I don't know how people enjoy it. SO often I was just standing around waiting for everything to happen since there wasn't anything else for me to do, besides fishing which got old quick. 

14 hours in and I still feel like I haven't accomplished anything, I can see the potential, building my own town would be lovely but it would take actual days to get there and I just don't feel anywhere engaged enough to get there. 

Honestly I feel saying no to recommending this game is a bit harsh, its certainly a game that has good merits, a fun aesthetic and a good core game play loop, its just far too slow for me.

Chill game which borrows heavily from the likes of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, puts an outback spin on it, and lets you play with friends. If you like both of those games you'll like this. 

The day cycle takes about 30 minutes at a time, and the game is only saved each night when you go to bed - this has not presented an issue to me at all playing solo, or online in co-op, but I've noted other people mentioning its caused them to lose progress if they lost connection to the host before going to bed, so keep that in mind. 

I find the control scheme a little unintuitive - I often click the wrong mouse button or have to pause and think when I'm trying to use, move or place objects, perhaps something which could be altered a bit to be more natural, or maybe I will play with the controls. 

Some mechanics are not really telegraphed enough - the one that I didn't work out without looking it up is that there is a scale in the shop which can be used to weigh and pay for objects you might find when digging which don't fit in your pockets. This would be alleviated by allowing the player to interact with it and have John explain it to you. 

So far I definitely recommend the game in spite of those quibbles, I'm excited to keep growing my town and actually start designing and laying it out more now that I know what I'm doing. Looking forward to what more is to come as the development continues, but it seems pretty close to done!

Dinkum is a wholesome and fun game often called "Aussie Animal Crossing". Although I have never personally played Animal Crossing, I like what is on offer here. Dinkum is an easy game to play, but loaded with content, two things that make a great game for me. There are a lot of really cool game mechanics, and I love the concept of having to acquire new licenses to do new things. This game slowly opens up into a pretty interesting and deep game, but it does take a considerable amount of time to get there if you are playing solo like I am. Definitely recommend if you are into town builders and Minecraft-style games.

The game is great, and it needs some minor improvements.

Survival system:
The only things you should be concerned about are your health and energy levels. Even though health is easy to handle, energy can be a challenge when you need to do a lot of tasks, as you can only consume up to 3 meals. And if you do not eat on time, you lose some precious time. Mid and end game meals make it easier to manage.

Resident system:
Although it's a nice idea, it doesn't seem to be purely random. On one game, the same resident kept visiting each 4 days. And in another game, he has not come yet, after 3 seasons. Not sure if it's a bug or very bad luck though.

Skill levelling:
Farming is the only area where the difficulty is not balanced. I find it very annoying and very slow. End-game meals are the only ones that provide some XP boost. Despite completing 3 seasons and burying 250 seeds (not trees) of a few things, my level is only 7. It's not motivating.

Otherwise, it's a peaceful game to spend time on

I'll update later, but seeing as I have 65+ hours after playing for less than a week, I figured I'd start this now.

Imagine Australian Animal Crossing (NH), but you're being bossed around by a grandma, there are giant angry birds, and you have some kickass customization options. I love it, truly. It's a little buggy here and there, but it's honestly smooth for early access.

-Graphics/performance: ACNH+Minecraft; the colors are SUPER vibrant, so if you have sensitive eyes, you may need to mess around with your pc's color/brightness settings, because I haven't noticed a way to do it in-game. Still running smooth with mods installed.
-Music/Sound: the music reminds me so much of House Flipper, and I can't tell if I hate it, but I have the music turned down anyways, so potato potato. The thunder crash for thunder eggs makes me jump like a bish every time and I'm still salty. The animal noises are super cute & the villagers sound Animalese-ish.
-Overall Story/Gameplay: the story is kinda cute. Grandma is a little bossy, but not condescending like a certain tanuki. The friendship system is pretty standard, although the neighbors sometimes have impossible tasks; it's not a game breaking occurrence, just motivation for more unlocks. Definitely grind, but the map is so big that I seriously never get bored of running around and hoarding.

Overall: 8.5/10; I am absolutely obsessed with this game right now; some QoL features are definitely missing, but moddable. But for those who don't like modding, that could be an issue.

I'll update later once I've progressed further

Perfect for unwinding after a hard day, or if you want a stress free afternoon. Also, sometimes you get letters from people in town, just thanking you for everything you do, and it's really made bad days feel good again. Pros:

+ Lots of stuff to do: farming, crafting, mining, hunting, trapping, decorate your house etc
+ Decent amount of quality of life options
+ Lots of fun vehicles to make
+ Can be modded to add even more quality of life options
+ Adorable animals and charming aesthetic
+ Isn't real time like animal crossing: the game doesn't expect you to tailor your schedule to a video game

Cons:

- Invert aim option doesn't stick when aiming ranged weapons making it impossible unless you constantly switch the option on and off. I keep mentioning it on forum/discord. It still hasn't been fixed.
- Extremely tedious and grindy
- Expensive mechanical tools can break
- Has a godawful weapon/tool durability system
- Endgame is atrocious AND pointless: spend ages to Grind keys to waste them on treasure rooms that may or may not be empty. Then spend additional ages to eventually get enough ore to make ONE single tool not break, yet it still degrades.... yay!  /s
- Dev hides in a discord server surrounded by yesmen, making more and more questionable decisions, refusing to fix bugs, or listen to feedback.  Completely out of touch with their community.

There is so much to do in this game and it's still in early access! I never knew I needed an Australian Outback survival cozy farming sim game in my library, but I legit can't put it down. I'm so impressed with this game from top to bottom. I've been playing for over a year and I haven't run out of things to do yet.

Cute and addictive, Dinkum is a Life Sim game where you collect resources to grow up your farm and animals in a mostly peaceful World.

The biggest plus is the amount of different things to do: mining, hunting, fishing, finding treasures, exploring underground mines, building the houses and town, animal husbandry and NPCs quests and errands. 

But... somehow it gets easily repetitive! You need energy to complete tasks and you need food to replenish this energy, but at midnight, energy stalls and your character gets chronically slow. That makes the days quite short. Crop seeds are ridiculously expensive as well and the return vs effort curve is reeeeeeally steep and I found it super difficult to level it up. Maybe the game was designed to be played in multiplayer and still needs some tweaking and balancing for single player? 

It is already in a fine state, with some adjustments this will be a great game. Worked perfectly fine on Linux via Steam Proton. No achievements (yet?)

Dinkum is a very relaxing fun game that can be played alone or with friends.

You can build, design, farm, hunt and much more. I would recommend this game to other players as its fun, easy to play and very pretty.  10/10

Edited Review - changed from Positive to Negative: 

My old review was 2 hours in and somewhat hasty. 45 hours in, and a year later, I wouldn't recommend it and not for this price. There's content updates, sure, but there are too many quality of life updates that are basically needed to make the UI tolerable. And it's not like scaling/balancing issues like how resting on your bed should give you stamina, or how the mini map could have NPC markers - it's more issues like, "The scroll wheel will not finish an action if you scroll 'too fast' before the entire animation is finished", "I fell through the floor when I woke up", "the game continues to make sound after I mute the master volume",  "there is no price indication anywhere for any prices" and "there is no inventory or storage autosort".

It's also just god awful slow at starting, like beyond New Horizons initial grind, and I didn't like how woefully inadequate the metal detecting felt without sound - which sucks on an accessibility level but also a technical one that I could not progress with money and plans without being forced to do this metal detecting, with bad ui. 

It's buggy, to summarise. It is not a polished, complete product, and the longer you play it, the more problems appear. And with no objectives other than Fletch's "nookmiles" book that pads out the license grind, and no achievements, it's pretty hollow. 

INB4 "It's early access, it's going to be incomplete and have bugs" - I feel like the base game itself should be functional without the need for mods before they start adding freaking anniversary items and game events. Get out of Early Access and stop the bugs before you start adding extras.
---

For now I will change my review to positive.

While the game has a significant imbalance related to iron, which is essential, it is a very enjoyable game.

Positives

Stable - no crashes
Activities -  Farming, bug catching, mining, museum collecting, relationship building, fishing, and more.
Customization - Vast amounts of clothing, terrain modifying options, furniture, etc.
NPCs - Many different NPCs to recruit and build relationships with, each with their own specialties.


Negatives

Saves - only after the end of a day, which could be 20 or more minutes.
Mines - Very expensive for when it appears and very unbalanced. I was attacked by 5 enemies the first time I entered. Killing bats is difficult due to the timing required to hit them. This was compounded by the inventor only being available 7-9 days over three visits during the first year who makes an item that is almost required for this location. It also requires an expensive pass each time you enter.
Pace - I feel the pacing of this game is far too slow. This is likely heavily influenced by not being able to get enough iron and the lack of inventor availability, in my case. It took 5 seasons to get him to stay on the island.
Requests - NPCs wanting items you cannot make or are ultra rare.
Fun for the whole family

This is one of my top 5 favourite game! It takes place in a very unique location and has a large open world map. It has self guided game play (after the initial tutorial). It has lots of survival aspects as well as crafting, farming (both plants and animals), mining, collecting, hunting, fishing and logging to name a few activities. It even has vehicles: the jet ski is loads fun! You can build your town how you like it and the game is also multiplayer (although I personally haven't played that mode yet). The game is totally playable even though there are a couple of hiccups but to be fair it is still in Early Access and the company is working on developing the game further, adding extra content and fixing any reported issues. I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes open ended, crafty, world building, survival games. I would say it is a collision of all the best parts of Stardew Valley meets Animal Crossing meets Dragon Quest Builders 2.

imagine if stardew valley and animal crossing had a baby but instead of in a nice friendly fictional world, you're in a nice, friendly version of Australia where all the animals can and will kill you but only some of them actually want to at any given time.

It's very fun! There's so much to do( hunting, building homes and a town, attracting people to live in the town, growing crops and raising animals, mining, boating, unlocking different vehicles). Buy it!!!!

The game is early access, and you can feel where there is additional work to do, but for that, it's truly fantastic. I have over 200 hours in on the game, and find it very relaxing to just sit down and play for a "day" or two when I've got some free time. Like Stardew Valley, there's a lot more to it than meets the eye, and you can spend entire days on a theme (such as fishing, exploring, digging, fighting) or just do whatever personal projects you feel like. It's got a similar feel to Animal Crossing, but feels like there are fewer in-game slowdowns, compared to that. (Also, you an create as many islands as you want.)

Finally, for what the developer has coming in the Summer update, I'm excited for the changes to the game as it grows up.

The Cloud sync isn't even working correctly when going from Desktop to Steam Deck. I haven't touched my desktop version since I preferred it on the steam deck. Dinkum is a great game and I highly recommend it. it's one of the few good examples of an early access game that runs fine with a few glitches here and there but already a lot of content and things to do.

The ability to found a small town and shape the environment around you is awesome and I have sunk many hours into slowly transforming the outback. 

I've only encountered a small amount of issues with sometimes conversations get stuck in a loop or starting a new day and falling through the floor but the issues seem to sort themselves out after restarting and playing on.

There is a lot of potential here and I look forward to updates that expand the game further.
It's already one of my favourite games and I still plan to sink more time into it when I can.

I should also say I've only played it in solo mode.
Overall would recommend if you are into these kinds of games.

Before I say anything else, this is a quality game that feels very animal crossing in its style.  There is a lot to love about it. You can design your town, craft, cook, fish, and catch bugs just like any great cosy farming game. For many people this game will be wonderful.  
Where it fell down for me was in the combat. It's everywhere and can come at you at any time, including in your town. The mines were the worst, where it's completely dark and you have to put down torches to see. Sometimes you get attacked just coming out of the lift. Avoiding the mine is impossible,  as you can't get enough resources without going down there.
I suffer with anxiety and this kept triggering my nerves and made me feel bad. I do not recommend this game to anyone who finds in your face, sudden combat anxiety inducing as I do. You are better off choosing a different farming,  life sim. I had to stop playing this game because of it and wanted to mention it in a review in case it would be a consideration for someone else looking at buying this game.
Dinkum is relaxing. You can play at your own pace, and no combat except for a few animals that would love to kill you. But not all the time and they can be avoided.

Dont listen to the people saying this is like Stardew Valley; the vibe is COMPLETELY and utterly different! 

First of all the setting is obviously not a seasonal one like in Stardew, but tropical and therefore quite monotonous. You mostly get endless, glaring, harsh sun, ouch D: 
Secondly, the graphics have a much paler/colder pastel'y  Nintendo64 feel, compared to Stardews old school, warm, pixel looks. So anyone  expecting to get the same cozy feels as they did in Stardew, will be disappointed. This one doesnt have any of the warmth, coziness and mystical vibes of Stardew, unfortunately! 

As far as gameplay goes its allright, and its pretty cute in its own, strange way! Its mildly exciting during the initial phase of the game, moving to a remote island and getting set up is quite fun. At 36 hours however I feel stuck, and not sure if I can be bothered to continue doing the same things over and over again. I cant figure out how to get more islanders to move in, and the endless cycle of bringing the NPCs gifts is getting very repetitive. Theres not much of a storyline or depth of any kind, so it all feels kinda .. pointless? I feel like I should apply sunscreen while playing this, but I dont wanna be sticky.

positive:

Dinkum is the perfect game if you want a mix of Stardew Valley, Animal Crossing and Minecraft. It's not as complex as the games listed in direct comparison when it comes to the specific abilities and possibilities each of these games provide, but it's a very good mix overall.

Easy to learn and still with a decent amount of depth. Yes, it's a lot of farming, crafting and building. Not to forget grinding is also part of it, but it's not necessary to grind excessively. You can play the game in short sessions and not regularly and still feel the progress over a pretty short period. If you like these attributes or even love these kind of games, Dinkum could be your game.

Also not to forget it's extremely relaxing. You can progress even while mostly growing plants. Yes, you will reach end game later, but you are not forced into a hardcore grind or something.

One of the best games of the genres i've played and not to forget to mention it's low price.
For me it was absolutely worth the price and time i've put into the game.


neutral: 

I wish there would be more variety when it comes to the amount of possible villagers or more enemies. Some people may not like the setting (Australia flair).


negative:

It has it's flaws, like some minor bugs, others are at least a bit annoying here and there. Disconnecting in Multiplayer leads to lose the progress like items for example (that happens not often but should still be mentioned until it's totally fixed).
This game is incredibly addicting, and great with friends.

This game is massive and adorable. At this point i'm 128 hours in and have so much content left to do. I'm just gonna get it out of the way early in case it's not what you're looking for but this game is a grind. Luckily it's not so much of a do the same thing over and over and over till you hate the game(although if you get the bright idea to relocate an island or waterway it quickly can be). The grind in this can take any shape you want it to, at the end it just comes down to the almighty dollar. Gotta buy stuff right? I know it might seem like i'm bashing the game but i'm not. Limitless potential in this game. The goal? Build a town. You start with a sleeping bag and gotta build an entire town. Tons of decorations, paths, lighting options, etc. Incredible creative freedom. I've heard it reminds people of Animal crossing. Don't know never played it. I have however spent a lot of time on Dinkum, and you should to!
With over 300 Hours now into the game, its still as addicting as the first day I started!

A One-Man Wonder Down Under! ü¶ò

I'm still rubbing my eyes in disbelief that Dinkum is the brainchild of a single developer! This game is an expansive sandbox adventure that lets you explore, build, and thrive in a stylised Australian outback, and it's packed with enough content to rival titles created by much larger teams.

The attention to detail is jaw-dropping‚Äîfrom the variety of native flora and fauna to the intricacies of the crafting system. Whether you‚Äôre wrestling crocs, building your dream Outback homestead, or chilling with your mates around a campfire, Dinkum offers an experience as diverse as Australia itself.

It's not just the scale; it's the heart in this game that impresses. You can sense the love and care poured into every pixel and game play mechanic. And because it‚Äôs continuously updated, each visit feels like a new adventure waiting to unfold.

If you're a fan of open-world exploration and don't mind dodging a virtual snake or two, Dinkum is the bush-tastic experience you've been searching for. One developer, one vision, and a whole continent to explore‚Äîwhat more could you ask for? ü¶ò

If you're like me and became absolutely obsessed with animal crossing, but now find your life empty because animal crossing is over and no longer getting new content, then I have WONDERFUL news: this game has a very similar feel, but not in a "hey, they copied animal crossing!" kind of way. Dinkum is unique, while still delivering that familiar mostly-cozy feel. There are aggressive wildlife to watch out for- or hunt, if that's your thing- a great crafting system, customization, design, exploration, and, most importantly, you get to invite people to move to your island! The creator does an amazing job at tying everything together in a way that doesn't cause burnout or dread at the next step. Honestly a lovely game and I regret not making a review sooner!

Dinkum is a genuinely great game that feels like what Animal Crossing and Harvest Moon are supposed to be. Maybe in comparison to Stardew Valley the game feels inferior, and I think that's true largely to polish, but the idea of building up the whole town, the whole world being your sandbox, in comparison to just a small slice is an awe-inspiring and encouraging feat to tackle. I recommend Dinkum to all, and my more detailed thoughts on the highs and lows are as follows:

+1: The art style of the game is genuinely adorable, like Animal Crossing but warmer and lest harsh on the eyes. Even looking out over the haze of the world across the ocean is something I find myself doing.

+2: The settlers all feel very unique and have a great personality all their own. Though Clover may be a cultist/serial killer, I find myself really clicking with each of the NPCs in different ways, and unlike a game like Stardew, I generally engage with all of them fairly equally.

+3: The wildlife of the world helps it feel like it's always moving, and therefore keeps me wanting to enjoy the beauty of the natural generation.

+4: The shovel-scrap-finding mechanic is actually a really cool idea, and helps make the crafting recipes more reasonable and fun to gather supplies for.

+5: A weird one, but I love the vehicles in the game. I just wish the sailing boat was easier to get the recipe for.

-1: The deep mines are mechanically unbalanced. I don't like having to pay a big chunk every time to use it, especially when it already takes so much to build the elevator. The cost of losing day of progress elsewhere all for some stone and extra ore doesn't feel like it's worth an extra 25k every time you want to use it. Even the secret rooms require keys and collectables that can be hard enough to find. Add to that the difficulty at level 2 and I think the only way to not feel like you've been wasting money and time is if you reset the day when you die; a mechanic I hate doing but often do because of how overpowered those lizards are. I think the elevator passes should be one pass to unlock that level (25k for lvl1, 75k for lvl 2, etc) for unlimited uses and/or the base cost and materials to build the elevator should go up.

-2: Minor, but crafting should really use nearby chests. It's tedious to go back and forth to chests to find things, even with the help of the checklist. It would also help to craft multiple at once: let the game spend 2 minutes crafting a ton of paths while I go to the bathroom rather than have to sit and click a button every 3 seconds.

-3: Crafting blueprints themselves... super tedious and annoying to get. I wish there was more consistency in when you'd get them from NPC quests, offer them in lieu of bulletin board dinks, and give more variety at Franklin's lab. At the very least I'd like to see all the recipes I'm still missing, just greyed out, but more over I think it would be nice to have a wider range of available recipes at shops or some indication as to a blueprint reward for completing a certain request.

-4: Shop inventories in general are frustrating, especially Rayne's seeds. I understand furniture and clothes being a small rotating selection and a list of everything you've already gotten and want more of, but it's really annoying when she doesn't have the seeds you want. There should be a full selection at all times. The same goes for John's goods, at least regarding food and parts as getting Sheila to the island requires so many flour, sugar, and crops that are seasonal and hard to get early means you'll take forever to actually be able to get her recipes.

-5: Either remove the penalty from failing to make a daily request or give the option to speak to the NPC and back out. It's very annoying when RNG means you can't find an item that you've spent a day searching for or it turns out you're missing one ingredient for the recipe. This would also allow you to actually put harder requests like rarer fish and bugs without deterring players all the time.

-6: Rechargeable tools shouldn't break when they drain. I hate that I can't get better tools because every opal has to go to new dirt printers because the bar doesn't always drain at the same rate. It doesn't make sense that the mining helmets turn off when they run out but a power tool just evaporates.

Again, most of these are fairly minor, and for an early access game. Let me know your thoughts, but I hope the developer takes things like these from a heavy player into account. I love everything you've done, and just want the game to be as approachable and fun as it's clearly built to be! Keep adding such wonderful colour and life to the world, I can't wait to see what else it fills with!

I wanted to play about a month in-game time before I decided to review this game since that sounded like a fair amount of time to get a feel for most of the gameplay systems for an early access game like this. So, here are my thoughts on Australian Harvest Moon with a dash of Animal Crossing.

For an early access title, it's pretty fun! There's a lot of things that are there at the jump for you to interact with once you unlock them, from farming and animal rearing to fishing and animal hunting. You go out into your own little outback and start to build a little town from the ground up, enticing townsfolk into your little community by doing tasks for them. At the time of this review I have only 4 people in my town and the last one to finish a major task hasn't wanted to join my town. There is also a debt system similar to Animal Crossing with building any building and the prices are a BIT high, especially for the beginning of the game.

Another problem I have is that it feels like resources for certain things are sort of hard to find? Copper especially seems very scarce to find once tin/iron seem to be the main material for most crafting materials. Granted I did just unlock the deep mines so perhaps more ore is plentiful down there. The game music also doesn't really loop much, going into long stretches of time with no sound.

A MAJOR problem that is a bit of a nit-pick is that time in game does not freeze unless you hit a button in the book menu to actually pause the game. Talking with npcs and buying/selling things does not freeze the time so it feels like you're in a rush to do these actions unlike most farming sim games of this variety.

Overall, the experience is fun and it is enjoyable to play with only a few minor things that dampen the fun only slightly.
Loving this game !!
What Animal Crossing should have been.

There is a particular sort of individuals that will adore this game. They either have it or will grab it asap as soon as they are made aware of it.

For everyone else, this is a mishmash of ACNH + Stardew + 3D Harvest Moon + Minecraft. It lacks the soul and charm of all. Like a pale imitation or copy. Even the emotes seem like they were added without much understanding (they're weird). An air of awkwardness permeates Dinkum. If you never managed to get into Minecraft because it quickly starts to feel like work and a manual labor simulator... Dinkum feels more like work than a game. Tons of tasks, chores, tedium, and monotony. I didn't care for the aesthetics either. Pixelated and generic. 

The game just didn't work for me. That preview video at the top of the page is after hundreds of days. This game seems like a, "It gets better once you get out of Midgar." game if you know what I mean. Don't expect jetskis and hang gliders when you start.

I had "No" selected while writing this review. I don't imagine the vast majority will stick with it through to the end. I think like many indie games, most are for a niche group of players. However, for the amount of play hours Dinkum will provide for it's cost and the fact that its like the first game to finally try to merge so many other games into 1, I switched it to "Yes". I have no plans or patience to play this anymore. 

My favorite thing about 'Dinkum' is just how lazy it makes Nintendo appear to be. ACNH was a big disappointment. Ridiculously shallow. Extremely time gated. Probably a huge team of experienced developers and what we got is what they sold us for 60 big ones ($). A tiny indie game crams more content in for just 20 ones. The state of AAA gaming anymore  is depressing.

Voting with your wallet is getting harder every year in video games and indie games will be the last shining oasis for many gamers to cast their votes and still have a voice. I don't feel bad about buying this game. Maybe years from now, I'll be in a better place mentally where I won't mind dropping 100+ hours on a chores sim game again. Its like my stamina bar needs to refill. Until then, this is a vote I'm happy I made.

Honestly, I have to say it... "FINALLY!". Every time a game is popular and does well, copycats come out of the woodwork and release their version in an attempt to get a slice of that sweet pie... or improve upon ideas. Look at 'Vampire Survivor' or any match 3 game, WoW clones, Minecraft clones, the GTA like games. Animal Crossing came out in the 90s. The nineties! It was successful. For decades. No copycats. Top selling game over Covid. Nothing. Then this game releases. Maybe there are other attempts out there, but I don't remember them and never heard of them. ACrossing is a low low bar too and it still took all these years. Really quite strange if you think about it...

Did you enjoy playing Animal Crossing growing up but realized when you became an adult you couldn't play it again without it taking up a part-time job time frame out of your schedule? Then this is the game for you. Dinkum is wildly similar to Animal Crossing but it really adds many fun twists of its own. From being able to go to a mine shaft daily that changes the map every time to hunting for food to use for energy, to exploring a massive island with various terrains, this game has a lot to offer.

It's exciting, similar but different, and massively addictive. Those 81.2 hours of mine were in an embarrassingly short period of time. As with all my reviews on early access games, I take a prediction on the future of the game, and I believe Dinkum has a bright one. From what I know this game is a one man show, but he is doing a fantastic job and adding awesome things to the game so far and down the line.

This game is Animal Crossing X Stardew Valley set in Australia. There is nothing not to love here. I see many, many hours of my life spent in this game, and I look forward to future content and official release. I have been playing over 80 hours and I can surely affirm that this is THE BEST GAME OF ITS GENRE! It's relaxing and simple but never boring, it has a varied gameplay but still it feels like always playing in a 'comfort zone'. I love the ideas, the coherence and above all the BALANCE, which is a rare to find feature in this kind of game (that they are easily known to be "farming" games where you have to struggle for hours repeating over and over the same exact boring task, or too boring and without a real purpose or challenge).  Another nice and rare to find feature is the music, varied and relaxing. Plus, I also appreciated the fact that sometimes there is just silence and no music. Deep congrats to the creators! <3

Relaxing, easy game play. 

102 hours of playtime, and there are still new varieties of animals, plants, and resources to discover, let alone explorring the underground mines for a bit more "action-packed" gameplay. 

Excellent game to kick back with a spliff and kill some time in a satisfying way- if construction/building sim is your thing. Multi-player works seamlessly and it is great to build a town together with a mate and let your imaginations run wild, from homes, to landscaping to waterfalls. 

I give it a solid 9/10.

It's like Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley had an Australian baby that was just as innocent as their parent's but maybe a bit more mature and easier to understand 

But as easy as it is to compare this game to its obvious influences, particularly where AC is concerned, I think it's important to note how unique this game is as well. As an Aussie who loves both aforementioned games, I am absolutely the target audience for this product and I just love this so much! All the references to Australian culture, the wholesome vibe, the relaxing nature of building your town however you like with no time restraints or pressure, it's just a very cozy and enjoyable game with really nice visual and audio feedback, and an addictive gameplay loop where I've lost 9+ hours without even realising it

In Dinkum, you can immerse yourself in a world filled with farming, crafting, and adorable elements. You'll need to gather resources, cultivate crops, and raise animals on your farm. With those resources, you can craft tools, items, and structures to expand your farm and explore the game's world. The game provides a space where you can unleash your creativity and design your farm exactly the way you want it. So, if you're into farming, crafting, and cute aesthetics, Dinkum is definitely the game for you!

Great game if you want to build a town from scratch, but I do have some feedback. The progression mechanics are really awkward, especially at the beginning. Getting people to join your town feels really arbitrary and takes forever. The combat is also really rough, there are crocodiles EVERYWHERE and they're really annoying. I wish there was a way to keep them away from my house and the town at least. And the mines are really rough too, it really sucks when you get swarmed right out of the elevator and die, especially when going to the mines is so expensive. Either combat needs to be easier or the mines need to be a one time cost, or there needs to be some kind of armor or something. It's a sandbox game, I'm not here to fight for my life every 2 minutes.

The last game like this I played was Animal Crossing New Leaf. I've tried like 10 times to get in to Stardew and I can't do it. Dinkum is... simply put..the Stardew Valley game made for Animal Crossing fans and its better than both. It also brings over some elements from Minecraft and lets you really shape/build/customize your town. In my case its Sean's AssFarm. 

Heavy Emphasis: All the bullsh** in Stardew that makes you feel like the game is overcomplicated is non-existent here. It maintains the Animal Crossing simplicity but also doesn't make you feel like youre getting diminishing returns for playing on a single given day. (This was a problem in New Leaf for me) 

Its in "early access" but this game couldve launched anytime now. Its more than polished. Impressive game.

Great, cute game with friends.  Few hiccups in multiplayer but they're being fixed fairly quickly.

I looked at this game for a long time while i debated buying it and happened to snag it at the very last day of the summer sale this year, but didn't get to play it because i ended up in the hospital. After i got home, i was looking for something to play and feeling very blah so i jumped into this hoping it would be the thing that made me feel better and it is! I was thinking it would be a sort of bland "farm together" task sort of simulation game (i love simulation games don't get me wrong) but it's actually much more than i thought it would be and i'm kind of hooked now!

It's been really cool recovering while playing this game. I haven't even explored the entire map, but i absolutely LOVE this game! I really enjoy the fact that everything, or nearly everything has a use or a purpose and a lot of the items aren't exactly easy to get & take a bit of grinding to obtain.

Some of the animals i thought would be hostile aren't while some i thought would be very tame are not so it's definitely keeping me on my toes. i am pretty impressed with the overall weather and wildlife in the game  especially seeing as one sometimes seems to effect the other as well as time of day and many other things. There is a LOT to do and residents to help out and convince to stay, things to build, and Dinks(money) to earn.

Over all, super happy with this purchase. This turned out to be a really cool game. i hope there are updates in the future and other possible games similar to this from this dev.

Some stuff to note:
* "passing out" or dying damages all your tools, so avoid that!
*Sleep to save your game if you log out without sleeping until the next day everything you did will be unsaved.
*If you buy chooks from Irwin, pen them in first so the dingos don't eat them, because it's nearly impossible to pick up an animal once you have placed it!
*Help EVERYONE! it makes them want to stay in your town and that ultimately helps you out a lot! They will also help you out with items and dinks.
* BUILD! especially a bulletin and some of the cooking and crafting tables. 
* Check your mail! There's cool stuff in there and tips about stuff you definitely want to know about.
GOOD

The best of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley with an Australian flavour. 

So, imagine Animal Crossing... but good. All the stuff that annoyed me has been fixed. The stuff you craft has a purpose, but you also get to wear fun outfits. You still get to go fishing, but you can actually SEE the fish under the water. 

You can keep chickens and they lay eggs. You can cook meals and eating them gives you buffs. You get hungry and tired so you actually do have a reason to eat or to rest. Water plants and grow them. Go fishing and actually see which fish is which under the water! You can hunt. You can mine. You can build your town and make friends and run errands for people. 

Still in early access but absolutely playable, with the occasional Need Text Here placeholders in speech bubbles. 

The more I play the more addicted I get.

My biggest question is, how is this game still in Early Access?  It's simply wonderful and already very polished!  It takes what made Animal Crossing so enjoyable and expands and enhances it in a number of ways.  Pretty much bug-free and with very wide-ranging play.  I can see some quality of life adjustments being possible as the game moves to full release, but as it is right now, it's an absolute gem.  Highly, highly recommend!
Bad multiplayer makes this a no go for me

99% exactly the same as Animal Crossing with all the Nintendo fat removed. Seamless controls, satisfying progress without laborious dialogue that you can't skip. Oh and there's no Nintendo tax so the game is a reasonable price. Caution, the gameplay loop is addictive!
10ZINGERS/10

The perfect blend of AC, SDV, and Minecraft. I almost got hung up on the 'Down Under' theme, but I'm glad I looked past it. The game is excellent, not gimmicky at all, and best of all has no cringe "fan service" stuff that seems to seep into every game. Well done.

The game itself is fine if you are 4 to 17 years old. For a grown hairy man like me, the game is boring, bland and soulless. I have a tendency to puke violently when I play awful games and in my first minutes of playing I have done just that. This game makes me light headed and fatigued from the lack of game in this game. 
Let alone how the bugs in this game completely ruin the whole map. Lots of features do not work, or are there for no reason. The restaurant for example, you cannot eat the food that you buy there. If this is a role-play game, how come I cannot eat and drink in the place I bought it from. One time I had a bug where when I sat in any seat, the invisible barber lady asked me if I wanted to get my hair cut or colored.

But, then again, it could be just me.

„ÄÄIf you're familiar with Animal Crossing, then you'll get the idea, but this time without the furry or cat characters to dance and making baby with. Love this game. I would rate it an 11 if I could and it didn't  have bats. It is not just another builder game that quickly gets boring. There is always something to do and is versatile enough to give you many options. If you like to design and build towns, there is a wide variety of materials and decorations . You can also explore, hunt, fish, farm, mine or race your vehicles around the islands. Though I have never played multi-player, you can even have friends join you. Being an early access game, I have come across a few minor glitches like weird head rolls, but have never had a single game crash or any other bug that affects game play. I recommend this game to all my friends. If you like games like Stardew Valley, you will love Dinkum.

This game is riddled with bugs that the developer knows about but won't fix. They're not usually game-breaking but still very frustrating. Check the Dinkum Discord channel to see just how many there are. Usually bug reports are met with 'This is a well known, common bug. Use this inconvenient workaround/deal with it' but no actual fix seems imminent. Makes the game seem more like a cash grab than a passion project. Having read the reviews, I had high hopes for this game to satisfy my Animal Crossing itch. Unfortunately, it fell short.

While it does share some similarities with Animal Crossing in its small features, there's a significant missing element: the villagers. Instead of regular residents, all characters on your island serve specific functions like shopkeepers, quest givers, instructors, museum head, etc. Though you can form bonds with them, the depth of those bonds is limited. Furthermore, the lack of variety in characters makes the experience predictable for everyone as the order in which your island grows does not change.

One minor gripe I have is the monotonous landscape, entirely comprised of different shades of brown. It becomes visually dull with no diversity. Incorporating different biomes or the full implementation of seasonal changes could significantly improve this aspect.

Overall, the game is okay, but I wouldn't recommend it if you're seeking an Animal Crossing-like experience.

Dinkum is a fun co-op experience and an enjoyable, lighthearted take on the survival genre with an Australian twist. 

This early access title takes heavy inspiration from games like Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley. 

While the game is largely refined and plays well on the Steam Deck, I anticipate future updates and features to expand on the late game content.

Even in its less than version 0.5 state the game is rather good and there's a lot to keep you busy. I recommend reversing the mouse Y axis in the options and also set Mouse Always Move Camera for the best experience on PC. I'll update this review as the game gets closer to 'done'. FYI the game runs clean and smooth in Linux Mint without Proton.

I don't write much reviews but I just gotta put my time in a review for this game. It absolutely deserves the love it gets. This game actually feels rewarding to do even the most basic tasks. When you unlock licences by Fletch's tent/town hall, this game doesn't hold me down for anything. 

You can get sprinklers to water the crops for you, there's animals and bosses to defeat, there's hidden (and regular) NPCs that can give you the best stuff in the game if you have the resources, if you reach a good friendship with an NPC they can fight, farm, and harvest with you and a cave system that has some cool items like the glider, a wand that can spawn rocks/ore, a bottle that can make the game rain and more that i haven't even discovered yet. (At my pace lol) Watch out tho if you're new, it can be quite challenging

This games community is sweet too. The discord has a ton of nice people that can help and even have a tab for mods! Just watch out for those random public lobby trolls.

The one thing I was afraid of is overabundance the orange desert look when I made my purchase. However when you have the flooring you want, you can make even mountains have an industrial look if you really wanted to. So don't worry about that :)

Overall a must buy especially if you wished more from New Horizons or a fan of chill games like this. 
Lastly before I finish this review, Clover is an absolute sweetheart! Love her to bits >w< and thank you James for making such a fantastic game <3

I adore this game! It has the concepts from minecraft I loved but with added interactions from towns people like animal crossing! I enjoy making my own town with different maps each time. I enjoy that my map can at any point change from single player to multi-player without being restricted to always being single player on a save. Fishing is very fun and I even miss a few so its not too easy. I love seeing everyone's shared pictures of their unique towns! 
 Only draw back for me is I have to step away a lot while playing games and as much as I love the pause button..... I would like the sleeping bag to save without having to end my whole day. I accidently logged out inside my tent but without sleeping first on day three and cried at all the progress id lost. 
However i am absolutely enjoying this game and 100% am going to force my friends to buy and play with me! Can't wait to see what is coming!

Just got this game the other day and, so far, it's very addicting.

As many have said, Dinkum most definitely takes inspiration from games like Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley. At first, it might almost feel like you're playing an AC fan game, which is far from being a bad thing as AC is incredibly addictive and time-consuming in the best way. For example, you'll never run out of things to do thanks to a daily task system which gives you 3 optional tasks daily. These small jobs can be anything from mining to helping out your neighbors with their requests, and completing the tasks will give you special currency which you can spend on upgrading your toolset and things that you're allowed to do on your island.

Speaking of the islands, there are a few small areas where this game doesn't act like it should. For example, when you start the game you get a randomly generated island where you begin your first few tasks. These tasks are mandatory for progressing into the more open parts of the game. Unfortunately, on my first time generating one of these islands, I was spawned on a small sand circle where the closest island with the resources I needed to progress was farther than I could swim with the current energy bar. That meant I was stuck and had to start a completely new save. Fortunately, I got a far better island the second time around. Aside from that, the only other issues I've experienced with the game so far are small visual errors such as water tiles not being seamless and my character managing to stick his head through one of the NPC tents.

Overall, despite its few bugs and poor design choices, Dinkum is a great game for anybody looking to express their creativity in a long-term town builder. If you're a fan of Animal Crossing, you'll most definitely enjoy this game. Even if you aren't or haven't played Animal Crossing before, I'd still recommend trying Dinkum as long as you're a fan of building/slow-progression games. It's perfect for all ages despite having a more cartoonish style.

In total, I give Dinkum an 8/10. :)

"Dinkum" is a truly remarkable game that completely captivated me from start to finish. Developed by a talented team, this immersive gaming experience offers an extraordinary journey through a richly crafted world filled with adventure, excitement, and a touch of mining.
 From the moment I launched the game, I was immediately drawn in by its stunning visuals. The attention to detail is simply breathtaking, with lush landscapes, vibrant colors, and meticulously designed characters and creatures. The world feels alive and vibrant, making exploration a joyous endeavor. Whether it's navigating through dense forests, scaling treacherous mountains, or delving into mysterious Caves, each environment is a visual treat.
The game-play mechanics in "Dinkum" are seamless and intuitive. The controls are responsive and easy to grasp, allowing for smooth navigation and engaging combat. The combat system itself strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and depth, offering a wide variety of skills, and play styles to cater to different player preferences. Whether I was engaging in epic sword fights or mining in the depths, every encounter felt dynamic and satisfying.
One aspect that truly sets "Dinkum" apart is its compelling story-line. The game weaves a captivating narrative, filled with memorable characters and unexpected twists. The quests and side missions are well-crafted, immersing players in intriguing subplots that add depth to the overarching story. The dialogue is excellently written, further enhancing the emotional connection to the game's world and its inhabitants.
Furthermore, the sound design and musical score deserve special recognition. The ambient sounds transport players into the heart of the game, whether it's the rustling of leaves, the echoes of footsteps, or the distant howls of mythical creatures. The enchanting soundtrack perfectly complements each scene, evoking a range of emotions from wonder and excitement to tension and melancholy.
The level of polish and attention to detail in "Dinkum" is truly commendable. The game runs smoothly, without any noticeable bugs or glitches that could detract from the experience. The user interface is intuitive, making it easy to navigate menus, manage inventory, and track quests.
In conclusion, "Dinkum" is an outstanding gaming experience that I highly recommend to all fans of adventure and fantasy. With its breathtaking visuals, immersive game-play, captivating story-line, and stellar audio design, it sets a new standard for excellence in the gaming industry. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the genre, "Dinkum" promises an unforgettable journey that will keep you enthralled from beginning to end.

"Dinkum" captured my heart from the moment I started playing. Reminiscent of Animal Crossing, this charming game's graphics and setup instantly drew me in, creating a comforting and immersive experience.

I genuinely adore this game and the direction it's heading in. The blend of relaxing gameplay, captivating aesthetics, and the promise of future updates makes "Dinkum" a must-play for fans of life simulation games.

With each new update, the potential for even more engaging gameplay and delightful surprises increases. I'm eagerly looking forward to what the future holds for "Dinkum" and the exciting experiences it has in store for players.

In conclusion, "Dinkum" is a delightful journey that captures the essence of beloved life simulation games. Its reminiscent style, coupled with the promise of future updates, makes it an enchanting and worthwhile experience. I simply can't wait to dive back into its world and discover all the new content awaiting me.

I think this game has a lot of potential to be one of the best in its genre, however, in its current Early Access state, it feels a bit empty. This game feels like a good mix of Animal Crossing and Stardew valley. However, it's lacking in that the game feels a bit empty and soulless. The NPCs are great, but since there aren't a lot of them, the island feels like a barren land.

The wiki says there are 8 biomes total, but it really just feels like there's 2-3 that are the same but have different colored grass and trees. I'm not sure if I'm playing the game the wrong way, but after 13hrs, I am still in Summer, which I only bring up because that means I've only seen about 3-4 different bugs on the entire island and maybe 4-6 different fish, regardless of the time of day. This island also takes a good amount of time to walk from one side to the other, and the only thing I see along the entire walk are trees, water, and foliage. The animal life is pretty sparse and not too diverse.

Worst of all, I think a lot of this could be remedied if the early game weren't so slow. The energy system feels like something that creates a large unnecessary grind to maintain your energy and keep food supplies for it. Maybe it gets better late game, but it seems to have a lot of grind associated with it to get to the fun part of the game like the trailers have where you have an established town and a nice island. After enabling cheats to see, it also seems like there isn't a whole lot of options for decoration in general.

I think if the game had more to it, it could be very enjoyable. More bugs, fish, and critters would make the island feel more alive. For example, Animal Crossing has anywhere from 20-30 different bugs and 20-30 different fish that can spawn per month, so if the game had something like that with their season system, that would help the island feel more diverse. Also, maybe increasing the spawn rate of insects once there are more would help. 

Another thing that would help is more decoration. Again, I know it's early game and making all of these things takes time, but with Animal Crossing, there's a LOT you can do both in your house and on your island. With Dinkum, even after 13hrs, I have almost 0 decorative options for outside aside from pathways and fences. Maybe I missed a vital part of the game, but I don't have any recipes to make furniture with.

It might be important to note that I played this solo. Maybe it's more fun with friends? I think in another year or two, I think this game will be a solid 10/10, but as of right now, it's still a bit too rough around the edges for me.

I've played a *lot* of terrible games that are trying to recapture the playability of Minecraft or Stardew Valley or Raft or many other games that have a blend of any or all of building/exploring/crafting/socializing.  A loooot of games.  Dinkum was... a pleasant surprise!  It's definitely not as developed as either of the above games, but it does reflect the spirit of both games.  And I do want to distinguish that from 'ripping off' SV or MC which, again, a LOT of (terrible) other games have ended up being.  Dinkum definitely has many of the same features, but it's all its own flavor.  The world design - characters, objects, animals - are unique and appealing, the map design is clean and distinctive, the quests and gameplay revolve around a novel story.

On an initial playthrough I found the gameplay very cute, but a slow grind to build the town.  I put it down for awhile, and recently picked it back up - after I stumbled on a discussion that it had mod support!  I downloaded what I wanted and fired the game back up.

Now, I'm not here to say that the game isn't good without mods - there are plenty of people who love it as is.  But the beauty of a game that allows mods is in how it can affect the game.  Worst case scenario, your game remains mostly unplayable but people play longer than they would otherwise because the mods do everything they can to fix what the makers didn't (cough cough, Skyrim, cough cough, My Time At Portia).  Best case scenario is that it can draw in hitherto uninterested players and greatly expand the fanbase, as well as greatly increasing the amount of replayability for those fans.  So I think it's well worth pointing out that while it's not yet workshop enabled (I believe James has stated that he's hoping to implement that later), there are mods available outside of Steam and while the setup is a bit confusing at first (I had to find a tutorial), once you've got the basics done it's very, VERY easy to add and remove, and I have yet to discover a conflict between what I've chosen.

So what type of mods have made this game more playable for me?  Well, first of all, I have ADHD, and I have worked some VERY stressful jobs in the past.  When I open up a game such as Dinkum or any of the similar I listed, I'm looking for a game that is very peaceful, very isolating, something that makes me feel as if I'm alone in a non-threatening world where I can go as I please and make as I please.  The scenery, the design, and the music all make that happen, and the rest is simply tweaking.  So I turn off animal hostility because I want them to be part of the peaceful and beautiful environment I interact with, not something that's constantly distracting me from it.  I make fish and insects stackable and able to be put in containers because trying to track gifts and quest items tweaks the ol' ADHD anxiety.  I add a sprint feature because I love running and leaping like a gazelle.  I add a communism mod because listen, I'm the one out here doing all the hard work of building and gathering for everyone else's profit, so y'all are gonna get your taxes on new buildings upped, deal with it.  Inventory management, because again, ADHD YIKES.

I do have more but the point is, purists would point at the above and yell "that's not the same game anymore!" and my response is "yeah... isn't it *great*?"

Making a game takes a lot of work - a LOT of work.  This game's maker has clearly put their heart into it and they've been very good with providing updates on the progress as well as releasing new content to try and keep people interested while working toward an official release.  Putting aside their ego enough to keep their game friendly to mod makers and to people like me is simply the sign of a very good creator - a creator with a healthy ego that allows for room in their world for people who aren't exactly like them to still come in and have fun.  I'm very grateful for that sort of mindset, and I absolutely believe the early access price is reasonable for what I've received in turn.

I lastly want to hark back to the animals I talked about.  I LOVE the animals in this game.  A great example is 'diggos', clearly a variation on 'doggos' and immediately makes you want to love and cuddle them and make them your pet - and you CAN!  Another sign of a good gamemaker, understands the OBVIOUS result of putting adorable puppers in games and doesn't be a jerk and make them non-interactive forever.  But the hostile animals are just as adorable!  The crocos with their adorable big smiles, the bush devils that are 1000% distant relatives of Stitch, so you're damn right I don't want to fight those cuties!, and the cuuuute frilly frills and their running animation!  There are many more adorable animals to be found, but those are certainly my favorites.

Anyway, it's time to jump back in and play some more Dinkum, but James' latest post reminded me that I've very rudely never sat down and taken the time to express what about the game makes it worth the purchase for me.  Thank you, James, and happy anniversary to you and your wonderful and personable game!

I wanted to like this game but the limitations on the multiplayer is a deal breaker for me. Wanted to make and share a island together with my friends but as it is right now there are some unnecessary host privileges that I really see no reason to exist. This is especially bad since the game is marketed as a multiplayer focused game but clearly didn't think these things through.

* Only the host can place buildings.
* Only the host relationships matter when inviting villagers to live on the island.
* All players have to enter the mines if you want to go there.

These limitations could easily be fixed with permissions and the mine shouldn't be a problem to fix either.

Another thing is that the characters designs are really boring and bland.
The "voices" sounds very robotic in general and more so when emoting.
The game has multiple band cell shading for some reason that makes the graphics and especially the characters and light look really crusty.

I also selected fishing as my first license so I could catch fish and have early reliable source of energy since it runs out so fast. But I never found a way to cook it. There aren't even any recipes in the cooking table that has fish in it.

Maybe at some point this game will fix some of these things but atm if you are looking to share a island with friends I would not bother. For single player its probably ok.

This game keeps crashing. I've spent a couple of hours trying to fix the issue on my end, but nothing seems to resolve it. I could tolerate the crashes if the save mechanic weren't so janky. The game's save mechanic requires you to sleep, which ends the game's day. The game was designed for players to engage in a full day of activities before sleeping. However, I haven't been able to put in a full day's work so far, and I'm not willing to sleep midday just to save. I'm running a Ryzen 9 5900X, NVIDIA RTX 3070, and 16GB RAM. I'm pretty sure my setup can handle the game.

It's a shame because it's a really fun game. I've wasted so much time just for it to crash before I was ready to save.

Cool blend of Stardew Valley, Animal Crossing, and a bit of Minecraft. Progresses time like Stardew, offers "building the island of your dreams" like Animal Crossing, and has some open-world exploration like in Minecraft.

For the town itself, you have to build everything from scratch and get NPCs to move in, similar to Animal Crossing. You have a set amount of NPCs that you can do requests for and level up their "hearts" with you. I'm understanding you gradually unlock more perks as you raise your heart level, but I don't really see much of a difference at this time. 

Most things you can't really do immediately, though, since the game works on a licensing system. To get a shovel, you need to get a license. To fish, you need a license. Basically, to do anything meaningful early game, you need to get a lot of licenses. Those licenses are obtained with Permit Points, which is just like the Nook Points in AC. Luckily those points are easy to rack up. It keeps the game at a fair pace so you don't complete everything too fast.

My biggest complaint is that there's obviously not a lot of content implemented just yet. Some items like toad skin have no use whatsoever besides selling for a meager amount of coins. Bottle-wood trees don't respawn or drop seeds. Once you've explored enough and obtained a few licenses, there's not much more that the game offers. 

There's also a handful of bugs or concerns:
- Sometimes the map may load incorrectly and you will clip under it and fall.
- I've had a few dialogue boxes that just say "Need Text Here", or there's just blatant grammatical or spelling errors. 
- Shop owners sometimes never navigate to their shop when they're supposed to. This is already pretty frustrating considering NPCs have specific days off. For example, John is off on Sunday entirely, so whatever you need to sell or buy has to wait until Monday.

A few more suggestions:
- Going back to the NPCs having days off, I like the idea. The reason they have days off is to let the player "hang out" with them. They can help you do small tasks like water crops, chop down trees, or maybe hunt. There's not much else, though. There's no way to tell right now what NPCs have what days off though, which is frustrating if I want to go to the bank or buy more seeds. It's not a great trade-off for a "hang out" feature that isn't great to begin with.
- PLEASE make an easier way to make scarecrows besides pumpkins and melons. I have to gamble on whether my crops will survive (including the pumpkins and melons) themselves for a good chunk of the game because I have to wait for those two to grow. And they take almost 2 weeks in-game. 
- Maybe unlock sprinklers earlier or reduce energy for watering? Realistically, you can only have a handful of crops early game since watering them can easily take up all your energy.
- Stop making NPCs wander so far from town. I hate having to track them down if they decide to wander halfway across the map.
- There's no separate storage system for clothing and furniture like in Animal Crossing. I am stuck with several crates or drawers just to hold a few shirts, couches, beds, etc. 

MULTIPLAYER: 
It's alright. It's not "true" co-op, in the sense that you're really just visiting someone's island and helping them out, like in Animal Crossing. It's not like Stardew, where you feel like you actually have your own livelihood outside of the host. But it's also not as restrictive as Animal Crossing, where you can't even pull out an axe. It's basically having a buddy to help you do things, but they don't really get much out of it. 

Overall, I enjoy Dinkum quite a lot, but there still needs to be more content. More fish, bugs, tasks, etc.

Having to add new NCPs to your town, building and creating your town/island to your hearts desire are all there, but with the added benefit of a combat type system and more farming.

This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I'm almost 80 hours into this game and I can solidly say that I recommend it. It's a really fun cozy game and as a lover of cozy games I highly recommend it.

There is a * on that statement though. Here's why.

A lot of people compare this game to Animal Crossing and while I see the comparison there are some BIG differences. The biggest difference being that this game has combat. Not all animals in this game are aggressive but there are aggressive ones.

You have the Croco's (crocodiles) that will chase and bite at you, Glowing Croco's (in the deep mines), Sharks, Wary Mu's (cassowarys), and then Bush Devils that will shoot fire balls at you. Now as long as you don't set up your base close to nests of Bush Devils most stuff is pretty managable. Run far away enough and most stuff will leave you alone.

It's a little less different in the Deep Mines though. You are going to need to go down there at some point in order to get the ores you need if nothing else. Yeah there are goodies down there and rubies, but frankly the main reason I go down there is for ores because on the surface there is VERY little Iron to be found at a point.

So you are going to HAVE to go down into the deep mines at some point and you will be one of 3 people...

-The person that fights everything
-The person that runs past everything
-The person that panics while fighting and running

As you get chased by Bush Devil's, Glowing Crocos, and Bats.

To be honest the part of the game I hate the absolute most is going to those stupid mines. I don't like it. I don't mind the combat on the surface because most stuff in avoidable and I can just choose if I want to fight something for the resources they give. In the mines though it feels eerie cause it's so dark and the Glowing Crocos are easy enough to avoid but a Bush Devil pops up out of no where, scares the hell out of me, and slams my panic button with a fire ball like it owed it money.

So I generaly avoid the mines as much as possible and just get the trickle of ores I get here and there from mining ores, breaking giant boulders in the oceans, and grinding glittering rocks. I only go to the deep mines if i REALLY have to.

Outside of combat though there are comparsions to Animal Crossing. The usual stuff. Catch bugs, fish, farm, decorate, etc. Just in Australia with weirdly named Australian wildlife. You also get "villagers" but not really. The people who gather to your settlement are people and each of them mans a store of some kind. With Fletch being this games Tom Nook. Sitting there behind her desk... judging you for not dropping thousands of dollars on someone elses business and home immediately.

Also the multiplayer in this game is LEAPS above Animal Crossing. I haven't done muliplayer because no one else i know has this game, but I've watched videos on it and it's amazing. Your friends can actually do stuff like decorate, terraform, mine, fish, basically anything in the game with you. It's great.

I do have my little complaints about the game and have an on going list of suggestions in the discussion forum on their steam. For the most part though there is nothing major I have an issue with. The game runs great and at it's current state there is plenty of game for the price you pay. I'm going to stay away from my complaints for the time being just because the game IS in early access and will get those kinks ironed out in no time I'm sure

In the mean time I can't suggest the game more if you like cozy decorating games.... eeeeeeeeven if it means you might get your ass set on fire and have to stab the occasional Croco. And.... for some reason milk a Wombat which will never stop feeling weird to me.

I am an Animal Crossing fan who has done it all.  I needed a new game and Dinkum caught my eye.  You can keep animals, farm, fish, mine, cook, interact with wonderful NPCs...you name it!  You can also hunt a variety of Australian-themed animals.  Being a animal-loving vegetarian, this really bothered me at first.  But then I decided that if it's an animal trying to kill me, I will defend myself!  Take that Crocos and Bush Devils!!  Not all wild animals here are dangerous, many are benign, and you can even tame a diggo (dingo) and mu (emu.)  The game has incredible depth and is very addictive.  It will be a long, long time before I feel like I've done it all.  With a developer who is very engaged with his following and always taking suggestions for new additions, I don't see this game ever going stale.  James Bendon is the sole developer for Dinkum and I continuously shake my head in wonder at how he's done it.  The game is still in early release and it's so rich with content now, I can't even imagine how wonderful it will be when it's fully released.  Kudos, James Bendon, KUDOS!
