Dinkum is a really good game! Especially for an Early Access title. You can tell that there is a lot of love in the development.

+ The sound effects are all nice. Nothing sounds cheap!
+The graphics look really appealing. The game is simply beautiful and charming.
+ Rag-Doll Effects on death. It never gets old.
+ A ton of crafting providing many options to design your village in your own Style.
+ Sandbox game in its core. Means basically you can do whatever you want and you are your own Boss but your Main Goal remains to build a Community. Every new villager brings a new store. This is basically your progression.
+ Travel by land, water or air. You get the vehicles, you decide how to traverse.
+ Combat is simple but entertaining enough
+ No DLC nonsense - you get what you paid for

The only negative thing that i can say about this game is that you cant build your own buildings. All the houses come preset. I've built my Farm/Crafting areas, a pier. a garage and now im building roads so i can travel easier. Its a sandbox game, as long as you have enough imagination to build the world around you you will never get bored.

edit: okay had some good playtime in this so full review time

Pros; it's charming. the sound design is excellent, very soothing. Mechanics are mostly smooth. intuitive and simple to get to grips with. there's loads to do in the game with the variety of all the different types of collections keeping it from feeling too grindy. You can turn off the very annoying vocals/

Cons; saving is only when you end the day by going to sleep; not when the player wants it, which when the beta crashes can be annoying if you've done lots of things in the daytime and lose everything from the crash. 

What could make it amazing:
Either an auto-save or mini-progress save i.e. it just saves the last thing you did, not the rewards bit (that can be as it is). 
Change the Drop to say Drop / Plant  - that would be super useful. Some actions have dual purposes which isn't necessarily clear from the outset. Some of these are fun to find, others are a PITA.
A bit more info about what each licence gives you i.e. unlocks x y & z so then if you're trying to do something specific you don't waste credits on something you think might give you what you need only to be disappointed 

Overall this is a great game, I deeply enjoy the mechanics but the soundscape is what really really sells it. Being able to plug in at the end of a stressful day and listen to the asmr qualities of the sounds whilst playing a charming little game is 100% worth it.

to me, this feels like one of the most underrated PC games in the farming sim genre in a long time. after a few weeks of putting in 30ish hours with my girlfriend, I can't believe I hadn't heard of Dinkum before stumbling upon it on the Steam store. in a lot of ways, the game is a farming sim, with the nature of the game clock and stamina bar that many farm sim fans will be used to, but where Dinkum succeeds and really stands out is it's ability to be the first game I've ever played that manages to be evocative of what makes Animal Crossing so great, besides Animal Crossing of course. the nature of building your town, talking with NPCs, and catching bugs & fish is so clearly evocative of Animal Crossing, but the farming sim gameplay, as well as combat and mining elements help Dinkum stand out as more than just an Animal Crossing clone. The multiplayer/co-op experience is also more robust than Animal Crossing as you not only can you visit each others' islands as you would in New Horizons, but you can also fully participate as a member of each others' islands as well. all-in-all, if you're an Animal Crossing fan and you're looking for any other game that even scratches that itch, Dinkum is the only one that I've ever found to do so.

it is worth mentioning that the game is an early access game made by only one guy. it's scope is still limited in some ways and there is more content to be added to make the game feel like a fuller experience. interestingly, all the NPCs in the game are people who have also function as town hall workers or store owners, so it's like if Tom Nook, Isabelle, Sable, Mable, etc. were also the only villagers in your Animal Crossing town, albeit with the ability to make small talk and ask for favors and such. I think having NPCs that could just be regular old townsfolk would be a nice addition, and fleshing out your island with neighborhoods of citizens would add some more depth to the game. in general, I hope the future content just gives the player more things to add to their town, both functioning and decorative, as after about 30 hours we're taking a bit of a break as well as waiting for some more content. but with all that said, at $20 Dinkum is more than worth the price.

[olist]
[*]No dedicated key for Pause button.
[*]Cannot skip dialogue all together. You can fast forward it so that is a lot of clicks.
[*]Tedious repetitive dialogues to do the same activity again and again. Un-necessary follow up conversation - like I just want to buy my license and be done or sell my item for the 3 millionth time, why do I have to listen to the same follow up conversation that I cannot just one-key-press escape. 
[*]Small small small map.
Map is not built for transportation. Want to carry that Amber Chunk in your pocket? You can't - you can a whole engine that you found but you can't this particular item.

[*]Planting seeds - I don't know if I am doing this wrong, but planting a tree goes as such 1.Dig a hole. 2. drop a seed 3.Plug that hole with soil. Now if you want to do this say 400 times for a big tree farm imagine doing that over an over.  You can try putting down multiple seeds but they can get clubbed together and when you pick up one you pick up both. And if you drop two seeds - it won't just plant one and leave one be instead it won't plant at all.
[*]Game is not scaled to do massive projects. Want to expand the land? Or flatten it? Sure - you can do it one block at time. Which is fine - but your tool that degrades and eventually breaks if you over use it to the end. So better make 20 of these or just be ready to spend several days flattening a huge area. Or make 10 of those charging stations to keep cycling through them. 
[*]Again - Giant animals but not enough land to house them. Want to do a 100 wombat farm? You going to need a ton of land, but not for the animals silly. Its for the housing that shelters the animals.
[*] The whole petting the animal nonsense. Not a fan even once you are in possession of the musical instrument.
[*]Some tools break some you can recharge. Helmet - recharges does not break but any other powertool breaks? Why?
[*]Sleep to save system. Did you enjoy flattening that 2 mile long area that took you long time to flatten? Great you were so excited that forgot that tool was about to at its last usage and broke? No worries just don't save and start over. Yes you will have to do that whole flattening again.
[*]Flowers? Can we make colors out of this yet or not?
[*]Bats - fun to kill. Till you keep getting hordes of them while mining. Even with two bat-zappers you will run out of them. The game's philosophy is progression = 10x of the same item.
Anyway, spent ton of hours on this - but game still feels as tedious as it is on Day1 (IN-GAME) you would think after few years worth of days in game and pretty much unlocking everything it would be easier to do massive projects? But no. What is the end goal of this game if not that? It is not minecraft with procedural endless regeneration.

[/olist]
absolutely lovely game! good, relaxing, open world game. loads to do or can just chill and work on your town <3

The PC version of animal crossing, minus the long real-life wait times. 
You can keep customising your own village to your hearts desire and the one dev that is making this game keeps adding content to this game [b] and interacts with the community [/b]. There is a grind-aspect to it but it feels very natural, as you progress the grind dies down as you can automate a lot of the stuff. The graphics aren't anything mind-blowing but they are nice. Some bird sounds may sound low quality and the music may get repetitive after a while, but nothing a nice spotify list can't fix.
This game is well worth it's price and James deserves your money for making solo a way better game than some huge corporations can come up with.

Dinkum is an amazing title that is rough around the edges.

There's not a lot of depth when it comes to npcs and story. The main interaction you will have with npcs is by completing request for them. "bring me fish/food/furniture/clothing or can i buy this from you/do you want to buy this from me?"
Requests are worth it to get new items/blueprints, but you don't learn anything about the npcs by doing them. It also has a frustrating relationship decay mechanics.

Then there's building. That's where the game shines. You can place npcs houses wherever you want, you can build wherever and whatever you want. The main drawback is the fact that you can't create roofs (due to coding, one √≠tem per title) community found a workaround by using bridges as roofs, but It's not a perfect solution.

Creative ppl will have a blast, and can spend tonsss of time on this game. I spent 100hrs and I only created like 5% of things I wanted to make.
Building aside, the game feels pretty lifeless. So if you try to focus on anything but building you might get bored and rather disappointed with this title.

[b] Obligatory TL;DR because I ramble too much [/b] - if you like the genre, and don't mind how the multiplayer works, 100% buy this game and I personally think if you can, pay full price and support a legit solo dev! I would say it's 8.5/10 with the only things stopping it from being higher for me can mostly be boiled down to "Early Access jank". Detailed ramblings that resemble a review below.

I am a veteran Harvest Moon, AC, Rune Factory etc player based in Australia. These games are my Vegemite (or I suppose, Mighty, in Dinkum's case) on toast. This game to me is worth full price right now with the amount of content it has, and with more major updates on the way. Obviously, it has its bugs and flaws as most Early Access games tend to, but most of the time, it's nothing making sure your saves are backed up won't fix.

The main thing that helps Dinkum stand out and shine is the setting for sure. Many people, Aussie and not, I've streamed the game for have said "wow, this is exactly how I imagine a HarvestCrossing Australian Flavoured game to be". While Dinkum isn't necessarily a "lore heavy" game like some others in the genre, I really like the little tidbits we hear about the world "before things went South" and about "South City" as we have people move to our island and befriend them. Essentially, the premise of Dinkum is the world has gone South (aka to Jackaroo Poo), and Fletch, an elderly woman, puts out an ad one day about a once-in-a-lifetime chance to get out of South City that you the player are the only one who takes interest in. She tells you about the island, which is where her father lived many years ago, and provides you his old journal (which functions as your "achievement" system and progression tracking namely) and you get on an airship and go from there!

The overall "mechanics" of the game are incredibly familiar with, but there are things like the licenses, and Franklyn's shop, that are distinct enough that it's hard for me to 1:1 compare Dinkum to another game mechanically, or for me to say that it feels "too similar" to another game. One thing I like and wish was more common in the Harvest Moon series is when you make meals at your cooking table, they all have certain unique buffs! These buffs both make it easier to do that action and also affect your EXP. For example, if a food has a sword and a shield icon in it, that means it buffs your attack and defense. On the note of combat, for anyone expecting the game to be combat heavy, you will likely be disappointed to hear the combat is fairly basic and not necessarily a required part of the game until you start getting into the endgame. But that doesn't bother me personally, if I want a more combat heavy game in the genre, I'll go play RF4 or SDV. My favourite part of the progression would have to be the things you unlock via Franklyn, especially things like the motorbike or helicopter (which is a cool 3 million dinks and many Shiny Disc sacrifices :P). Yes, you read that right, the money is literally called Dinks :D

Regarding co-op/multiplayer, it can be a bit buggy and janky at certain points, but for the most part I like how it is. The only major gripe I have about it is if we want to pause, the only way to do that it seems is by ending the day (which for reference Dinkum days are about 30 mins irl time if you use the full day). Aside from that, I like the travel bag system (a "global" backpack for taking things to others islands) and the fact that it's easy to avoid getting burned if you're trading because of how the save system works (which is, the game only saves when you start a new day). I know some people have complaints it's not "true" co-op, in the sense of it isn't it's own separate save or mode, but rather you take your character and your items in your inventory and travel bag to someone's island, or they come to yours. However, you can still work on things for your own island on someone else's, such as your relationship/hearts progression with NPCs or doing things like bug catching, fishing, mining etc. etc. to work on your "exp" for those skills, so it's not like co-op not being hosted on your island is a detriment to you, especially because time won't progress on your island while you're on someone else's, it only progresses their day. I get the complaints and if this is a deal breaker for you that is understandable, given how games like SDV have much more refined co-op/multiplayer comparatively. At the same time it is only in Early Access, so this may change once the game releases, especially since the Developer has said he would like to work on bringing Dinkum to non-PC platforms once the game is officially "done" and released out of Early Access (this is in the FAQs on the community Discord). 

The only negative for me personally is the fishing is a biiiit janky, which is a relatively common "negative" people cite. I actually preferred the old button mash system as a controller player though I understand the reasoning for the minor rework. The main reasons I wanted to call this out are because 1) fishing is how you get the current anniversary event currency, and 2) fishing one of the ways you can make a lot of Dinks, and is pretty easy to do so especially once you have the jetski and the Fishing Book from Theodore's Museum. I haven't heard many people say they actively *like* the fishing system, so do be prepared for some minor frustrations in that department.

It's one of those games you initially like and are really excited about until that epiphany hits you "WHY AM I PLAYING THIS GAME?"

Once you get to the "end game" you realise there is nothing to do, there is zero incentive to do anything in this game. The creator of this game is trying to milk the early access for as long as possible. The updates are just time buffers that add just more things onto your to do list but are seldom fun or creative in anyway. What is the point in a sandbox that offers no reward and is hollow? This game has so much potential but the road map is boring and un-innovative. Every new thing is just more work and it creates this time wasting simulator. Everything is a rip off from Animal crossing. We get it's the aussie version of Animal crossing ... BUT it could be soo much more! I think the guy who created this game is so scared to take the risks it needs to be a solid game that can be replayed many times over but once you beat it initially, you have no reason to ever pick it up ever again! Stardew valley handles this problem so well, even talking about Stardew makes me want to replay it again but this game ... you just have an overwhelming feeling of dread that prevents you from exploring this hollow husk of what could be a GREAT game but instead all you have is a copy and paste cash grab that makes you feel like a chump for buying into it

I want to see this game progress past the point of adding some element of an end game and overall point and not just cutting things from other games and pasting it in because it's a safe bet.

Update: The developer has made two really bad design decisions. The first one is tying seasonal items to real time. I remember asking about this a long time ago and I was told it was temporary and seasonal events would eventually be tied to the in-game calendar. It has yet to happen and I'm doubtful it's going to. This isn't a live service game so this is just bad design.

The worst decision though was to have heart levels (NPC affinity) reduce over time. I put in a ton of time doing fetch quests for the NPCs to get them to 5 hearts. Now you want me to do it every day or they stop liking me? There's a reason SDV, Sun Haven, SOS/Harvest Moon, or any other game in this genre doesn't do this. It's beyond bad design. It takes what was a chill, cozy game and turns it into a nightmare of chasing down NPCs constantly to do never ending fetch quests for them.

James, with all due respect, crawl out of your circle jerk of a Discord server and stop letting those suck ups who worship you feed you one bad idea after another. You have one of the best chill games on Steam right now and you're making it tedious for no reason. It may not hurt your overwhelmingly positive rating immediately but if you start reading the Steam forums again you'll see the growing frustration with your recent choices. It's only a matter of time until it hurts Dinkum's rating.

Original Review:

I have only played single player so far. This game is full of bugs. I haven't had any game breaking ones yet but there are definitely clipping issues. Combat is clunky and a feature to toggle lock onto a target would probably solve the issue. For some reason, the pause button is in the options sub menu making pausing the game inefficient but it was recently implemented so I'm glad it exists at all (although having pause bound to one of the many unused keys would be far better or even stopping time when the menu opens). As far as I can tell, there is no way to rebind keys. 

Despite the issues, this game is very fun. I'm enjoying leveling my skills, earning points, selling goods, unlocking new crafting recipes, and shaping the landscape. The systems in play are so well thought out and implemented that they outshine the flaws. Dinkum is well worth the asking price.

Very much enjoying my time in Dinkum. Very much a casual game; but the town feels like a place I created, the peoples quirks are interesting and all the mechanics are fairly solid.

100hrs in and still finding new things, and have a list of things to unlock, but that's the beauty of this game, take it at your own pace, fast or slow, it's up to you. But the more you engage, the more fun you seem to have.

A day is roughly 30-45 min, so you'll need multiples of that to play. Unlock initially can be slow (and at times a little perplexing), but there are guides galore when you get a little stuck. But I think the pace of the unlocks are about right.

Combat gets progressively easier as soon as you learn the move sets; and assuming you remember to heal up...  The vehicles are all quite fun and have their moments; 

Generally been rock solid, occasional bugs, but better put together than many early access games.

Would I recommend it? yes, and I am to keep playing for some time.
good game, haven't played much of it though.

Dinkum is a game in which the player builds and creates a lttle community settlement in an untamed Island Archepelago. The locol wildlife is numurous and even some dangerous creatures inhabit the Islands. Digging for ores, collecting  materials and resources for crafting  while building your town slowly ,adding waterfalls, landscaping the environment, hunting fish and animals , as well as farming the land for sustainable crops to use or sell, dinkum is a truly inspiring game to play as a single or as  co-op players. It's trul;y awesome

UPDATE:

*Will never play this game again*

I truly loved this game so much, to the extent that I was a community moderator on the official Discord server for 8 months, starting before the game even launched. At the end of the day I really just have to say that the people that I gave so much of my time and heart to, turned out to be some of the most awful and unkind people that I have had the displeasure of working with. Some of the staff are still good people, but one by one the best and hardest working members of the team have been forced right out of the community. 

It's been a few months now and I have moved on with my life, but I now have maybe half a dozen friends who have had such deeply negative experiences that they will never play the game again, both general community members and former staff. This review is for them, and for me and for any other person who might interact with that community. Just, beware. It's not a safe place and you likely won't even see it coming, I sure didn't.

This would be a maybe recommendation. I enjoyed my time with the game, but some problems are too big for me to ignored, and I hope they are fixed by the full release:
1 - Please!!! make it so when you open a menu it paused the game. I don't want to have to go to the tittle screen every time I need to step away from the game and loose everything I did since the start of the day. And when I need to step away isn't always at night when I sleep. 
2 - Similarly, it's not okay that animals can attack me when I am in a cut scene. An alligator attack me when I was speaking with the grandma when we arrived on the island. I was also attacked when I was looking at the board with the demand or when I had just catch a bug and it played the cute animation. 
3 - I got no info on how to drive the wheelbarel so I was just confused until i try everything on my controler. I think leaving the player figure some things outs is nice, but I don't think this is one of them, since it is specific to this game and no one will instinctively know how to do it. 

Overall, this game will be great, but I think I will wait a bit so those issues are fixed and then played more. I hope the developpers are aware of the first two problems the most and fix it or the game will just be more annoying than fun for me. 

Also, I played on the steam deck and got no problem specific to it I can recall, it was pretty smooth.

I got this game when it was on sale and so far, it seemed to be promising enough. I definitely think the available materials in the world should be optimized so a beginner wouldn't find it so hard to find certain ores, such as tin and copper, that are needed to progress further into the game. It can get a bit frustrating to run around looking for tin because Fletch asked me to go get some and find out it's a bit of a long walk from camp, which certainly wouldn't be a problem if the tin ores were many. If it were then walking that far would be justified but that's not really the case here. (I generated two worlds and encountered the same problem. Sure, I might just be picking bad locations but even then, common ores should be, well, common).

It's also worth mentioning that the excavation mechanic in this game is very clever because you can't just shovel a piece of dirt and then forget about it, you're gonna have to find a place to dump that dirt onto. Seems simple enough but as someone who played Minecraft for years, it was a welcome albeit troublesome change in game play. 

Yet as much as I find the excavation in this game wonderful, I truly do hope that there would be an easier way to terraform your world. Maybe a vehicle that would flatten dirt and eliminate the trouble of having to find a place to dump dirt onto would be really great. All in all, it's a good game! I'm looking forward to sinking more hours into this but knowing what I know now, I personally wouldn't buy this game during Early Access. 

Nevertheless, it's still an 8/10 for me. James Bendon did great on this one :))

[h1] Review of Dinkum! YES! [/h1]


* [b]Immediate reaction:[/b] So much yes. Cute visuals, intuitive controls, and peaceful audio.

* [b]Within 10 hours of gameplay:[/b] My boyfriend and I are both addicted, separately. (We don‚Äôt know how to join each other‚Äôs islands yet, but we don‚Äôt care, we‚Äôre so happy on our individual islands.)

* [b] At ~50 hours of gameplay,[/b] we visited each other's islands briefly. We are having very different game experiences. He's flying a helicopter, riding a jetski, and trapping angry cassowary-emus. I'm farming adorable chickens, platypus-sheep, and wombat-cows; and I'm becoming a fruit-salad mogul with the world's longest tree-lined path to nowhere. We're both having a blast. :)

It's taken me a while to think about how to write this review, but here it goes...
Dinkum is a beautifully wholesome game with a fresh blend of unique & familiar game styles. The simplicity in the game ui & character controls makes it easy to pick up and hard to put down. You can lose many hours of your life in this game and not regret a single second of it.
I'm a particularly a big fan of the animals and interactions with them the game offers. So many other games of this nature go for fantasy or more western animals so to play with Australian animals is refreshing and just as adorable as usual. Pick up a guitar and -bam- you've got the cutest audience for your little performance. 
The game doesn't hold back when it comes to the survival elements, a backpack full of grub is often needed to get from one place to another. Angry critters will run after you too, I find the encounters engaging but never too difficult for me to manage. 
Overall, Dinkum is chock full of endearing qualities all put together in a bright and eye-catching graphic design, James has done a truly wonderful job creating this game. There are things that could be improved but this game is in early access so I'll give it the benefit of "maybe eventually it will all work out"
For a game that is very new it runs very smoothly and with few bugs, I can safely say it's one of the best early access games I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

Here's where we get to the *but*...
Whilst I would recommend the game I'd advise extreme caution when engaging with the online Dinkum community. I met some of the most amazing people and truly felt I'd found somewhere I belonged, but it was short lived. I was one of a group of people accused of being "too helpful" and was very confused and upset. When I did eventually gather myself and make a heartfelt apology I was responded to with a message that started "I'm not reading that" and then banned. I'm still under the belief that there was severe misunderstanding and miscommunication from both myself & the admin team but this thing isn't what upsets me the most. When I say I met amazing people I do truly mean it, and those amazing people were also cut off and bullied out of the server. I've heard some horrible things about what happens behind the scenes and the bias certain people show towards others, I have seen messages from the community manager that I would never expect anyone to send let alone somebody in charge of a massive network of gamers (some of which were/are incredibly vulnerable). With all of this some of our friends reached out to James himself and he made it clear that he supports the actions of this CM and so I feel I cannot support the game anymore.
I loved this game, adored it, I put so much of myself into it and dedicated myself to helping others wherever I could, but now when I even look at it in my games menu I feel sick to the core. Not only was it an extremely traumatic and upsetting time for me but the way that my friends and other community members have been treated upsets me greatly. 
A game as beautiful and accepting as this should have a community that reflects that, instead it's caused harm to a group of people who were only trying to help and engage. 
Download the game, have the most amazing time because I promise you 100% you will. Catch fish, grow wheat, ride a bike into the river (trust me it's far too easy to ride a bike into a river). My god the world has been waiting for a game like this for way too long... but maybe give that invite to the discord a miss.

I absolutely adore this game. It has fast become my favourite game to play all the time. My Hyper Fixation as of the last few months. I love the whole feel of the game, the chill of it, the do things at your own pace. 

I haven't played for a few months and it is doubtful that I will ever play this game again. 
I would recommend the game to anyone in a heartbeat but the community not so much anymore.
Myself and a few people I met through the Discord server were told to stop talking and helping people as it is not our job to tell someone how to do something. 2 of the Helpers that I am quite close friends with have been removed from helpers because the community manager prefers a team full of bullies than people who actually help.

We have tried to talk to the dev about this and he has been sent a few messages but we were told he doesn't see that his CM is doing anything wrong, when she is bulling people out of a server because they don't act in a way she deems appropriate. She banned my friend for Online bullying when the only people in the server who are bullies is the CM herself and at least 1 of her staff members. 

The game is beautiful and so well done, It makes me sad that 1 person ruined it all for me. I have never belonged to a community for a game before and I was so happy to have found Dinkum and its server. Now its all sour.
I will recommend the game to anyone but the discord server I would stay away from because they will ruin your love for this game and it is such a shame after all the hardwork James has put in, the person who runs his community will be the reason so many people stop playing.

Played an average of 4 hours/day since I first started it, and I don't see myself stopping anytime soon. Progress is slow but steady; gameplay is enjoyable, relaxing, and extremely forgiving. 
Your enjoyment is bound by your creative limitations, as well as limitations in building (i.e. bridge placement, lack of certain types of decorations.) Early access with a community-feedback-driven developer (yes, just one dev), so I'm sure we'll get more stuff eventually :)

You know what, after 60 hours in this game, I will say it has been a wild ride. Getting constantly pounded by fire breathing dogs, doesn't sound as bad as you would think. Great and very polished early-access game. Imagine Animal Crossing Down under.

I really wanted to like this game... but 4 things made it not very enjoyable. The first thing is that every time you die every tool in your inventory takes a hit. The lower the item the bigger the hit. Which means you are constantly buying new tools. Second, Copper is too hard to find, and you need it for everything. I don't like that in order to make an iron tool, you need to make a copper one first. I wouldn't mind it so much, if the tools did not break all the time. The third thing is that if you are playing a multiplayer game, there is no way to lock chests. Which means anyone you have come on your land in multiplayer, can take anything and bring it back to their own town. Last the fourth reason is the shovel is a pain in the butt!! If you get a scoop, you have to put down a scoop somewhere. Its very hard to flatten the land, if you want to add a fence. It is a cute game, I had fun playing with my friends, but there are better games out there.

Dinkum is an immersive and charming game set in the Australian outback. The beautiful landscapes, customization options, and engaging gameplay make it a truly enjoyable experience. From building and expanding your town to exploring diverse environments and interacting with NPC's, Dinkum offers a rewarding and memorable adventure. I highly recommend it to anyone seeking a unique and immersive gaming experience. Franklyn might be a bit too rude though.

[h1] Dinkum [/h1] 

Dinkum is an [b]extraordinary game[/b] that effortlessly transports players into a realm of tranquility, offering a welcome escape from the realities of everyday life. From the moment you embark on your journey, you'll be enchanted by its serene landscapes, delightful gameplay mechanics, and the sheer joy it brings.

One of the most exceptional qualities of Dinkum is its ability to create an atmosphere of complete relaxation. Whether you're seeking solace after a long day or simply craving a break from the chaos of the world, this game provides a haven of calmness. Its soothing visuals, enchanting soundscapes, and gentle pace combine harmoniously to create a truly serene experience. It's like stepping into a virtual sanctuary where worries fade away, leaving only a blissful sense of peace.

Dinkum's gameplay is not only relaxing but also incredibly fun. As you delve deeper into its enchanting world, you'll discover a myriad of activities and challenges that keep you engaged and entertained for hours on end. The game seamlessly blends exploration, resource gathering, and creative problem-solving, ensuring that every moment feels fresh and exciting. Whether you're tending to your virtual garden, fishing in tranquil lakes, or engaging in captivating quests, Dinkum's gameplay is an absolute delight.

One of the most intriguing aspects of Dinkum is its emphasis on finding new and better ways to earn money. Rather than simply rewarding mindless grinding, the game encourages you to think strategically and innovatively. It presents a range of options, from establishing a bustling marketplace to nurturing a thriving farm, allowing you to craft your own path to prosperity. This dynamic system fosters a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction as you witness your efforts bear fruit and your virtual wealth grow.

Furthermore, Dinkum's flexibility is a true testament to its brilliance. It can be enjoyed anytime, anywhere, making it the perfect companion for those seeking a temporary reprieve from reality. Whether you have a few spare minutes during a commute or desire a lengthier session in the comfort of your own home, Dinkum is always there to whisk you away to a world of serenity and joy.

In summary, Dinkum is an extraordinary game that offers a mesmerizing and relaxing escape from the demands of everyday life. With its tranquil ambiance, engaging gameplay, and the opportunity to explore new and inventive ways to earn money, it provides an unparalleled experience that leaves players feeling refreshed and invigorated. Dinkum is a true gem, a testament to the power of gaming as a medium for joy, relaxation, and personal growth.

I love this game.  Elements that remind me of all my favourites: Minecraft, Animal Crossing and Stardew.  Unique in it's own way though, relaxing, cute and just perfect for some weekend exploring. An amazing relaxing - but if you want - also action filled holiday, where you can build a farm as well as a city. If you have the patience to do it, you can reshape and reform the whole map, which reminds me very much of Minecarft or Dragon Quest Builders. The freedom to do so, while this place you create is also inhabited by other people to make the world feel less empty, is a great adition.

So what can make it better? A few ideas came into my mind, but I don't intend them as complaint, just as an inspiration:
Maybe tourists a few more residents would come - how about some workers to hire for farming, mining and fishing, musicians, writer/poets, artists as friend of the guy running the museum, a pilot/ferryman for the residents? Or the possibility to run a streetfood-stall, where you can sell your stuff to the residents? It also would be nice, if someone with interior decoration ambitions could change the interior and the exterior of the residents houses. And how about family members of the residents, like old parents or brothers and sisters? Granny can't be the only old person on the island... And how about a starwatch tower, a music hall, a cinema and a hotel?

Very slow-paced game, so not for people who are in a rush, but for anyone looking for soothing/calming games that force them to slow down? This is IT. I love games that make me appreciate my time and efforts, and I've been enjoying slowly but surely carving my town into the landscape. I already have tons of ideas and plans for builds in this save file, AND for future restarts.

Also, a tip for anyone starting the game - I recommend growing an orchard as soon as possible if you want to make your earliest days last longer than bed at 2pm, haha! I have a group of fruit trees (5x5) which grow fruit on different days, so I have a constant food supply to keep my stamina up! (Also, it's not necessary to hunt animals, as far as I'm aware, in case that concerns you!)

Now that's what I call a keeper!

Edit: I've put a few more hours into this game, and am still enjoying it. Though, those who don't like to grind for resources to make things happen may find it a little tedious. However there are many things you can do in this game, and the player gets to decide in the end what they want to accomplish here. 
The fishing mechanic is a little hard to learn at first, but it is fun in a challenging way. The deep mine is pretty deadly, at least for me. I'm not much into the combat, and having everything in there all out to get you nearly at once is too much for me. 

All in all, I do recommend this game. The music is chill and parts of the game are much more relaxed. These are the parts I enjoy the most.

I'm picky with these sorts of games. I grew up playing Harvest Moon 64, and once I eventually got into PC gaming, I found myself searching around every year or so for something similar, and eventually there was Stardew Valley, which is now my personal favorite game of all time.

Since then, I've had a hard time finding another farm/life sim that I can really get lost in. I have tried quite literally all of them, and some came close to really drawing me in for the long haul, like My Time at Portia, and Kynseed, but they all seemed to lack that certain X factor that made the game a permanent staple of my library.

But this game? This game fully slaps. It's another game well above the rest, sitting up near Stardew, but where exactly it ranks will be made clear with more play time. I'll update as I go.

EDIT:

After nearly tripling my play time since my initial review, and playing a few games that have come out in the same vein since then, I think I have a fair grasp on the overall quality of the game. Dinkum might go down as my second favorite game in the genre, stopping just short of Stardew for me in terms of art style, overall fun, and general longevity.

Fans of Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley and Minecraft would absolutely love this game! 

There's so much to do and explore! Comparing it to the other games listed above, all the items have a purpose, there's more to craft, you can explore your island in different ways, there's lots of animals to take care of or hunt, and so much more. There's no way you can rush through this game. 

If you like decorating and is concerned about filling your island up too fast, don't worry! Your island is MASSIVE! There's so much land to explore that you couldn't finish decorating or laying everything out within a short period of time. There's also lots of recipes and items to discover as well as visitors to bring to your island.

One of my favourite things is DInkum's online co-op. You can have up to 4 players per island, AND there's no restriction to what you and your friends can do on each other islands. It's a great help especially when you go down to the mines, need to fight an alpha or even to get materials around the island. 

Overall, for the price of this game it is well worth your money. There's endless stuff to do and lots of tips and tricks to learn along the way!

Original review:
I have three Animal Crossing saves, each with hundreds of hours. The graphics in Dinkum are not as nice, but the game... You can swim and dive in the rivers. You can take a boat far out into the ocean. Hang gliding!

There is just so much to do, and the game is still early access. Highly recommended.

Update May 2023:
Months later, I'm still playing.

I did burn out for a while. There is a lot of grinding. At one point I just lost interest because it was going to take me real world months to move in 5 residents. At that point the game was not fun for me. I finally decided to use some sparing dev commands to get myself to a place where it was enjoyable.

I'm not a fan of combat, so I've only been in the mines once. I will probably add the peaceful mining mod.

I'm not a fan of hunting, either. I scavenge all my meat. I do kill the crocodiles that come after me. I've done a few alpha quests. But just not a fan of this part of the game, so I mostly ignore it. 

I've got 170 hours so far, so there is plenty to do if you are not a fan of combat and hunting. I actually restarted after realizing just how terrible my original map was.
Great game to relax with, do a little crafting, a bit of fishing, or just doing a few tasks.  Its fun to build up the town and watch your homestead grow. I recommend this game.
Fun Animal Crossing type game.
Animal Crossing but with violence. I can also crash helicopters

This game is so much fun to play.  I enjoy just about everything about it.  The crafting, the cooking, the fishing, the friendly interaction with NPCs. I love the bulletin board and the various quests it offers. There are a couple of things I would love to have changed, however... 1) is to be able to skip out of conversations with one click or hotkey. It becomes wearisome to have to go through every step of dialogue with every character interaction... 2) would be to enable "tabbing" with a hotkey when you open your progress book. Having to click on the tabs with the mouse also gets a bit tedious. Other than that, no complaints. (These aren't really complaints as much as thoughts for the developers to mull over in their minds.) I love the deep mine and when I get enough ruby shards I will go even deeper! I have about 365 hours into this is and can really see hundreds of hours more. In the end it's safe to say, I highly recommend Dinkum!

Let me preface this by saying this game is VERY good. It's hard to stop playing sometimes. There's a lot to like about this game, and there are also some areas that could use improvement. Below are some points I hope are implemented.

1: Manual Save Functionality - Probably the only real annoyance I have is that the only way to save the game (aside from using the debug console cheats) is by sleeping to end the day. Often I will do the "morning routine" of watering crops, tending to animals, getting the NPC daily tasks, etc., which will usually take until mid-afternoon. There's still a lot of time left in the day to go into the deep mines, go out and collect materials, etc., but I sometimes will be pulled away or just want to stop, and I have to choose between just ending the day there or redoing it all. I strongly believe there should be a way to save the game without ending the day.

2: Bugs and Fish in Containers - I feel that bugs and fish should be able to be stored in containers. It was annoying to have to go get a specific one when an NPC requested it, when I had previously caught it and had to sell/drop it to make room (this was before learning you can place them on the ground. However, this still gets cluttered when you have a lot of them, and it can get hard to tell which is which). Perhaps special containers can be locked behind licenses or bought from Franklyn or Julia.

3: Crafting and Automation - Some of the first mods I look for in games with crafting systems are mods for inventory management and crafting automation. By the end of the first in-game year, I had a lot of chests, and just one day in the deep mines could net up to 200 ore. I think it could be satisfying to have some options for improved crafting and processing. Perhaps some Franklyn commissions for a special crafting table that pulls from boxes that are in specific squares, special boxes that feed into adjacent production items, etc.

4: Wheelbarrow - I think the wheelbarrow has extremely limited uses currently. It is nice if you want to transport dirt a small distance, but that usually isn't something I've needed, and by the time I did, I had the dirt printer. I think if the wheelbarrow could place its contents in the square in front of it one at a time, it could serve as a nice in-between before you have the dirt printer, and it would have a lot more utility.

5: Silos - Placing animal feed into silos should require a single click to place the entire stack you're holding. There is no reason to place them one at a time, and it is tedious to have to click 200 times to completely fill one. Even just topping one off after a few days of use kind of defeats the purpose of it automatically filling the feeders if you have to click the same number of times anyway.

6: Crab Pots - Currently, crab pots feel pretty disappointing. Being locked behind the 3000 perk point fishing license and requiring a total of 35 ore *per pot* is a lot. Then, each requires some meat to bait every day (which really adds up when you make a lot of them), and each only catches a single item per day, which is usually a common item you could get a bunch of anyway. It either shouldn't be able to catch anything other than some of the more rare critters, should catch multiple things per day, or it should cost much less to craft. For similar materials, you could just make an animal pen and get consistently more valuable items to sell from processing animal products and spend 1 animal feed per day instead of 1 meat.

All this being said, most of these points are addressed by mods (bless this game's modding community), and again the game is still very fun and engaging (I also love the soundtrack!). I hope James sees this and takes these points into consideration.

Dinkum is one of those games that just takes you away from it all. The game's island setting, inspired by the rugged Australian outback, is simply breathtaking. I loved exploring every nook and cranny, foraging, fishing, mining, and farming for resources. The game creates an immersive experience that lets you truly feel like you're living off the land.

But what really sets Dinkum apart is the ability to interact with the island's people. It's like stepping into a little community, where everyone has their own story to tell. It's heartwarming and charming, and I found myself getting lost in the stories and the characters.

The game's relaxing soundtrack is the cherry on top. It's the perfect accompaniment to the island's tranquil atmosphere, and it's the kind of music you can just sit back and listen to for hours.

Overall, I give Dinkum a rating of 9 out of 10. It's a well-crafted game that immerses you in a world of simplicity and tranquility. If you're looking for a game that lets you escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life, then Dinkum is definitely worth checking out. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

*WIP review while I play through the game*

Pros: The game is moddable, which trust me, it needs it! There's several issues with the game that modders fortunately solved. God bless the modding community, I tell ya.

The game has good regional pricing (for the most part)

Cons: The game only has a singular save file AND the game ONLY saves when you go to sleep at the end of the day. Now, considering that you can spend upwards of 30minutes on a single day, this means that if the game were to crash at any time during the day, then you lose ALL that progress made during the day and lose all loot. And since the game crashes every so often, that means you're going to lose hours of gameplay if you invest any meaningful amount of time into playing the game. The dev could easily fix this by implementing a save system that ISN'T straight out of the year 1995.

A single butterfly/spider/etc. takes up a whole inventory slot, but you can have 20 engines on 1 inventory slot. Makes sense?

Because of the above inventory stacking design decision, the inventory is far too small, and it rightfully should be increased by at least 10 spaces.

Weapons/Tools/etc. break when they reach zero durability, meaning you lose them forever.

Your stamina/energy bar comes 1/10th of the size when you go past 00:00 at night, and you LOSE all stamina that you had above that line. A [u]MUCH[/u] better mechanic would be to instead simply not allow the player to recoup their stamina after the 00:00 time.

Bats in the mines don't give any loot, ever. They're the only thing in the game that doesn't give loot AND they're the only thing in the game that can't be hit by weapons in a straight forward fashion. Two things that make no sense in the logic of the game.

There's some special animals in the game, like Radioactive Crocs for instance, but these animals give no special loot besides the regular Croc loot. This is pretty stupid imo as there's zero incentive to hunt these special animals.

The mines are very annoying (as even the self-aware loading screen tip states.) If I wanted to be frustrated, I'd play Dark Souls, not Dinkum.

Also, it takes too long in the beginning to make enough money to get anything done.

Other than that, it's a pretty cool game.
This game is an AMAZING GAME!! the only downside is it is kind of hard to complete i rate it 9.8/10

I wanted to leave a note for one singular reason: this is the first game where the volume wasn't maxed at the start, and didn't end up blowing out my eardrums as a result. The master volume slider starts at around 30%, which is fantastic - can every game be like this please?

Regarding the 'recommendation' for this game - I am refunding it; it's not one I see myself playing in the long term (plus the sounds were really bothering me). That said..

tl;dr : It tries its hardest to be Animal Crossing, but just isn't - though it certainly feels like it's well on that path. Maybe with some quality-of-life updates it can get a lot closer, but - wasn't for me. To be fair, I was never the biggest Animal Crossing player to begin with - so if you were, it may be more palatable.

Good:
(1) Serious Animal Crossing [Switch]/Nintendo vibes - if you enjoyed that game, this one is very likely up your alley - at least with regards to the graphics/ui/overall feel of the game off the bat.

Bad:
(1) The sound effects - the developers sure love their extremely high-pitched/grating sounds, for everything. List: [UI menu clicks for everything/Pickaxe mining sound/even the occasional footstep sound] - they're all just... incredibly irritating, like nails on a chalkboard.
(2) The inventory system - like Animal Crossing, it offers a toolbar+backpack organization of your items. That itself isn't bad, but - unlike Animal Crossing, there is no rotating through your backpack/toolbars - there's only a singular bar you can put things on. I found myself CONSTANTLY having to open up the backpack and move things around, which as a controller player was just time-consuming/obnoxious. Seriously, just do it the way Animal Crossing [Switch] does, and it'd feel SO much better.
(3) Selling items - there's no way to see how much each item sells for, as a single unit, or as a stack; when you hover over your items at a merchant, or try to find them in the informational menus. You select everything you want to sell, and John just gives you a price - that's it. I'm sure I could sell him one item at a time and note how much each thing sells for - but come on, that's unrealistic.

It reminds me a lot of Animal Crossing, but actually challenging. You take damage, fight things AND build up an island. You don't just wander aimlessly after a few hours of game play. I have a hard time really sinking hours into games but I LOVE this one.

I‚Äôve waited weeks to write this review, to ensure I knew the game well. 220 hours of gameplay later, here we go. 

Dinkum is a charming, creative, well executed title. It is essentially Animal Crossing style gameplay, in a little Australian world. A delight to play and addictive to those who don‚Äôt mind a little grind.

Speaking of grind, the grind in early game won‚Äôt last forever, Dinkum manages to balance the work / reward mechanic to near perfection. Work hard, reap the benefits and when everything seems to be in abundance, there‚Äôs still a lot to do. 

Negatives? Honestly, I love it so much it‚Äôs difficult to come up with any. It is in early access, so there‚Äôs a few bugs, but they‚Äôre far from terrible (and the dev is very in touch with community feedback). 

Buy Dinkum, it‚Äôs a wonderful experience that just goes on and on. Made by one guy‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a miracle and he‚Äôs still iterating.

One of the best missing games I played this year without exaggeration. Here's why (after 52 hours of play)
It will be a long speech, in which I will explain some details and say the missing things

The movement of the camera is unique in this game and smooth, and the smoothness of the game even in entering and exiting buildings at high speed without a loading screen is a beautiful thing that I cannot describe accurately

The graphics of the game are beautiful and cartoony, not exaggerated, such as trying to reach realism, because games always fail in that, except rarely

Everyone in the city has special interests and also different working times, and you can chat with them and give you advice or tell their life stories (the dialogues will be special at the beginning of the game and become repeated later), and you can befriend any individual and go out with them, but before that you must carry out several tasks for them in order for the love meter to increase And they become your friends, but their programming is not good. Unfortunately, I sometimes have problems with them, such as delay in reactions.

In short, the game will be excellent, like the first 30, 40, 50, or 60 hours, after which you will notice a lack of activities and repetition of tasks, but it is not a big problem, especially since the game is early access.

Here are the missing things that I wish were present in the game

The map becomes larger and more diverse, and there are different cities in it that you cannot modify. You only deal with them, such as trading or buying from their stores, and their products are different from those of your city, so that you are encouraged to go to them.

More diversity in environments, changing the desert from red to beige, adding a snowy and mountainous area and a green area

When winter came, I wished that the land, trees, and buildings would be covered with snow, and the lighting of the game would change to be more white, and in the fall, the leaves would fall and fill the land, and the sunlight would be orange

Add more wild animals such as bears, lions, hyenas, etc

Adding legendary animals whose sizes are larger and more difficult to hunt, and that there is a shop that buys the skins or heads of these animals from you at high prices to encourage hunting them and their places differ such as land, seas and sky, on land, for example, there will be a bear, and in the sea, for example, it will be Megaldon, and in the sky will be the eagle

Adding a larger and wider aquatic life, and the possibility of buying a diving suit or a submarine to explore it, or to catch more or larger fish

Adding more modifications to the houses, more colors, and adding a garage

Add NPCs Interact in town

Adding more mini games, for example, an arcade game store, or any fun side activity

Adding dinosaur fossils to the museum, and the bones are collected and restored by the player

I apologize for the prolongation. The bottom line is that the game has great potential, and the more developers are interested in their game, the more and more the success of the game will be. Therefore, I hope to add continuous updates, whether new or to fix glitch.

Dinkum is really good at scratching that itch that Animal Crossing New Horizon scratches, while also incorporating farming, exploration, and animal handling. There's a lot to do, lots of customization, and it's very charming. If you like collecting for the museum in AC, you will enjoy that aspect very much. The animations are adorable, and the hunting of animals is fun. 

The biggest issue for this game is the lack of being able to pause. In Animal Crossing it makes sense you wouldn't be able to pause as it runs on real time. However, in a game that runs on a timer much like Story of Seasons or Stardew Valley this is a big hindrance. Time management is huge in this game, and when you can't pause by opening the menu or going into options it really hurts the enjoyment. Especially when you can only save the game when you go to sleep.

Dinkum has positive aspects, but it's also has several significant flaws that detract from the overall experience. it has plenty of content to keep players entertained for hours on end. However, there are several areas in which the game falls short. 

Co-op:
Co-op is advertised as a true co-op experience, but in reality, your friends are limited to acting as sidekicks with minimal interactions in your world. If you started together on one island, your friends will miss out on important blueprints and story and town progress and they don't share your quests rewards, all of this can make the co-op mode feel less rewarding and less immersive than it could be.

Controls:
Controls are unnatural and feels wrong leading to numerous frustrating moments where you accidentally pick up furniture instead of using it, or find yourself doing multiple loops before marking the exact spot they need whether you want to catch a bug or remove some dirt.

Combat:
The combat system is also clunky and lacks depth. you will quickly tire of the repetitive button-mashing and the lack of options leads to the combat quickly becomes boring.

I think the best way to play this game is by playing solo, only then everyone can fully experience the game's content and mechanics without feeling held back by the limitations of the co-op mode. And by joining friends only when needed, players can still enjoy the social aspect of the game without sacrificing their own progress or enjoyment.

Maybe by implementing a shared world or realm system similar to Minecraft, players would be able to fully experience the co-op mode without feeling limited by the game's current setup. Allowing players to travel back to their own island to retrieve gear or finish missions would also give them more agency and control over their own progress, which is important for keeping players engaged and invested in the game.

I know all I listed here were only negatives but believe me this game is good and worth a shot.

Dinkum is obviously inspired by Animal Crossing and includes most of its features (museum, neighbors, seasons, gathering, upgrading buildings, etc.) It also includes basic combat with predator animals and unique twists such as metal detecting, animal trapping, terrain manipulation, and quite a few different vehicles to be sought after.  Interesting tech tree grinds with their respective machines and a fast paced dungeon dive system.  So Animal Crossing + My Time at Portia/Sandrock, essentially. Maybe a lesser relative to Stardew Valley; Dinkum is less complicated, I would say.

 Comes with functional multiplayer which is a hit with my 4 and 6 year old. The game can be challenging but also provides easy tasks for younger players.

Cons: the gatekeeping of basic skills via the certification system (basically nook miles in AC). You start with bug catching and being able to pick up stuff off the ground but you can't buy tools until you get a few in game days worth of certificate tickets. I almost turned the game off at the beginning because of that but I stuck through it and it makes more sense after the initial hump. Please just allow the basic axes for new players, it can be confusing as to what they are supposed to do at the start.

A love letter to homesteading games, done by a single dev. Basically Stardew Valley as if running on Animal Crossing: New Horizons, with Minecraft sprinkled in. The different inspirations work together well, greater than the sum of its parts.

My main gripes with AC:NH (you are beholden to the passage of time) is fixed here by days being shorter than real time. My issues with Stardew Valley time (things being locked to seasons) is much looser here by having many more things unrelated to time of year. And unlike Minecraft's quicksandbox where there's just too much for me to take in all at once, Dinkum instead is more quality over quantity and there are things to dabble in and when I find I like it, jump right in.

Multiplayer works fantastically. I've only played with one other person so far, but there have been no major issues with desyncing. A few scattered oddities (fishing lag, duplicated NPCs), but nothing that can't just be laughed off.

The Spring Update added lovely flowers, another (more dangerous) mine type, a super useful restaurant NPC, and all sorts of lovely new items. I do wish the undergrowth wasn't so hard in single player, but I can either explore in multiplayer or change up my strategies and equipment. All in all, a great addition to the game.

Looking forward to more updates as they come!

Dinkum is a fun, cosy, game (as long as you're not too afraid of Australian wildlife). In it's early access stage, it is still a little buggy, but I've not experienced anything disastrous. A lot of the game-play is similar to the likes of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, and as an Aussie myself, it's kind of exciting to see landscapes that are so much like home.

(Side question: Is South City a dig at Melbourne? I feel like it is ...)

I would like to see more fruit trees (like plums... hello, that song is stuck in my head now) in the game. Also, be prepared for the fact that getting the permit points and dinks to get to some of the cooler game functions will likely take you a while.

I also find it a little odd that this game doesn't flow in real-time, yet to get things like the cherries, your computer needs to be set to real-time December. That is a little odd. However, I do like the white Boomers! Nice touch!

I've still got a lot yet to achieve in this game, but I can already tell it's a game I'll continue playing for some time yet!
kidna gang

There seems to be more "disliked" reasons instead of the "liked" ones, possibly due to it still being Early Access:
 
- First off, the map environment is (shall we say) quite "small" for such a large map. Passing the Ocean boundaries does literally...nothing. When reaching "???" boundaries (open the map to know if you're there), there's literally nothing out there. It feels like an endless, 2-block high water seas with nothing but you, your boat, and the vast horizon. I'm guessing there's going to be something added there later in the future updates?
- Adding to the first "dislike" reason, there are some "height" issues with the ocean. I found out that some of the water areas are either higher or lower than the normal height of the ocean, either by one block higher or one or two blocks lower. This can cause your boat to fall into the water, unable to use it. There is no way to break and obtain the sunken boat, since you CANNOT USE ANY TOOLS IN THE WATER. Once it is sunk...it's permanently sunken. The boat marker in the map is still showing where it was left at. If luck, you can lure a shark to break it for you? Unfortunately, that all depends on the random spawn rate.
- All the level experiences seem fine (Mining, Logging, Fishing, etc,), All, except Farming. From some certain sources that I've found, I noticed that you can't level up the Farming until you obtained the Watering Can and Hoe from a certain NPC. The Crafting Table, unfortunately, does not give you a recipe to craft them. So, sadly enough, you'll have to wait for that NPC to visit your island in order to obtain them and start Farming. It would be nice if the first Farming License would give you the crafting recipes to make them.
- There are some Favors that require you to not be able to make them in time or is "too early". One favor, by Fletch, wants me to cook a Pavlova, which requires impossible things to finish in one day (you can only do one Favor per NPC for just a day before resetting). Sugar and Big Chicken Egg, two of three ingredients to make a Pavlova, are impossible to obtain early in the game. Sugar can only be obtained from the Sugar Cane placed in a Grain Mill (in which you have to craft it, if you don't have it yet), while Big Chicken Egg can only be obtained by waiting for a Chook (Dinkum name for "Chicken") to lay it if they're very happy. Sugar Canes can be bought by Rayne, who (if you're still in the early game) is just visiting the island until you make a permanent deed for her. Chooks can be bought by Irene, who (once again if you're in early game) is just visiting the island until you make a permanent deed for him. Simply put: ALL OF THESE TAKES ALOT OF TIME, BUT NOT ENOUGH FOR ONE DAY TO FINISH. And yes: Fletch gave me her Pavlova favor in my early game, so there was nothing I can do for her (and it was a waste of a day).
- The controls are really lacking, especially the camera. Sadly enough, there's no zoom distance, in case for closer inspection or screenshotting a nice view of the landscape. Even the mouse also has a problem for "staying in the center" when selecting choices.

Here are some "Liked" reasons:
- The fishing can be a bit of a hassle, especially if there's no fish present. However, the mechanics are enjoyable when catching fishes.
- Breaking furnitures and structures (bridges, for example) can be re-usable, rather than breaking them into a few materials. I don't like my work to be re-made for naught, especially when some materials are scarce.
- Obtaining Permit Points from Milestone achievements can be satisfying, considering they're like currencies for "upgrading" yourself to learn something new or more.
- Some food gave you some semi-permanent health and/or stamina boost, which is quite useful for tough enemies in the island. Unfortunately, it resets back to normal the next day.
- This is sort of a "Dislike" reason, but: The durability on the tools are a pain to hold, considering if (for example) you see some Copper Rocks but your pickaxe is about to break. Then again, there's a Milestone achievement for your tools breaking, so I guess it's fine with me. The only tool that has no durability is the Watering Can (replaces durability to how much water it can hold), which is a sigh of relief, since buying another Watering Can from Rayne is too much ($15,000 for a Watering Can, if I'm correct).

Dinkum, like many are saying, is a perfect blend of Animal Crossing meets Stardew Valley just in the outback! At first I thought this looked to be a MySim adaptation but I've been pleasantly surprised over the past 55 hours.  The game itself is a town sim with animal crossing/Stardew valley -esque tasks and dailies. The different aspects such as Fishing, Farming, Bug catching, Mining, Metal detecting are unique especially when it comes to the leveling up aspect of said skills. The different villagers add to the fun as they all have their own specialties that really give the game life - especially when it takes place on an island that you're building up a town in. Now everyone's favorite breakdown

Pros:

- So much to do (Farming | Fishing | Cooking | Building | Hunting | Mining) and so much more!

- Freedom of choosing where Buildings | furniture | Roads| Decorations can go

- *cheating when I say this* But there literally is something for every type of person to do in the game. From the Farmer to the Miners or Fashion divas to the Hunters. Every avenue opens up blueprints to build more items or quests give outfits to those who desire them. 

- Lovely cartoon-style visuals throughout the game that make it 'soft' with a calming note to zone out to while you play

- A clear vision as to what the Developers want this game to be as they've gotten the point across in the first five seconds of the game and the latest update being the holiday one really pushes the point forward that this game is being worked on. 

- Reputation or Relationship bar that needs time and attention as to keep the player engaged into interacting with the animals/townsfolk

--
Cons:

- The sort of Animalese (or peopleese?) that the townsfolk speak can get a bit annoying but this is just a personal nitpick and In the sound options I'm actually sure it can be turned off or lowered.

- Certain movements or placements can have your character bug out in a demonic sense with their head turning around or going through the very in-game earth itself to meet the void. After 1-2 minutes of falling you'll be put back where your character was before the void fall.

- Animals can be buggy when moving around their pens or near their little huts as they can bully the other animals into corners or push them out of the gates you set up. (This only happened to me once and I couldn't get them to re-create the escape method)

- Being Early access I don't like putting this here but after a certain point in the game things tend to slow down and can become a grind-like scenario (Which a game in where you gather resources it isn't necessarily a bad thing)

- This ties into the 2nd and 3rd cons where a glitch happens to me where the save screen pulses red such as the event when you're exhausted /pass out the screen will do this red pulse around the edges. Though the issue here is when I'm tending to my village all day with my health and energy full then go to bed  it is as if I went 10 rounds with a Jackaroo.


Though with all this in mind please remember this is an Early Access game and thus far it is genuinely a must have game. I truly look forward to it, and hope that the devs keep adding to this game as it has become one of my new favorite obsession. Thank you Dinkum Dev for the hard work, your game is beautiful.
Fun, relaxing, still growing game with lots of similarities to Animal Crossing! If you enjoy AC, you'll likely enjoy this one as well.

So I tried to like this game despite some issues I'd foreseen in play-ability from other gamer's YouTube videos. But like a bull, I saw those red flags and charged. This game has the potential to be a pretty cute, fun, and even relaxing game, but as it is, I've never wanted to smash my keyboard more. Without further ado, here are my thoughts on this game:

Graphics 7/10:
The graphics are cute for the most part, but rather mediocre. If you like staring at reddish-orange sand for most of your game time, (and your eyes aren't prone to hurting from prolonged exposure to those colors unlike mine) then this tidbit won't matter much to you. As for me, I keep too many sharp objects near my desk which I'm tempted to use to dislodge my eyes from their ocular cavities to want to play this game longer than I already have.

Music 7/10:
Cute, but mediocre. I almost forget there even is any music playing while I'm running around.

Controls 3/10:
Ever thought you'd have to "line up your shot" just to remove dirt and place it somewhere else? Look no further. I can't count the number of times I'd have to walk in circles just to get the damn cursor placement to fall on the block I was aiming for. You can also do a 180 in mid-air if you fancy that, which does come in handy for combat. The camera angles are actually pretty good, and walking is fine, but heaven help you when you want to build or decorate. This is especially true when you want to plant fruit trees (you have to dig up a square of dirt, throw 1 bit of fruit in the hole, then place the dirt back on top; yeah, fun).

Combat 2/10:
This game reminds me of Stardew Valley, except Stardew Valley allows the player to equip stylish shoes and rings that help you tank hits. But not Dinkum. As far as I can tell this game has you relying on boosts you get from eating meals you cook, which many of the ingredients aren't easy to obtain (at least to make cooking worth-while). I figure you can tank about 2 croc hits, but that third one is iffy. I found Halo attack-jumping quite useful for combat, but that method isn't fool-proof. Considering you do a fair bit of killing things that are trying to kill you, I would've thought the devs would've incorporated some sort of armor.

Crafting 3/10:
Grinding for materials is a staple feature with any crafting game, so you can expect that here. What I didn't expect, is for this game to make the material-gathering so tedious since you burn through your energy bar rapidly from using any of your tools to do anything. And that includes when you miss. If you're trying to catch a bug, make sure you're lined up correctly because both your energy and the tool's health bar will get depleted. I also didn't expect this game to make crafting in Staxel seem like a dream. Need 40 planks of wood? Guess what, you get to spend the very finite amount of time in this game's day/night cycle clicking that damn saw table 40 damn times. The same goes for cooking fruits, veggies, and meats in the BBQ or by way of the campfire. As far as I've gotten into the game, I don't see any sort of automation. You can speed up the process of certain tasks, but you're still going to be clicking each and every time.

Economy 1/10:
This game doesn't exactly have an economy in the sense that if you sell a bunch of one item, the demand lowers, and thus the amount of currency it's worth decreases. However, the townspeople require you to build them permanent shops which cost exorbitant amounts of Dinks (the currency). Each time you request a deed to build these stupid things, the mayor lady tells you how much money it will put the town in debt. The mayor lady also lets you know that everyone will help pay off the debt, which is true, but when a building puts you 250k in debt and the townsfolk donate tiny bits here or there, you're basically in charge of paying the bulk. It's easy enough to collect things to hock, and you can make a decent bit of cash selling all the items you find with the metal detector, but those items are also building materials so doing that often times works against you.

Overall 4/10:
Like I said, I wanted to like this game, but between the aforementioned qualms I have with this game, and my general patience for crafting games, I realized this game frustrates me beyond any desire I have for playing it further. I've been playing it a few hours each day for about a week, and I seem to be getting less and less happy playing this game. The only thing that does make me happy in this game is catching bugs. And also weakening the sharks enough that they swim from you in fear, which I then chase after them because I'm petty and vengeful. Did I mention swimming uses energy? Go figure.

I've been putting off writing a review. Overall, yes i would recommend Dinkum. It's feels like Animal Crossing but set in Australia. 

Building your town, interacting with NPC's to join your town, farming, mining, fishing etc. Its fun to see your little town grow. explore the map, take on sharks and crocs (once you can figure out how and have a good enough weapon to survive), learning and discovering food items and recipes. 

Something to note, while yes you'll be able to move buildings, it comes with a hefty price tag, so make sure you're certain on where you want your npc's setting up shop. 

In the not so great however, various glitches / bugs are inconvenient at best (camera lag, cooking on fire/bbq lag, unable to check mail) or extremely frustrating( game crashing, fish disappearing, friends going invisible when in co-op) My friend and i have worked out that when we notice the glitching/bugs showing up, to back out to the menu and restart the game, however - since i host most often, i have to restart the game entirely to refresh it. 
It seems the longer you spend in game, the more likely the bugs/glitches happen and the worse they get. 

The dev has done an AMAZING job with this game. It's very engaging and figuring out stuff has been fun. Early Access games aren't without their bugs and glitches, so with some patience it's undeniably enjoyable. I'm definitely looking forward to further patches and updates.

in its current state of the 'Bloomin' Springs" update I definitely recommend this game for people who like a grind-y game.Its more akin to animal crossing in its progression but without the real time aspect which I greatly enjoy as I work a full time job Monday to Friday so this allows me to sink in a few hours each day and still make decent progress. I would also love for the NPCs to have more in-depth personalities rather than stereotypical cookie cutters but so far its good.
