[h1]In my opinion this game is not very good.[/h1] 

The from the gameplay trailers, the positive reviews, and the screenshots! I was sold. I paid full price, loaded it up. And was extremely disappointed with the experience I got. After like half an hour I was left unsatisfied with my experience. I haven't gotten past the part where you get Four residents to stay. I've got Two Buildings, the Store and the Museum, as well as the mine. To those curious as to where I am up to. 

When playing farming games, I like to have a storyline of some sort, or loads of quests from NPC's to keep myself occupied. This game barely has any of these things. Yes. The game kinda has its own form of this, by asking the NPC's if they need anything. But I have one gripe with this system. Why is there a day time limit on them? It‚Äôs just unnecessary and stresses me out. Isn't the point of these types of games to be cosy? Do you know how freakin stressful it is trying to find a microscopic fly, by the end of the day?! And no Fletch, I can't find you a Blue Spot Flathead! I mean if there wasn't a day time limit maybe I could?! Moving on.

Another gripe I have with this game is that the gameplay gets really stale, extremely quick. In other words, the grind isn‚Äôt fun! In this game Money is your best friend. But the way you get money is really tedious! Mostly by gathering, fishing or bug catching. You collect the same shells, same Butterflies, maybe the same fish but who knows! After I've bought the blueprints, placed them, gotten the materials, and the building is built. It sure does feel like a chore to pay off your debt! As soon as go to that donation box to see how much in debt the town is in, I think man I want to quit. Especially when I placed the mine and found out I have to buy a Pass EACH, I'll repeat that, [b]EACH[/b] time we want to go down. Why? Please explain why? Next point.

The NPC's. Never in a game have I met such dull, lifeless, and boring NPC's. For real! They just stand there all day every day, just in the same spot. Even when you speak to them it feels boring, they feel like Robots. Each time I interact with them, it feels like I'm opening the settings app on my PC. They feel like they were just created to be store clerks. Can they walk around the town? Do stuff in their free time? Have quests for us to complete that help us progress? Or give us something interesting to do? Nope. There is no personality, interests, hobbies, other than their job. They're just nice. They smile, they laugh, the wonder, they work, and THATS IT! Please can the NPCs be updated? Next point.

The attack system isn‚Äôt very good. Its very easy to be hurt and eventually killed by animals at least in my experience. I spear a Croc, and after three bites from it I‚Äôm dead! And I‚Äôve lost crap! This gave me multiple headaches and migraines, I just gave up on it and decided not to try and attack things anymore lol. Now closing.

In conclusion the game is pretty bad. There was a clear effort, but it all falls flat. The gameplay is extremely repetitive, and boring. Honestly don't care even if this game is still in early access. Telling my friends not to buy this anymore, especially since I‚Äôve heard that the multiplayer is mostly just visiting the Town instead of actually participating. I‚Äôm sure some people will say that it gets better after building most of the town, I actually kept playing thinking the same thing. But should I be forced to suffer though all that to get to some eventual enjoyment? Maybe if it was more of like an hour of boredom I would consider still playing, but I don't understand why this game has all this praise. I wish I could my money and time back. Maybe I'll come back to it sometimes but its really mediocre. The End.

[i]An incredibly fun game. It‚Äôs quite literally Aussie Animal Crossing and it‚Äôll capture you in the exact same way. Made by one bloke and it‚Äôs one hell of an achievement. [/i]


[b]Visuals: 3/5[/b] 
[list]
[*] The colour pallet is very true to the region/aesthetic. Each biome is distinct and pleasant to look at.
[*] Models are clear and detailed. What you see in the screenshots is what you get.
[*] Lighting works [i]really[/i] well, imo.
[*] It won‚Äôt blow you mind. Everything is very functional rather than attempting to impress you.
[/list]

[b]Sound: 3/5[/b]
[list]
[*] A nice ambience. The soundtrack is great to chill for, but you will substitute it for your own.
[*] Sounds are clear and easy to recognise. I never noticed any clutter, even with several things going on around me.
[*] As with the visuals, everything is functional rather than attempting to impress you. 
[/list]

[b]Gameplay: 5/5[/b]
[list]
[*] Bug catching, Decorating (fashion, furniture, town), Fishing, Foraging, Hunting, Mining ‚Äì there‚Äôs plenty to do and each option has plenty of variety built into it.
[*] A giant sandbox. You do what you want as you want to do it. There is progression which will help direct you, but even that gives you complete agency.
[*] Townsfolk have distinct personalities. While they‚Äôre not deep, I still enjoyed interacting with them. In most games like this, building relations with townsfolk becomes a chore. In Dinkum, I still read every line of dialogue and find myself smiling or chuckling.
[*] More content as time goes on. I hope the developer loved making this game because it feels like a lot of care, detail and effort has gone into it.
[*] I encountered a single alt+tab softlock in an earlier version. That‚Äôs the only bug I‚Äôve encountered. A [b]very[/b] stable game.
[/list]

[b]Control: 3/5[/b]
[list]
[*] Handles exactly as you‚Äôd expect from a sim like this.
[*] Precision placement can be a touch clunky, but any mistakes are very easy to undo.
[*] Combat is a touch finicky, but easy to adapt to.
[*] Played using a keyboard + mouse. 
[/list]
 
[b]Summary: 4/5[/b]
[list]
[*] A very stable and enjoyable experience. I‚Äôve put 93 hours into it over two major periods of play. I can see myself putting in more as more content is added.
[*] Incredibly easy to pick up and put down. There‚Äôs no need to ever feel burnout.
[/list]

If you like farming/crafting games, this one is for you.  I have seen it described as a cross between Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, and I would agree.  There is so much to do and you don't run out of tasks so quickly that you become bored.  If you like building a town and decorating, it has all that.  The game is still in development so, while there are lots of in-game items, there still aren't as many as more advanced games.  It's more intuitive than many other similar games.   There are friendly Discord, FB pages, and YouTube videos if you have questions and need tips.

Cons:  It is still in development, so still a little buggy at times and more in-game items and DIYs are needed.  It still needs more tweaks to be more intuitive, IMO.  Overall these issues are very minor and only minimally affect your experience.

You can't help but compare this to Animal Crossing, but I think Dinkum stands up well on it's own. 
[list]
[*]You can quickly unlock the basic features and get to gathering/building. 
[*]You can have multiple saves! 
[*]There are enemies; none that are very hard and it's not gory so I don't think those with kiddos will be upset by this addition. 
[*]There is a lot to collect and do right from the start. 
[*]You can obtain vehicles.
[*]There are mines.
[*]Villagers have daily quests.
[*]The game is not tied to real time so things progress much faster.
[/list]

Multiplayer is decent. I haven't experienced any connection issues. When I'm visiting my nephew's game the town acts like I'm a resident. I haven't encountered anything I can do as a visitor. The one annoyance was that the store still only sold one of each tool per day even with two people playing. It's not the kind of set up where you would want to let strangers visit your game though due to all the freedoms.

[b]Glitches I've encountered so far:[/b]
[list]
[*]Your island can generate in a way that the docking area is blocked by a tower so you can't actually play. You have to restart.
[*]Your mailbox might glitch and no longer let you open letters. You can sometimes see a tool icon such as a pick ax as your pointer in the mailbox screen. Existing and reloading your save fixes this.
[*]There are times when the 'Sell' button becomes unresponsive when selling items to John. Closing out of the conversation and trying to sell again works. 
[/list]

[b]Recommendations:[/b] 
[list]
[*]A way to pause in multiplayer. Real life is always happening. Perhaps in multiplayer if all the players enter their journals or inventory that could be a trigger to pause time.
[*]Lower the cost of mine passes, at least for the first year. 
[*]More villagers. I find I do miss the quantity in Stardew and the ability to pick and chose who inhabits your island from Animal Crossing. I wouldn't mind some kid/teens that moved in with their family. Perhaps a teen could work part time at John's or some other store and thus the place would/could be open in the evening hours or on a formerly 'closed' day. If colds, wounds, infections, or poison was thing in the game then a doctor/pharmacist. Maybe a librarian, you could find books and donate them to the library which could increase villager happiness. You could also increase your skills slightly by choosing to read for a bit. Maybe some trees or plants could get sick and thus a botanist would be needed in order to treat your crops or keep trees from dying off. A mechanic for when your vehicles break down. 
[*]Build a family for your character. My Harvest Moon/Story of Season/Rune Factory days make me wish this game let you pick a spouse and have and/or adopt kids.
[*]Second mine/cave.  I would love a second area to explore; preferably with a different feel/design.
[/list]

As long as this type of game is your jam, I think it's worth the money.

Much like Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley, and other games to which Dinkum is compared, it's a beautiful confluence of fairly simple gameplay mechanics and core loops that rather than getting repetitive, instead gets more relaxing with increased mastery of its systems.

It is a bit slow to get going, and the mechanics are very poorly tutorialized, so the game really does expect you to have a certain degree of familiarity with the genre mechanics of other games previously mentioned. This is a poor "baby's first farming/crafting sim" as it currently stands, and hopefully the dev does a better job of adding in those elements during Early Access.

But that's not much of a knock against it overall. Dinkum sets out to be a fun, quirky, cute time-burner and it succeeds in its task admirably. That plus the $20 price tag is enough to recommend it.

As a solo dev's passion project, I'd say all that's left to say to the dev is good on ya, mate.

Animal crossing mixed with Stardew with a dash of minecraft

Co-Op oriented but not required  

One of the first Early Access games I've played in *years* where it feels meaty enough to justify the purchase with more to come

Framing - crafting - mining - fishing - animal rearing - animal trapping - bug hunting

You can *buy a helicopter*... 

Best part???

Made by *one guy*...

Excellent game. I really thought the aggressive animals would be more of a problem when I first started, but I've learned I can outrun nearly any unwanted encounter with any harmful wildlife.

I'm trying to build with the terrain but I've seen some incredible builds on YouTube where people have filled in rivers to create more land, so the limit is really your own imagination in this game.

I love how I can play differently depending on what I have time for or how I feel. If I need a relaxing experience, I'll go fish on the beach and listen to the waves. If I need to zone out a little bit and think about something else, I'll move dirt with my shovel and wheelbarrow while my mind drifts elsewhere. If I'm feeling like taking a risk and gaining a great reward, I'll buy a mine pass and try to find locked treasure rooms and evade crocs in the deep mine.

I love building relationships with the villagers and it's always nice to receive gifts from them, too. Just the other day I got a letter from Irwin with no gift, only a lovely note that said something like "I just wanted to say it's great what you've done for our town."

It'd be cool to see a similar feature as Animal Crossing, where we could send villagers mail. I was 11 when I played the first Animal Crossing game and it was really exciting to send mail and receive replies.

Farming was, at first, seemingly unnecessary until I realized I could expand my stamina and health bars with certain foods. I'm looking forward to any expansion of the farming system. I don't have a tractor yet (I don't have ANY expensive tools, really), so I only farm a small plot for now. I've heard it becomes especially lucrative when you're planting and harvesting huge lots with a tractor.

The only negative feedback I'll give is that fishing became harder with the spring update. I didn't have a 100% success rate or anything before, but it wasn't too hard to wrangle any fish, big or small. Now the updated system requires I look at the sidebar for the green GO!, instead of at the fish I'm trying to catch. I greatly preferred the original fishing system and I've definitely caught a lot less fish since the system was updated. Fishing previously brought me calm, but now it's a bit too busy to be relaxing.

I could go on for days about the different aspects of this game that I love. I got it on sale for $15 but it's worth every penny of $20 if you won't wait for a sale.

australian animal crossing

10/10

If you like Harvest Moon/Story of Seasons (for farming and tycoon feels) and Animal Crossing (for its aesthetic and a leisurely pace, though this game is NOT locked to real time), I think you will like Dinkum. It contains far less life sim than Animal Crossing - and no romance, unlike SoS/HM - but mirrors New Horizons' terraforming and definitely borrows heavily from the AC aesthetic and vibes. It feels satisfying to make a beautiful town. Because it is Early Access, it is still unfinished, but the updates are meaty and it's exciting to see how your established town can be changed and expanded in order to accommodate new items and buildings with updates.

I have not played Minecraft but the control you have over the terrain is pretty robust and seems similar. It's measured in blocks and the land appears blocky (though the animals and characters and buildings do not), and you can do things like turn what is currently sand into mud or dirt or vice versa, expand shorelines far into the ocean to create more landmass, and other similar massive renovations for your desired town look.

It also has an RPG-style tool upgrade system where you gain levels in skills to unlock crafting recipes or the ability to purchase higher level permits for those skills. So you mine a bunch in order to unlock better mining picks to mine more stuff - standard for farm sims, imo, and done well.

Lone downside: heavy on crafting. If you don't like games with a TON of makers, you will dislike that aspect of Dinkum. It's one of my least favorite parts of farm sims that seems to have crept into the genre, but it's not enough to ruin this game for me, unlike other similar maker-centric games (such as Pioneers of Olive Town which was destroyed, for me, by its over-reliance on Makers while having a farm you couldn't customize very well around their use).
If you like harvest moon, and stardew, you'll be right at home here.

My husband and I encountered a plethora of bugs while playing the game dated 02/04/2023, which prompted me to provide feedback today. The game had objects disappearing and dropping by themselves, and my avatar got stuck in a dialog, preventing me from moving or leaving. I was forced to lose an entire day's progress in the game by using the Alt + F4 command to exit the game due to these annoying bugs. Despite these issues, the game is enjoyable, especially considering it is in early access. The game has a pleasant soundtrack, and building the village is entertaining, while the quest system is captivating, providing ample entertainment. I recommend the game currently, with the expectation that new updates will address these bugs and bring improvements. However, if the game is released without resolving these issues, I will update my review to "not recommended".

During gameplay, my husband and I identified certain areas for improvement in the final game. For example, in Coop mode, the island should be divided between the host and players, with players becoming residents instead of mere visitors. 

Currently, multiplayer mode only allows all players on the island to enter the mine together and not alone by themselves. 

There is also a lack of a diverse range of animals and biomes, which makes the game less engaging. It took me a long time to buy the game since the few existing biomes are not vast and are quite similar, with unappealing color palettes. More biomes such as a snow biome, along with more types of flowers and plants, would be beneficial. Furthermore, the game needs more hair options for character creation, and the design of the face could also be improved.

Crafting items in the game is tedious and slow since it can only be done one unit at a time or in small packs, which consumes a whole day's progress. The same goes for refining wood and melting ores, which is also time-consuming. 

Changing buildings is inconvenient since I need to remove it from one place and put it in another before moving it to its final location, leading to additional charges for moving buildings more than once a day. Moreover, it is not feasible to change more than one building per day. 

I would also like to see a wardrobe added to the game with a changing room so that players don't have to store clothes in chests, and it's easier to see your avatar wearing them.

In addition, sign plates to put in chests would make it easier to organize and identify what is inside each chest. 

It would also be helpful to add a lawnmower to the game to remove the entire grass, and not just the weeds, as it would be easier to change the grass in some places. 

A new gate that NPC's cannot open would also be beneficial since they tend to open the gate of my animal's farm. 

Lastly, we encountered a bug where John is standing in front of the store on Monday at 9 am and does not want to go in, even though the store is supposed to open at 8 am every day except Sunday.

UPDATE: They added icons on clothes and furniture, which is a welcomed improvement.

Crikey, mates! Dinkum is an absolute corker of a survival sandbox game that brings the wonder and charm of the Australian outback to life, while giving a nod to the cozy vibes of Animal Crossing and the wholesome farming mechanics of Stardew Valley. Set in a procedurally generated land down under, Dinkum lets you explore, build, and craft. The game is chock-a-block with opportunities to create your own unique adventure, whether you're mining for precious resources, farming, or becoming a legendary wombat whisperer.

The game's vibrant art style and colorful environments will immediately catch your eye, while the cheeky humor and Aussie lingo create an authentic and immersive atmosphere. Dinkum's creatures, both real and mythical, will keep you on your toes as you traverse the bush, and the challenge of building up your settlement from scratch is as satisfying as a cold stubby on a hot day.

Now, don't get me wrong, Dinkum is a good a game, but after about 10 hours, the depth of gameplay and gameplay loop can start to wear a bit thin. While there's still plenty to see and do, the initial excitement might give way to a bit of a slog. But fear not, cobber, because the multiplayer aspect is where the game really shines. Nothing beats rounding up your mates and embarking on a grand adventure to tame the Outback together. The cooperative elements encourage teamwork and bring out the best of the game's mechanics.

In conclusion, Dinkum blends the charm of Animal Crossing and the farming fun of Stardew Valley while adding its own Aussie flair. Grab your mates, fire up the barbie, and savor a Vegemite sandwich as you embark on a ripper of an adventure!
a little slow but progressive, i like it.

This game was a disappointment for me. It starts out grindy and repetitive. There is not enough tin ore. You get llittle use out of your tools before they break. Money is hard to come by, you are supposed to run around the island all day, pick up and sell things, which is a huge time-sink for no reason.

I tried out fishing, but it is atrocious. The fish rarely(!) bite and when they do you have a fraction of a second to start reeling them in. The way it's made, the system wants you to spend the whole day for little reward and a lot of frustration!

I also didn't like the fact that random NPCs come and go. I managed to get John the trader to stay. I also got a guy that made me build a museum. However, the farming person never showed up and the furniture guy left after one day unexpectedly.

I'm approximately 8 hours in. I should be trawling the island for tin, but I can't get myself to log in anymore. One would hope for some progress for this amount of time spent and for more exciting gameplay features to open up, but nothing on the horizon. Everything costs a lot of resources, so all I see in more of the same grind.

Very serious thumbs-down! If I lived for 500 years, I would probably not have a problem investing this kind of time. But in this day and age, who has hundreds of hours to devote to Dinkum?

This game is so incredibly charming, I love how laid back the vibe is, and how easy it is to renovate and craft items to make your town beautiful! The characters are interesting, and the island has a lot to do. You can really push yourself, or take it really easy without feeling like you're missing out. I definitely recommend this one!

Overall, I loved this game, its like a better and faster paced animal crossing.

I'll start with what I really liked. The entire feel of the game feels like animal crossing, but better. There are fewer characters, but they all seem to have their own personalities so far and you can develop friendships with them. The fishing in this game is one of the better fishing "mini games" in any game I've played, its not hard, but it doesn't feel too easy either, once you get a feel for it. I don't like the added guide after the latest update.
The exploration feels nice, (though I do wish the different "areas" had a minimum size, some of my plains are only 10x10 blocks big so when looking for certain bugs, this can be a bit annoying, but not a big deal at all, just strange). 
It is very aesthetically pleasing. 
The music and general sound effects are amazing, especially after the update. There are even different sound effects for minor things, amazing attention to detail.
There aren't very many hair options, but there are enough. I loved to see that there is a variety of curly/kinky hair textures and though I'm not black, this was something nice to see included so that people can have characters that look like themselves. 
Dinkum feels like all the best parts of so many games I love.

I wish that pressing the escape button would pause the game in single player. I understand that maybe they want time to move forwards while you're looking in your bags so that you need to keep your weapon handy, or even other menus, but I could see someone thinking they're pausing the game when they aren't in reality. 
Some of the menus are awkward to navigate, especially speech menus. Sometimes pressing escape when talking with someone selects yes, sometimes it selects no. It should always select no or at least be consistent, it seems to be based on where your cursor is on the screen.
In multiplayer, there are many bugs, but that's to be expected. The secondary player can pay to adopt animals, but the animal never shows up. Most things that are different for the secondary character makes sense, but I do wish that they could at least upgrade their own house as only the main house can be upgraded in size.

I doubt anyone will actually read this review, but I hope it helps those who will. The creator of Dinkum has done something truly amazing when he developed this game and I admire him for that. However, the newest update has left a sour taste in my mouth. To be fair this has been coming on for a while and it all started with the fact that you can only save via sleeping. Therefor if your halfway into a day and something else happens in your life that you need to addend to, you have to sleep in game to save your for the progress, otherwise it will be lost. Here's the thing...after the new update, my game has been crashing quite a bit, I dealt with it via Gamer rage and moved on. But today I just threw my toys out of the cot when I saw that 4 hours of playtime (that's a lot for me in one sitting) has just been wiped due to a crash. The game loaded into the day that I should be in, but none of the tasks that I completed in the past four hours has saved, NOTHING. I can't explain to you the devastation when I walked into my town and saw nothing that I did was there anymore. Nor are the stuff I collected and/or built. 
Some other common complaints after the update include:
Fishing rods breaking - I no longer fish in game, it's just not enjoyable anymore.
Game crashing - I clearly am experiencing it.
NPC are "Buggy" - I have not experienced this yet.
Can't weight certain items at John - I have experienced this as well with rubies.
And then one more that I can't mention without a spoiler alert so I'll leave that one.

You also now need to have a license for absolutely everything. You actually need to have a license to write a sign. The other licenses I understand, like vehicles and such but to make a sign??Or to make cheese?? I don't agree with that, but I can see the appeal of why it was brought in, I just don't like it, so take that comment as you please. But to me personally, it feels as though the game is forcing you to focus on one area (Gathering points to buy a license, and then you kind of forget about the beautiful game that your playing. But again, this is a personal feeling so if you don't agree, don't mind me. 

In a whole, it's a beautiful game and I really do love it. There's a lot that you can do and experience and you can see that the Dev really does love and care for this game. But I can't deny that the things I listed above are pushing me to find a new game to play.

Nevertheless, I would still recommend it because new players will see these thing as a sort of normal since they don't know what the game use to be so it won't bother them as much as it would someone who's been playing for a while. So, enjoy the game for me and I hope that the Dev will consider his long time players as much as he does the new one's when making updates and please, PLEASE add a "Save" option without sleep. 

Thanks for reading!

In the land Down Under, where danger looms,
A game called Dinkum, with its deadly critter booms.
My wife and I venture, controller in hand,
Prepared to face creatures, both big and grand.

Kangaroos with boxing gloves, ready to strike,
Emus sprinting fast, like a racecar bike.
We must dodge and weave, to stay alive,
As we take on each challenge, and constantly strive.

The game of Dinkum, is not for the faint,
But with teamwork and strategy, we make no complaint.
We laugh and we cheer, as we make it through,
And continue on, to face the next deadly crew.

So join us in the game, if you dare,
But beware of the critters, and their deadly scare.
For in Dinkum's world, danger is near,
And only the bravest, can persevere

A really nice game to lose yourself in. I play when my brain is done and I am looking for a more laid back gaming experience than my usual fair of MilSim or Zombie Survival. Graphics are really nice with an art style that is perfect for the game. Game mechanics are pretty solid with little issues of low frame rates or crashes, I am running a 3070 with the game maxed out and it runs 60 FPS solid. 

The map size is a little small for my flavor, I am used to playing on maps that are several hundred sq kilometres. So the map feels small to me and with all the transportation you end up with it gets smaller, fast.

"Dinkum" is a charming and addictive farming simulation game that offers a relaxing and enjoyable gaming experience. The game allows players to cultivate their own farm, plant and harvest crops, and take care of livestock. With its beautiful and colorful graphics, players will feel immersed in a picturesque world of farming. The game also features a variety of characters to interact with and tasks to complete, keeping players engaged and entertained. Overall, "Dinkum" is a must-play game for anyone who loves farming simulations and wants to escape into a peaceful and beautiful virtual world.

Dinkum is a survivalist-y world sim game with an Australiana bent that is super cute and clever! Really loving it so far! I found it by accident on Steam and boy am I glad I bought the game!

It's a super fun game, and the first game I really took time to review because I'm enjoying it so much and it deserves the love. There was a major update days ago and it's even better now, with more things to do. It's very layered and detailed and even at 60+ hours there's lots I haven't unlocked. It's very Animal-Crossing style, maybe with a hint of Minecraft (with the world/building landscaping and mobs) and Stardew (mines, seasonal harvesting) but it is a unique thing that isn't any of these things. I really enjoy the battle/combat system (there are animals you can hunt, hope this element gets expanded) and the mining system, which just got an update/another level. Considering it's Early Access, the game is super polished and looks amazing and runs great, it's very well thought out-- I was very impressed with all the animations and the way that things feel-- for example, rowing the boat, driving the motorcycle, diving and fishing are very satisfying and have really good game-feel. World progression is fun, and I'm extremely excited to see the future of this game and what other visitors the dev is planning. We already got one more in the latest update, which is great! The updates so far have been fantastic. I hesitated at first because I wasn't sure what it would be like but it was worth every penny and then some, I highly recommend it. 

It has a bit of a learning curve at the start, which is the only drawback-- things are hard, but once you get the hang of the world and your skills progress then it becomes second nature and things become easier. Also, some of the things are a bit confusing-- for example, took me a while to figure out how the fishing first worked or how to move dirt with the wheelbarrow. And a couple of things aren't intuitive -- for example, if you shear a tin bar you get tin sheets which I discovered way late into the game. And If you find things when metal detecting that you can pick up over your head (like fossils or amber) you can weigh them in the store on the scale and sell them that way. I might have missed the game telling me about those, but at first I wasn't sure what those items were. But there are very informative wikis that dedicated people have put out that help a lot. 

If I had one gripe, it's that multiplayer needs a bit of a tweak-- it works pretty well but can be a bit laggy  -- especially when I connect to my international friends. It's probably my bad AU internet though, more than anything. Probably connecting in the same house/country is better.  Also it's kinda like AC in that one person hosts the game and the other 'visits' so while they can do almost everything, they can't progress certain parts of the settlement and are barred from certain things (like placing buildings etc), so you never really 'share' the world 100%. Personally, it works fine for us, but some people might not like that, preferring a server style world like MC. Despite this, multiplayer works well-- I have a world I only play with my SO and a world for my own personal play and I'm loving it-- as the worlds are randomised, it's always feels different to play each world. 

One suggestion I would love to see in future, is biome percentages on world creation, and the option of specifying which biome to start in. Default would work as it does now, a completely area in a random world-- but it would be great if you could increase biome percentages depending on if you wanted a swamp-heavy world or desert-y world etc. I really wanted a beachy or islandy world to contrast with my other game, and I had to restart my world a few times to get the stretch of coastline I wanted. If I could have upped the percentage of beach by 10-20% on the random world generation, that would have been awesome. You DO need the other biomes for crafting nodes and resources, so I don't wanna get rid  of them, but as long as you have a minimum percentage of those biomes in the game, it should work fine. I would love to see that in future.

The other thing is that I would love for the seasons to feel a bit more unique (especially winter) and more types of weather, but I believe the dev is working on this. The Bloomin Spring update is great step towards that direction so far, and I'm extremely excited for the future of this game. I actually prefer it to Stardew, because the rwg seed/minecraft aspect and AC concept of making your own settlement (plus 3d decorating) is more up my alley. Anyway, super cute and super worth it! If you like AC or Stardew, absolutely give it a try!
This game made me feel like I have my life together. Highly recommend

I want to say I definitely don't regret buying this game. I put 85 hours into it and that's a decent amount of hours for a game at this price. However, compared to other games that "scratch that itch", this game has a huge void where more content should be.

I have never played Animal Crossing, so I don't know how this game compares, but a lot of folks compare this game to Stardew Valley. I put 600 hours into Stardew Valley and never really made it through the Island quests, which is to say I freaking love Stardew and that game has a huge amount of content. Not to mention, Stardew is less expensive than Dinkum.

Please, stop comparing this to Stardew. It just does not match up. You can't make wine or beer, you can't marry anyone, you can't make the equivalent of a "slime hutch", there's no Wizard, there are very few recipes, and the list goes on. This game takes a very shallow dip into many of the pools of gameplay that really good games like Stardew have. But, it's just a shallow facsimile, not a true sandbox game.

This game will not cure your itch for "something like Stardew Valley but new". Only a new Stardew map, or a mod will do that. Then again, I didn't quite make it all the way to the very best tools I could have crafted, so I would say this game has a good 100 hours of gameplay or so if you want to do everything except the super grindy achievements.

The new update adds a few drops to each of the various gameplay pools, like some new flowers. I might have reinstalled and tried this game again if they had added any new crops to grow, or some way to make growing crops more interesting but alas that didn't happen. Growing crops and utilizing them for money, food, or anything in this game just sucks beans compared to Stardew.

One last little rant, I really wanted to like building in this game but it's just not a great experience. I wanted to build a lookout tower, so I manually shoveled piles of dirt into a wheelbarrow and slowly built upward. Interacting with tools and terrain in this game can be a nightmare, but I really wanted to get a bird's eye view of my little town, and the crop field I had planned out. The height limit for building is pretty short it turns out. So, you just can't build a tower. It's about 10 tiles up. Yeah, it's a sandbox, just not a very big one. Still, to its credit it's better than Green Hell or Ark for me in terms of fun per dollar spent, which is saying something. Get it on sale, with very low expectations.

I have no idea why Steam hasn't implemented a "maybe" button yet, but I would give this game a "maybe" recommendation, leaning towards "just play Stardew while listening to an Australian podcast or youtuber".

This is a great game to play alone or with family/friends. I haven't experienced any bugs or problems on single player and only a little laggy on multiplayer. The Good: Haven't played animal crossing or stardew valley, however, this game is a lot of fun.  Yes, there are a few bugs you'll run into with it being early access, but the game is actually quite polished and at a good stage to jump in. The game overall really grabs you right away and I was instantly addicted. Multiplayer is a lot of fun!The bad:  Performance is not good.  I have a RTX 4090 with a high end gaming system full optimized for gaming.   I have zero issues with other high end AAA games with MAX settings.  However, with Dinkum I cannot even run this game with high graphics without stuttering.   The stuttering only happens inside my town and probably because I have a big town with a lot of stuff in it.  However, when I'm only getting 50-60 FPS with medium graphics and 5 view chunk and high FPS setting this is very disappointing.  The game is a ton of fun but it needs better optimization and performance for me to come back and play again.
I'm the kind of person that normally doesn't like going back to games and spending too much on it but Dinkum just keep luring me back.

If you were previously a Switch player and were on the Animal Crossing train, this will be great on your steam deck. While I appreciate the mechanics of this game more so than AC, there is still something missing. Even still, I can't put it down. The tutorial in the beginning is hit or miss. Sometimes, its very straight forward, and sometimes you run around for a day or two wondering if you're going to prompt something new to happen. If I had to choose one complaint about in game play, its having to buy new tools in the beginning until you build the machine to repair them. Unlike AC, You do kind of have to plan more things or you'll get stuck without something in the first couple of days. I love the traditional day/night cycle. I love the environment but would love to see more diversity in the atmosphere. Overall, this is a great break for the more serious survival and RPGs I play. I've found myself looking forward to running around collecting Kangaroo poo and selling it.

Such a great game! A true passion project that's just so well executed. I think this is also created by a single person, the developer, James, as I watched a live stream with him and he's continually adding things and tweaking the game to make it even better. It's beautiful, there's crocodiles! It finds the perfect balance between animal crossing, stardew valley, and minecraft and maybe even Dragon Quest Builders 2 and Zelda BOTW. And it takes elements from those games that perhaps felt less fluid or like too much effort and makes them even more enjoyable. So well balanced and executed, and feels like we're entering a new era of a higher standard for games with this one. Oh and the sunlight! It's funny because these games really help people with learning about nature and farming and building and the names of all things wildlife... I was with a friend at the botanical gardens in my city irl, and he and I were both shocked at how many plants I could identify, just because i've played so many of these games! It's exciting that this one is set in an Australia like landscape and I'm learning about so many new things and now I'm gonna want to visit Australia one day... I'm sorry if I digress, my head is full and my heart even fuller with this one. Love, love, love  :)

Since the advent of Stardew Valley, I feel that there has been an explosion of these 3D farming/collecting games. They all more or less look the same when you are looking through the pictures and videos on the steam store pages, their only distinguishing features being the one or two gimmicks that make them unique. When I first saw Dinkum, I completely wrote it off as some lazy cash grab coming into to snipe the same audience as Stardew Valley and its many clones. 

That said during the Steam Winter sale of '22, Dinkum was going for a good price and it looked interesting enough to pick up. To be completely honest, I am super happy that I did. Dinkum is 100% greater than the sum of its parts and is a testament to what indie games can do with a little community support and some good ideas. Dinkum pays homage to the Outback better than any other title I have come across, doing a stellar job of invoking the desolation of rural Australia without ever making the player feel lonely or dejected. Mechanically, Dinkum is innovative and interesting to play with. The way that soil can be moved and manipulated and the various systems in place around this mechanic is quite impressive for a game that could otherwise be written off as just another farming game. The way that Dinkum includes bug catching, mining, farming, hunting, dungeon crawling, fishing, and vehicular gameplay without making any of the individual gameplay components feel too weak or unpolished in comparison to the others is a serious mark of success for an indie title. No one gameplay method is more overpowered than the rest, allowing players to enjoy Dinkum regardless of their gamestyle of choice. The game looks good, sounds good, and has mostly good performance with minimal bugs or crashing. Of note, there is a serious performance issue with the underground mines, but not any gamebreaking issues to be concerned about. The characters control well and the gameplay is intuitive without feeling like a copy of other titles. Dinkum is the complete survival package, pulling the best mechanics of its contemporaries into one solid title. I would happily recommend the title to anyone with a passing enjoyment of Stardew-like titles and I look forward to seeing what else is added to the otherwise already incredily fleshed out title as it moves towards release.

For a game that is named after edging and orgasm denial, it's pretty cute. However, the numbers of flaws and frustrations outweighs the fun and satisfaction I had in my 60+ hours of gameplay. Minor spoilers ahead:

[b]Overall[/b]
- If you are looking for Stardew Valley experience, this game isn't for you. It may look very much like SV, but the gameplay is more of sandbox or city building, rather than farming sims. 
- Despite being early access, the game is pretty much playable. However, there needs to be a significant amount of updates, quality of life improvements as well as balancing in order to make this game more enjoyable. 

[b]Good[/b]
- Graphic and animations are simple but yet fantastic. Main attraction of this game. 
- Background music and sound effects are decent. It gets repetitive after a while but not to the extend of annoying.
- There are a few glitches and fps drops but nothing game breaking so far.

[b]Bad[/b]
- The game is incredibly grindy AND repetitive, which makes everything a chore. There is limited numbers of automation at this stage. Hence, everything gets even worse as you progress/expand further. 
- Everything is randomized. Literally everything. From the world map, to the mines, to NPC quests and even to the crafting recipes. This takes the meaning out of exploration because no matter how far I venture away from my base, everything is the same as what I have in the vicinity. 
- NPC quests are garbage. The objectives and rewards are generic regardless who is the quest giver. Worst thing is that, crafting recipes, which are considered as key items for this game since it heavily revolves around decorating, are locked behind these freaking lame quests. But that's not all. you would have no prior knowledge of what reward you will receive until you have completed the quests, which I think it's complete bullsheet. 90% of the time, you get a pathetic amount of coins and 10% of it you will receiving a RANDOM crafting recipe. It took me an eternity just to unlock two wooden streetlamps, that are not aesthetically compatible with my base design.
- Speaking of crafting recipes, Frankly sells one every day (except Sat/Sun)... but... it's random, AND inclusive recipes that you've already learned. Seriously how hard is it for the developer to make him sell only new recipe, or create a vendor to allow me to straight up buy what I need? This is just stupid design at it's finest. 
- The deep mine is one of the most painful experience I had, as if it the developer is a sadist or masochist or some sort. Not a surprise if it's true, since anyone sane would not name the game [b]Din'tCum[/b]. Basically everything in the mine is once again, random. You can go 100km into the mine but still see the same crap you see in the first 100m. And there's like only 3 types of enemies in the mine which you can cheese easily by spamming jump hit.
- The game also has some serious balancing issues. Bugs, shells, fish, fruits and even crops are worthless, as compared to hunting down all the Mu and Crocs every day. Why bother with watering worthless crops or wasting your time with bugs and fishes, when you can get like 100-200K easily every day just by capturing stupid animals? Yes, it's tedious and not enjoyable, but it's the most efficient way to progress.
- Most of the stuffs are heavily overpriced, or incredibly inconvenient just to stall player and artificially lengthen the game. Take example if I wish to move a building, I gotta pay 25K AND wait a day. Oh? And this action is limited to only once per day. For fk sake this is a decorating game. How the hell am I suppose to experiment with my design and have fun at the same time, if there's so many unnecessary restrictions? 
- Licence system is a creative idea, but it's poorly executed. Irrigation licence, why does this exist? Shouldn't it be part of farming? It's like going to Mc Donalds and order a BigMac just to realize that patty is not included, sold separately. 
- There is no final goal or ways to beat the game. Once you reached financial freedom, which is less than a year in game for me, your purpose is to keep decorating and nothing else. Since most of the crafting recipes are locked behind randomly generated generic quests which I don't care enough to do, I have basically hit a wall. There is no motivation or purpose for me to continue playing the game unless I wish to suffer. 
- Multiplayer - I have not tried it, but thankfully I read the wiki first before persuading my friend to jump into this game. There's a huge tons of limitations from what I understood, which probably will not make the multiplayer experience fun.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
- The concept of this game is cool (although not original), but it would need at least a few years and significant amount of updates to meet my standards. 
- There needs to be a mod or a DLC to significant reduce the randomness in order to promote exploration, while making each NPCs unique and interesting. But I doubt that will happen.
- Considered how cheap this game is priced, if you like life sims, sandbox, or decorating games, give it a try. Just don't put your hopes and expectations too high up.

It's a bit rough.   But what's there is awesome.  I'd love it if they could build in as much depth as similar games.  I'd REALLY LOVE IT if they'd open up modding and let the community get more involved with creating content.  The idea of like... a almost endless supply of islanders and shops would be so great.  But right now; it's pretty similar to animal crossing.  I feel like adding a bug guy; a fishing guy; a wood chopping guy; a star collecting guy; you know the stuff that animal crossing had; but making them actual villagers would be super fun.  I played for about 40 to 50 hours; and hit a cliff.  it's honestly.  really pretty. really fun. and really well put together.  and the direction that they're looking to grow looks even better.  But i definitely air on the side that; they've gotta shoot big to blow animal crossing out of the water.  and let me tell you.  this is a close close call.  the 3d visuals; the island size and customization options are just... so cool.  with just slightly more depth this could be a home run.  and i feel like we're just at the edge.

As Gordon Ramsey would say : "a bit bland".

Major problem with the game is the Stamina management. There are no sure ways other than eating quality food to get stamina increase and recovery. 

This is especially painful early to mid game and somewhat persists throughout the whole experience. I had some days where all I did is either fish, farm or hunt just to stock up on food in order to do some creative stuff like : city planning, landscaping, forestry, crafting and plethora of other fun activities. 

Your character will level up certain skills which then consume less stamina in the process but some tasks like "shovelling the ground" DO NOT INCREASE the skills! I spent in game WEEKS to flatten the ground or make hills with NO PROGRESS and MONEY made. Just to have a nice flat surface to place buildings on. 

Yet, all that ground work consumes tons of stamina on top of breaking the tools. Even with electric tools that are unlocked later on the job is still painfully cumbersome. 

In my humble opinion there should be a skill that levels up the stamina ( with a limit, let's say 100 % more stamina than starting one ), some landscaping tasks should also count towards progression and decrease stamina usage. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Town Debt can be a pain but once the player starts farming with a traktor or unlock the mines ( mid- to late game ) player will be swimming in money. 

Exploration is rather bland and uneventful ( although I recommend choosing STARTING location wisely and have a plan in mind otherwise it will be costly and time consuming to move all the buildings to a new area ). 

Combat is... well it works. There is no active skills, armours, throwables, dodges etc. It's as basic as it can get. Left click to attack and WASD to move around. Considering enemies in the mines can be rather annoying and the rooms claustrophobic this kind of combat just begs for an improvement. 

NPC's are dull and they have very limited dialogue database. I had encountered some "TEXT GOES HERE" boxes on 4-5 star relationship hearts and I have never seen A.I doing some actual work. Like repairing stuff, farming or even fishing. Stuff that makes them a bit more believable. In the future I hope they will use vehicles, boats and interact with each other or the animals more... that however all depends on the Developer. 

Graphics are charming but personally hate some of the designs... such as kangaroos with antlers? dogs that look like an ordinary dingo or a mutt you see everywhere, NPC's are as charming as a potato and other than that I would like to see MOUNTAINS, WATERFALLS, BRIDGES FOR VEHICLES just to bring much needed variety! Most biomes are on repeat and once you have seen one there is no point in going to another... 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The game can be fun and relaxing. Seeing the biome slowly transform into a bustling town with plenty of crops gives a nice cosy, feeling of achievement. 
Grind is painful and constant stamina management makes it even worse. Unlocking recipes is random and some activities are not explained properly ( such as capturing animals etc. ). 

I would like to recommend the game but only if you have LOTS and i mean LOADS OF SPARE TIME. 

I've put around 40 hours in and I'm nowhere near the completion. Remember, take it slow as some days will be spent on catching up / stocking up, in order to have fun the day after.

Absolutely lovely game. If you're looking for an incredible farming game this is your stop. Very Aussie styled animal crossing type play.  Excellent with multiplayer :D all around very impressive.  graphics are so very cute.  The game is just very well put together.  I could play it forever <3

I cannot wait to see the future of Dinkum, it's the best game I've picked up in the past year.

Also, if you are sensitive to motion sickness from first-person gaming like I am, I haven't had any problems playing this game, so that's a huge plus just on its own.

I'm nearing the 30 hr mark, and I unfortunately would not recommend this game as-is. There is an update coming that the DEV plans to drop sometime soon and I'm uncertain if it's going to address any of my concerns,

I share sentiments with other reviews on several aspects. It's not the worst game I've played, but it has performance issues (that showed up when I tried to scale down the settings to gain performance), you'll need to wiki for insight on some matters because they just are not explained outright until a point that becomes sour (there are books on some things you can buy, but you need to get to the point you've built John's Shop). There-in, it could be said it suffers some pacing and conveyance of information issues.

Blueprints are gate-kept behind the permits, or research, or experience level, or you have to do favors for the NPCs and hope they decide to reward your help with clothings, furniture, or blueprint. Some items did not show up in catalog. Items are supposed to show up in catalog when you obtain them so you can ditch them to save inventory space and dinks towards paying off the debts. Debts slowly get contributions from the NPCS over time, but the debts are often large so if you don't know the fast money methods you would be grinding in an environment with very little in the way of mobs, plants, etc compared to many sandbox/building/crafting games.


I unlocked the deep mine to find that it costs 25K dinks for a one-time pass to access them, I have to buy iot every time I want to attempt to explore the deep mines. The town debt on adding the deep mines is 250K. Couldn't make progress in the mine because of bats and mushroom gator. Was expecting to not need to destroy all the surface rocks to get desperately needed copper and iron (have plenty of tin) so I could keep the natural appearances of the world. Not sure if I should have waited to do this deed, because frankly I'm not seeing the ROI in access to the ores I need to snowball the other projects I need to get done -building certain blueprint items and structures that will open up better revenue streams to accelerate the town growth.

But everything feels sand bagged despite having upgraded my house, have John's shop, the Museum, the Greenhouse, and the Deep Mine all built. I'm not feeling like I gained traction. NPCs have dialog, but it starts to really repeat after not too long. If you are asked to fetch a thing, you better have it on you already, because if you can't find it by the end of the in-game day then the character's bond to you takes a small hit.

This is a very ambitious project and frankly I feel like the sluggish build up to get the resources I need to build as I'd like is going to have me so dulled by the limited landscape and dull interactions that I'm going to drop this because I'm going to feel too much of my time is being taken for minimal reward in progression and ability to do what I desire to do: design the landscape and a town.

Technically, aside from performance hits that make no sense popping up sporadically, causing stuttering, I had issues where in trying to deselect items to sell to John the game simply refused to move the selection (playing on controller). I had to grab my mouse and keyboard to remedy the issue. Also, trying to toss caged animals to a drop zone sometimes is an issue as the cage lands on the walls of the drop spot, so some animals would break out and get stuck, and it'd take a few tries to get the cage in the drop zone -having to re-capture the animal each time the cage got stuck as you can't just pick it up again off the side wall it gets stuck on.


I'd love to have enjoyed this to the degree others seem to suggest they are at this point -but I'm not. It feels too early in development. I also feel like I'm likely going to need to restart each update to gauge how updates affected elements -which further derails from the building I want to do. There are going to be people who love the slow build up. Frankly I find it strange that I've upgraded my house and have 3 shops, and yet I don't have an actual bed and I'm not being bugged to build homes for the residents prior to building their shops. They all legit stand around at night in whatever weather and have no place to sleep. Nobody even raises a single complaint about it. I desperately need copper and iron, but time doing that detracts from time paying off debts for adding buildings. I don't think there is enough on the surface to not have me drastically changing everything. I am unaware if rocks randomly reform on the surface over time or not, which makes me hesitant to just break them all down.

As the dev points out in the explanation of the EA status, there is a generally playable game here. Thing is, what needs to be tweaked to make it all mesh just right and how long until that is implemented? I can't get a refund at this point.The gamet has charm, and potential. But I'm going to have to check back in months, maybe two years later to see if progress was ever made to a point that actually addresses deep dynamic synergies and immersion coherence in ways that make the experience better.

Charming game based off the Aussie outback where you build your own town, gather resources, and find mysterious gadgets and gizmos from the distant past. Can occasionally be buggy in multiplayer, but it's quite fun otherwise!

Unlike most early access games, this is completely playable. In fact, the feel of the movement, combat, vehicles, is extremely fluid for the most part. I've noticed very few glitches and none were game breaking. 

My problem is that unlike a lot of other games of the similar genre the story and other people feel lacking and not entirely thought out, very little changes from season to season, and there is very little incentive to play the game other than building because you enjoy building. The personalities of villagers all seem one dimensional with many of their responses being generically used for all other villagers and often when talking with them I get an "insert text here" instead of actual dialog. Melvin, for example, is old and his knees hurt. That is pretty much his entire personality. 

I know this game is in early access and I also fully respect that, however, we have little indication as to whether or not the townsfolk's personalities, quests, and relationship system will be overhauled. I would like a more detailed road map and time frame of what is coming to the game. Currently we know the developer is working on a spring overhaul, but there is little information on what that means or when it is coming. I want to see that this game has set goals, know what they are for each part of the game, and know roughly when we can expect them (A roadmap!). I don't mind if things are later than expected. problems happen, I just want to know what I can look forward to and if the things that I think would make this game great are even in the works!

For some reason, I can't stop playing this game. It's perfect for relaxing and it's the game Animal Crossing should have been in the first place. Animal Crossing had a ton of items, but they would just "sit there" and look cool. In this game, at least so far, you can actually use every item that you get. The wheelbarrow moves dirt. The fence keeps animals from eating crops. The campfire cooks food. The furnace processes ore. The metal detector finds usable treasure. This game is highly addictive. The graphics are appealing. It's like a combination of Stardew, Animal Crossing and Minecraft. If you like those kind of games you'll love this.

I do enjoy Dinkum and think it is a solid game, however, it does seem aimed at a younger audience because I quickly find out each day that I run out of things to do. Kids can endlessly run in circles and have fun, but that doesn't work for me as an adult. The other "harvest"-like games I've played I feel like I run out of time each day trying to do everything I want to get done, but with Dinkum I always run out of things to do each day. My long term wish is for Dinkum to have more activities and depth that can appeal to older players.

After playing for 66 hours, I really love this game. Dinkum remind me of Animal Crossing but we also interact with human. Landscaping come in early stages of the game by exchanging permit point to Landscape License. We will also get the recipes to craft paths, bridges, stairs.

The map area is so big, consist of different biomes which have different resources and creatures. For example:
1. You will have to go to Pine Forest to farm Hardwood (although some hardwood trees can also found in other biomes) and Pine Forest also has Bush Devil an aggressive animal that chase you even though you ran away far enough.
2. You will have to go to Bushland biome to get Yellow wattle flower and there are different insect that will appear specifically in Bushland in a certain time / season.
3. You will have to go to Desert or Plain biome to farm stone or ore.
4. etc.

What I really love about the game is:
1. We only need one click and repair kits to restore tools durability. Though Repair tools cost a lot of dinks. In my case, I will use the tools until it's durability limit then repair them at once. Repairing tools is really helpful since craft new durable tools will cost you so much ore.
2. Landscaping is easy. However, I will be so glad if James can give us more space in the wheelbarrow. But that's okay for me. We only need to buy more wheelbarrow right.
3. Making a pond is fun for me, though I have to make water path before the water go to the space I prepare for the pond. Please let the fish I capture can be release in the pond.
4. Capturing animals for research is fun activity. I struggle to catch the animals, but after i figure it out how. it's really fun. I can capture crocodile, bush devils which give me 12K dinks. My next experiment will be alpha animals. xD.
5. Fulfilling camp visitor is exciting because if we succeed, the will want to stay at our town and our town will get bigger.
6. The game is not only about building a prosperous island and decorating it but there are some challenges like aggressive animals that will chase us and attack us, defeating alpha animals, or finding special NPC like Ted Shelly.
7. I love the idea of transportation because the map is really big.
8. The option of single player and multiplayer is also fun. I can invite my friends to join my island or I don't have to be afraid of losing my island progress when joining their island.
9. There are farming, ranching, and fishing features in this game which I really like. With addition almost all of the wild plants, trees, and bushes have seed that we can plant near our base or plant as decoration. The trees and some bushes will definitely useful for stamina and health or for making dinks. And the residents also helps us watering our crops, petting our ranch animals.
10. Stamina and Health Bar limit can be increased to maximum by eating some foods. It helps a lot when dealing with Alpha Animals, Glowing Croco, Bush Devils or Landscaping, gathering resources, mining, fishing, farming, ranching, etc.

The issue that I am still dealing with is going to deep mine: the entry permit is just one time permit cost 25K dinks. So expensive for me and well, the animals there, especially glowing croco will deal massive damage. If we didn't max our health bar limit, then we will die instantly by just one hit from glowing croco.

And if I may give a suggestion:
1. Can we raise fish in the pond or fish can spawn in the pond that we made.
2. Because exploring the island need a lot of time, please slow down the time. Because some creatures only appear in certain times and certain biomes, I often cannot fulfill the residents request because the times is passed.
3. Can we use water bucket to fill an area with water to make pond instead of digging and making water path.
4. Please gives us ATM that available in Town Hall that can be accessed after 4 or 6 p.m. Because I've ever encountered Ted Shelly accidentally and when I went to the bank, the bank was closed. I couldn't withdraw my savings. Fortunately, I still could sell hunting loots to Ted Shelly, so I can bought the weapon from him.
5. Please give us the opportunity to save the game anytime.

The game is so fun and so promising. I can stop playing it. I also really curious about animal research department that I wish I can meet the researcher someday. You guys definitely should play dinkum.

Dinkum is a captivating and addictive game that enables players to construct and personalize their own town. Its adorable graphics and immersive gameplay make it an irresistible game for players who are sure to return for more.

One of the game's highlights is its user-friendly interface, which makes it effortless to get started. The game's mechanics are uncomplicated, making it easy for players to grasp the gameplay and begin building and decorating their town immediately. This simplicity allows players to avoid the challenges often encountered in other games and dive right into having fun.

As players progress through the game, they can expand their town by adding new buildings and decorations. The game offers a range of engaging activities, from catching bugs for the local museum to fishing for the town's inhabitants, which players can complete to earn rewards and enhance their town's overall rating.

Dinkum also features a multiplayer mode that allows players to team up with friends to build and customize their towns collaboratively. This feature makes the game even more interactive and social.

All in all, Dinkum is an exceptional game that is definitely worth exploring. Its charming graphics, engaging gameplay, and enjoyable multiplayer mode will keep players coming back for more.

If you like Animal Crossing, Harvest Moon, Stardew Valley, Sims, or Minecraft; You will probably love this game to death. Animated and relaxing gameplay with a fun outback Australia theme. If you have ever felt too constrained by time-gates in other RPGs, this game allows a quick use of a sleeping bag to fast forward to the next morning. I like how this game blends the best mechanics of games similar to it, to create a masterpiece of hunter gatherer gameplay mixed with community planning. Great value for the price you pay, especially if you get the game on sale.

Multiplayer with my partner has been really fun, with the limitation that only the person hosting the game can change island outcomes. Anybody visiting is just there to help gather resources and explore.

My experience with early access "bugs" is a mislabelled piece of furniture, or a wild animal staying underwater for a few days. Not game breaking but bizarre and hilarious.

This game runs pretty flawlessly even on an Intel Arc A770.

If you need your blood pressure lowered and an Australian vacation, do I ever have the game for you!

Third person would be great, if the mouse controls weren't so horrible; it is a challenge just trying to pickup items, there's no cross-hair on direction which isn't bound to camera and you have to pickup items individually, over and over, which means constantly readjusting the position of your character until you get the highlight.
Walking around the map sometimes I'll hit an invisible wall (or the controls are just derping) and go in a straight line regardless until I stop the player.
Control scheme is all over the place, every time a dialog switches to a mouse confirmation option, the mouse is automatically in the far right corner (extremely annoying in general, let alone on large resolutions) Why not make this like interaction confirmations, left/right click, accept/cancel etc?
Saving requires you sleep in a bed, which is great... However, if you crash before that time... (O`,,'o)... There's no forced save and apparently no auto-save either... Weee, back through the intro I go.

First impressions, it feels really 'basic' and 'barren', Fletcher has about as much personality as a toaster, are all NPC's like this? Straight away a sense of mundane grind and boredom, there's no excitement and coupled with the problems I've encountered in about 30 ish mins of game play, I cannot recommend.

Honestly, at first I thought this was another cheap indie farm simulator game and had been avoiding buying it until me and my friend were burnt out on other games in the genre and were looking for a new game to play together. I was so wrong.

I started up Dinkum and I was hooked. It just felt right the moment I got past the opening scene. I regret not playing this sooner because I have been playing it as soon as I finish and get home from work pretty much every day since the first day. My friend is getting annoyed at me for asking her every evening to play with me chanting "Dinkum time, Dinkum time, Dinkum time~!" -- I may be addicted... Maybe.

This game is a perfect mix of Harvest Moon/Story of Seasons and Animal Crossing: New Horizons with the twist of it being in a post-apocalyptic (?) Australia. It's amazing! There's a lot of potential here and despite being version 0.5 at the time of typing this, it already has a lot of content.

Since it's in Early Access it does have a few bugs and "Need text here" dialogues. Bugs are especially common when playing with my friend online, but they're not game-breaking as far as I've seen. A Common bug I encounter again and again that is a bit annoying is that when two fish bite the lure at the same time and I pick up both, the fish models disappear and I battle two fish at the same time, but only get one of them.

There are a few suggestions I have that I hope will make it into the game at some point; mostly QOL features in form of new items/furniture so it's something to work towards. Like for example I hope that there's going to be a workbench chest/box where if you put it next to a crafting station that the station next to it then takes the items in the storage for crafting in addition to your inventory. Or a fridge where the items in there will be available for the cooking station as well as the inventory if put within 2 blocks of the cooking station.

I'm also hoping that maybe in the future there will be NPCs that can come to your island that aren't just shop owners, but normal citizens. I understand that might be a bit cheat-y because of the hangout system but maybe it can be done so they just follow you around and don't really do anything or are only available on certain days. I wish that NPCs will have some story, etc. as well in the future when content-wise/time-wise there's still room to add that before release. Or maybe as some extra content in the future after release.

That being said, I really highly recommend this game, even in Early Access. It's a lot of fun already, even when playing solo.

I am enjoying this game so far, though there are a few things I have problems with. (Side note: I have never played animal crossing on the switch, but had an interest and heard this was similar. I have played Animal Crossing:New Leaf on the 3DS.)

Pros:
-Calming atmosphere. Really nice music and many friendly animals and people. 
-Lots to explore. The island is pretty big. 
-Awesome mapping features. Help make the island seem smaller than it is and help in navigating areas. 
-Different vehicle options. I only have a boat right now, but next time the scientist visits, I'll upgrade. 
-Almost a double jump. You can jump pretty high in this game. 
-Intro cut scene. Caught me off guard when it played. 
-Fishing. Took me a minute to understand the fishing mechanic, but once I learned, I enjoyed and welcomed the challenge. 
-Upgradable inventory. I like getting on a new level. 
-Pretty water. Everything looks nice and cute....*
-Loads quickly. Barely takes any time to load the game. 
-Pause in menu options. 

Cons:
-Targeting. Whether it's picking up items or fighting a croc, I have problems targeting the the right thing. For item pickup, you have to create distance to pick up the item. For enemies, that may be me just learning how to hunt, but it seemed rigged lol
-Cost of items. The store is tew mooch. 
-John. Overpricing store owner. 
-Placement near tent. I can't set objects right next to my tent. Weird gap in between. Maybe for posts at corner. Idk. 
-Lack of Lore. I need more drama. Like, someone running from the cops to my island, and I don't find out until later. More cut scenes lol
-Fishing. The fish ignore my line and my character doesn't turn smooth enough for me to get the correct degree. Not sure if bait upgrade will be in the future of play.
-*...besides the characters. Need more customization. May come with more visitors though. 
-Can only save when characters sleep. 
-Needs an optional tutorial. You kind of have to figure things out on your own. 

This game also reminds me of Ooblets, but without collection aspect, iykyk. But I am enjoying. Surprised at my game play time. Anyway, if you like a calm with a lil bit of challenge, play this. Challenges can be avoided if you don't fish and avoid enemies.

Yes, it's an Animal Crossing clone. However, it adds a lot of things which Animal Crossing lacks: combat, vehicles (even a helicopter FFS), skill-based fishing, a tiered crafting system, individual NPC relationship meters and quest-giving, character skill trees, <AUSTRALIA>, a very vague story about the end of the world, and it's still being developed.

I recommend this, at its current price, because it's a simple little game that scratches that AC itch but has enough variety on the formula to feel fresh. I look forward to seeing the future updates to add to what is already a very familiar, yet very fresh, experience. BONZA!

These are just some random ideas I had. Some may be too extra xD, but regardless here they are:

World:
I would love to see bigger maps, or maybe even a way to unlock more parts of the world to explore. A way to haul stuff in a car to allow for more expansion and longer journeys? I'm looking forward to more bugs, fish and animals. As we unlock more areas to the world maybe incorporate the new areas for specific new animals, bugs and fish? That could be a fun way of adding them. Where we had to sail across the waters to get to the new lands and possibly later game connecting the teleporters all together.

Mining:
maybe have certain caves spread out throughout the map that only allow certain ores to be found would be cool and even adding new ores. 

People: I'm looking forward to seeing more people to interact with as well as hearing more about their stories, possibly getting some cut scenes would be awesome!  It would be cool to see how multiplayer can advance as well. It would be nice to have the opportunity to trade with the fellow residents. Maybe having certain quests we can pick to unlock specific Items we want to learn? Also for hanging out with the residents it would be quite interesting if you could pick certain tasks to do together for a limited time. Example: I ask John to go out fishing with me and I get to keep those fish we both catch, then there being a time limit on how long we can do the activity together. Houses for the actual residents, so they aren't just wandering around past a certain time. These houses can come alongside the original deed or be an extra one you have to give them.

Skills:
I like how the permit points are and I would love to see more things we can unlock and maybe even new skills to get access to. For example Construction and Farming. I know there is technically already those in a way, but having more to unlock. Where for a farmer your crops have a higher chance of growing faster if you upgrade the fertilizer, or the water is better on the crops if it's filtered. The construction permit will have more building upgrades.

If you've enjoyed stardew and animal crossing this game will feel like a mix of the two. A cozy world to walk around and people to talk to, build friendship with that talk in familiar jumbled language (Which I presume to be Australian). 

The game is very open to the point that the world can feel somewhat empty, but note this is an early access game and there's still a lot to do and find. Deserts for instance which initially seem deserted are actually loaded with trash buried just under the surface. What a find! A true Australian experience. 

As an honorary Australian you can do things such as; Collect spiders, Fight crocodiles, flirt with old women but also not know who's a man or woman (Common problem in Australia) and also colonize an Island by racking up tremendous debts to build things such as a bug and fish museum. Fascinating subjects to all. 
Overall the game is very fun and If they continue to add more I expect they'll continue to see a growing fanbase. 

A few things I'd like to see; 

More things in the world, region unique resources for instance to encourage travel. Fruit is great to this purpose and encourages you to bring it home and plant a food forest. Which I did in the desert. Who knew it was that easy? 

A block or dodge for combat. You can literally run around enemies and jump over stuff pretty easy anyhow. But it'd be nice to have at least one little wrinkle the distinguishes swinging an axe from swinging a cricket bat with teeth stuck to it when engaging in mortal combat with mutant wombat. 

Some consistency on interactions. Something I struggle with is right click left click, E on how to use various things. Maybe I just need to rebind the keys to comfort.

Region specific buildings/bonuses? It'd be neat to have a reason to spread out your village, or finding the perfect place for certain structures that will encourage travel overland.
