This game is amazing and here's why:

Dinkum is basically Animal Crossing: Expanded and Enhanced. It takes everything you love from animal crossing, and adds onto it.

There's crafting, fighting, exploring, better movement, better building, better town customization.
The outfits are great, the items are great, progression feels earned, the farming is phenomenal, the characters are different and unique, the economy feels balanced, etc.

I have been a fan of the Animal Crossing games since Wild World, but always felt like something was missing. This game fills that void with things I didn't even know I wanted from a game like this.
if harvest moon, minecraft, and animal crossing met up, this is roughly what it would be.

**This review contains spoilers**

TLDR; If you love Animal Crossing you will enjoy Dinkum.


I rarely purchase early access games as it's difficult to gauge how "complete" a game is before purchasing. The overwhelmingly positive reviews and reasonable sale price enticed me and here I am - 100+ hours in.

While compared to Harvest Moon and Stardew Valley, Dinkum most closely resembles Animal Crossing. Harvest Moon and Stardew are fleshed-out towns with citizens, existing buildings, and very few (if any) new characters move in. Dinkum is different in that nobody lives on this island except for you and Fletch until you bust your butt to move them in. Bust your butt in this case means talking to potential residents, doing errands for them (fetch quests), and buying from their limited wares. I say limited, but once they move into your town their available inventory expands.

A bug/fish/sea creature museum feels very AC, as does the "visitor tent." A shady salesman in a boat sounds awfully familiar too - but no need to worry about wasting your dinks on bootleg artwork. 

The Gameplay:
The gameplay is enjoyable and the animations crisp. This area far exceeded my expectations for an early access game. Fishing, farming, bug catching, hunting, and decorating allows for a variety of game play styles. There are some mild clipping issues but nothing that has posed an issue.

I would love tutorial quests. For example, Fletch asks you to plant some crops and the game explains to you what you need, where to get it, etc. I spent 40+ hours confused that I had to buy seeds/tools from a specific villager. Once this information is explained to the player it could be added to the in-game wiki tab.  I was growing watermelons and pumpkins to create scarecrows and the birds kept eating them. Thanks to reddit I discovered that birds can't cross fences so I crafted a bunch and never lost another crop. This isn't a big deal as I have nothing but time. If I had put in 40 hours in the office and wanted to come home to play a game only to not understand the mechanics I might not have continued playing.
I still haven‚Äôt figured out animal trapping and I managed to catch several fish but I'm not sure how I did it :)

I was so excited for the motorbike but I found the controls to be entirely too sensitive. I play with a  controller and the amount of times I revved up only to find myself in a river outnumbers the amount of times I steered with ease.  I found the lawnmower tedious to use, very slow, and stiff to steer. Although I haven't purchased a tractor yet I would love to have a grass cutting attachment. Larger area to cut, etc.   I have had no other issues with any of the vehicles. In fact, gliding around my island makes me ridiculously happy. I could have a whole game of just gliding around!

I'm not a huge fan of hunting or deep mines as I'm more for a relaxing gaming experience. I think that many players would enjoy these areas, but the deep mines left me feeling panicked. The bats are overabundant and out of the dozens I've slayed I've earned one bat wing. Thanks to the magic of mods, I've been able to freely traverse the deep mines and take my time without the anxiety of being lost in the cavernous abyss. 

Music:

The music is pleasant, but I would prefer to have more variety of music that plays continually. There are times when the music ends and the world feels a little empty aside from a few bird calls.

Characters: 

The character design is cute and the voices are very Animal Crossing - that's not a bad thing.

The only time this game feels early access is with the limited number of characters that move into your town. There is minimal if no backstory, the same dialogue is repeated multiple times, and the "text needed" message is shown for nearly every character when you speak to them. The frequency of the "text needed" message varies but I'm sure this will be remedied in future updates. One last note on dialogue:  I would like to have some sort of character development as you raise friendship levels. Surely the cranky banker wouldn't stay cranky forever would he?

New players: stock up on moon butterflies and flies. Once a day I have a villager asking for one.

Perhaps I am spoiled by Animal Crossing where visitors are enticed to stay after visiting the campsite but I would love to see more villagers who aren't just shopkeepers. Surely I‚Äôm not the only one in town who are providing all the economy to this island. I'd love to see more characters who are more than the products they sell.

Clothing and furniture:

I don‚Äôt feel strongly about the clothing or furniture. I‚Äôd like to see that using it raises the beauty score of the island. I don‚Äôt have any reason to buy it as I only go into my house at night to sleep. The ability to design your own clothing or paths would be a nice addition but again, Animal Crossing has spoiled me.

My Wishlist for quality of life improvements:

-It would be great to be able to craft from storage boxes that are nearby. I'm currently using a mod that allows this.
-I would like to see what season to plant which crops added to the in-game wiki
-I would like to see how much items sell for when I hover over them in my inventory
-Auto-pickup would be a very welcome addition. For anyone who is harvesting many crops it becomes tedious to have to click once to harvest and click again to pick it up. 
-The ability to turn off aggression in animals. Sometimes I just want to terraform and decorate my island without being charged by an irate crocodile.
-The ability to craft multiple items at once
-Once you've reached level 100 at a skill it would be nice to have an unbreakable variant of the corresponding tool/tools
-The beauty score is confusing - One day I'm at 94% the next 77% without making any changes to my island.

Overall, this game is shockingly polished for early access and I recommend anyone who enjoys Animal Crossing specifically to check it out. My final score is 7/10

Original review:
This game has been incredibly frustrating so far. The first time I opened it it crashed right away. Was able to reopen and play for an hour and then crashed and wasn't able to save. Relaunched and started over again, played about an hour again and crashed right as I rolled out the sleeping bag, again I wasn't able to save. I'm debating if I want to try and play again or not. I get it's early access but it's disappointing that I'm not able to get passed the first in-game day. 

if the developer sees this I would advise a manual save option instead of the sleeping bag being the only save point.

This game is a lot like Animal Crossing New Horizons but good. I like how you can kill sharks, it's funny. I would recommend this game to anyone who liked My Time At Portia and Stardew Valley. The controls are standard and it is easy to get into the flow of them.

With my short time so far, I am enjoying this game quite a bit. I would say this is a mix between Raft and Animal Crossing. Although fishing takes a little longer than other games, I enjoy how it is interactive and intuitive. I love how the fish don't disappear if you accidentally cancel or lose the fish. Also, movement is free flowing. Although there are heavy similarities to Animal Crossing, I prefer Dinkum due to the mechanics and how easy it is to swap tools. Hunting is always a plus. It's not difficult, but you can't just stand still and smack a gator to doom. 

Light on the survival, heavy on the building and crafting, which is my preference.

I'm really enjoying this game as the 231 hrs reflect. I haven't enjoyed a game this much since the last Animal Crossing was released. The amount of time in a day is very balanced. I don't feel too rushed. It's nice that time stops at "Late" or midnight. I can do all the things that don't require energy after it's Late, such as smelting, harvesting, collecting shells ect. I have yet to see any adverse affects of doing that. There is a lot to do already in early access such as farming, fishing, hunting, building, befriending, collecting. Lot's of Dinks (money) to be made. I also am really enjoying the Australian theme. Keep up the good work James Bendon, I can't wait to see what you add next.
enjoy the gathering of resources and trying reach a million Dinkum currency. exploring and not trying to get eaten by the croc that seems to be near my tent!

This is a fairly decent game when it comes to single player, it's quite grindy in the later portion of the game but the real negative part of the experience is definitely is the COOP as the progression of the game world isn't really shared which means certain items are soft locked until you reach a point in the game of your own world, which is a shame as i purchased this game to play with my partner. If the COOP was fixed then it would make the game experience much more fulfilling.

This is a truly great game, even more so because of the low price tag. The game is a mix of Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing with a Australian flare. The best part about it is the one man development team has created a game with all the good parts of two great games and none of the bad parts and I daresay made it better considering the depth of this game as an early access title. Don't wait for a sale, buy ASAP. Good by yourself and even more fun with friends!
Once you start you can't stop it is lots of fun designing your own "little" town I just love this game!!

This game really has potential, which is why I feel as though the game is being over-hyped.  This game will be in early access for a long time based on the gaps between content releases and the lack of any new "milestone" chart. The general attitude is "this one guy will get round to it when he does".

The game as it stands is very enjoyable at first, but becomes almost as barren as the Australian outback your placed on. All the skin and bones to make a really amazing Animal Crossing mixed in with Stardew valley type game is here, just with not much content you would expect from these types of games.

I play this game with my gf over LAN connection, which has it's own issues. This game is not really intended to be a share an island multiplayer game, which is a shame. It is basically my island that my gf can visit and will be limited on what she can do and can only play on "our" island when I play. It would be really nice to have a game release like in this genre that would allow full multiplayer. 

There is also an issue with save game files becoming corrupted. We lost a real days worth of progress because of this bug, and the single developer will blame steam cloud save feature - but I don't think so, as this is the only game that has been affected in this way. 

I will check back in a couple of years when some progress has been made. I think the overall hype is just that, hype and nothing more.
Cute game, gives me animal crossing vibes.

RATING: 8.5 - Crikey! Is that a Vombat?

This game is developed by one bloke named James, from Australia. It will probably take this bloke named James, a bloody long while to get to 1.0, however the content that is here is very fleshed out. Some might even say Girthy. Strewth!

I see a lot of people commenting on how it's Animal Crossing mixed with Stardew Valley put in an Australian BBQ without any Prawns. I kinda disagree in many aspects (1000 hours in Animal Crossing over here), but IT IS a Farming Sim... and comes with all the pros and cons that a classic farming sim has, whilst adding it's own unique flavours to the formula.

I would give this a 9.5, but I cannot do that to an early access game. ALSO... their are NO Drop Bears or Bin Chickens in the game (currently as of Feb 2023)... so the highest I can go is 8.5...

Apart from that, this game is highly addictive... and incredibly chill. 
James (that one bloke from Australia) has created something very charming and very cosy.
Whilst the Character Customisation is currently lacking... it's still early days... and the content in here already, is actually really incredible for a one person team.

HOWEVER! There are a few terrible game decisions in the game, which I will list here.
- Time speeds through a little too quick, and days feel like you're just unable to get done, what you need to be done... and what you want to be done. This is very bad for anyone with ADHD.
- Energy feels unbalanced, and when combined with the time speed, it can make some days feel very unfun.
- There is a Mine that is locked behind game progress (which is great!)... but also it requires a lot of resources and dinks (money) to travel down there... and it's very hectic down there... and I probably just need to get good. 
- I will say this again... there are NO Drop Bears or Bin Chickens in the game. This is a crime against Australians...

Not terrible but just not engaging. Some things I'm sure you could fix:
Making your first scarecrow is VERY expensive since it needs the grown crops the birds will be eating so you better care for 10 pumpkins in hoping you get one out of it.
Having to pay, what, 30 grand every single time you want to go into the mine is wild for a building that is already expensive.
Not many quests or general sense of direction; go get 5 residents by doing a load of fetch quests and unlocking that many merchants.
It's a slow grind to unlock merchants, but then you don't really have anything to do any more - no endgame yet.

Problem is the core gameplay loop just isn't that good - it doesn't have much engagement with the fixed villagers like Stardew and it doesn't have the variety of different townsfolk like AC (only seen merchants move in) so it's a weird unwelcome middle-ground. Way too much grind and no real engagement or motivation makes it worth the time investment.

If you love animal crossing, this is that (maybe not as cute graphics), but offers a lot more to do in terms of mechanics and gameplay.

Its the exact same story, with most of your time and money early on goes into convincing visitors to stay, expanding your town, unlocking and upgrading certain features.

On top of harvesting, mining, crafting, farming and cooking, there's weapon crafting for combat. There's a wide variety of animals to hunt and even aggressive/alpha boss animals to fight. And there's animal handling, to provide certain materials such as eggs, milk, wool, and even to use as a mount. There's vehicles (animal mounts, boats, motorcycles, gliders), which comes in handy since the world is pretty large and takes some time to explore on foot.

There's not as much customization in terms of floor tiles, clothing, building/furniture aesthetics, but maybe it's because I haven't unlocked it yet. Or it's still coming, this game is only in early access but already offers and does so much really well.

It's a wonderful labor of love game. I did have to find a mod to make the deep mines peaceful because I wanted a game I could just chill too and not have to worry about being swarmed by mobs underground. It would be nice if that was a setting I could toggle instead of downloading a mod for, but besides that this is a great game!

Almost 20 hours in - and I'll stop my gameplay here as there isn't a more patronizing gameplay experience available currently on the PC. I understand this is still in development, but I must point out the main issues:

- Combat: Quite possibly the least engaging combat mechanics created in several years. I'm not asking for an isometric Dark Souls, but the bat enemy is among the most baffling design choices ever made. Aiming a 2-dimensional attack on an enemy which darts about and attacks in 3-dimensions is every bit as tedious as it sounds. Not to mention the perma-repeating attack patterns of the crocs / every other enemy, it's so painfully simple.

- Fishing: every fish pulls away from the bait at the same rate / pattern. So fishing is entirely a rinse / repeat / robotic process. To randomise this would be so trivial, how has this functionality been allowed to be written like this? There's zen gameplay and then there's whatever this is.

- Until today, mouse forward/back would alter the camera angle / player perspective. But now, it zooms in/out of the player. Is this a bug, or a feature? Why go out of your way to make this change. More baffling design choices.

- Can you define somewhere, clearly, that when you faint + revive, all of your gear gets hit with damage? Almost everything else is defined, except this rather important detail. The choices of omission made in this game are genuinely baffling.

- Inventory management. Look at how terraria / minecraft lets you stack / auto-stack to chest / pick ONE item from a stack of x. The very bare minimum has been done here - and this is not good enough considering how much time you spend in the inventory screens / your chests. More endless clicking. More tedium.

- No automation whatsoever. So much scope for more interesting automation mechanics. If I have to saw 300 woods and cook 200 apples and 10 fish, that is my real-life afternoon written off right-clicking on the saw mill 300 times, then the BBQs 210 times, to make this happen one-at-a-time. Painstaking, devastating, and again, not-zen gameplay.

Stardew valley is Zen. Animal crossing is Zen. Terraria can be incredibly Zen.

This, is an own-brand local-repo end-of-semester-project knockoff designed to do the bare minimum, and proceeds to patronises you instead. It's great at the start. but you -will- hit that stage where you will feed your 600th gum-wood into the saw mill, and find yourself wishing you had spent your gameplay hours doing -literally- anything else.

A cute little life management sim that borrows a lot from animal crossing, but adds plenty of its own ideas. The map is fairly large with several different biomes, each with its own ecology that changes throughout the seasons. There's so many little things to do with few restrictions that it feels like your own personal playground.

There's a lot to chew on before you start to feel the effects of early access. However you inevitably start to notice the visual glitches and shared dialogue between the NPCs. The game also does a bad job of communicating some of its systems and you often have to rely on trial and error to figure them out, sometimes resulting in costly mistakes.

Overall I'm really enjoying the game and can't wait until its all polished up.

As a purveyor of fine life sim games (Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley, Harvest Moon, Graveyard Keeper, etc) I would have to rank Dinkum near the top. There's tons to do, you can spend entire in-game days fishing, searching for buried treasure, or stabbing turkeys to death.

February 15, 2023
At the time of writing this, the game is still early access and I know the dev is working hard on the next update, which I'm assuming will address the typos and grammatical errors that pop up throughout the dialogue and make my eye twitch involuntarily. 

There's also the issue of the dialogue menus being difficult to navigate. If you're like me, you have a habit of button-mashing through dialogue to get to the dialogue options (let's chat, I have something for you, etc). Doing this leads to the first dialogue option being pressed, which drives me insane and wastes time that would be better spent getting eaten by crocodiles or chased by rabid birds. After 20 hours of gameplay, I have not been able to break the habit.

Please Mr Dev, make it so I can't accidentally press the first dialogue option due to my own impatience. This is ingrained in my vidya gaming, my almost-40 year old brain can't rewire for this. It's my only real complaint, the game is otherwise fantastic and I'm looking forward to shirking my real-life responsibilities so my town can grow big and strong.

Fun game, bought a copy for my "non-gamer" wife (who does play Animal Crossing on the Switch). Nice little relaxing, social game with a heavy influence from Animal Crossing.  Easy enough "survival mechanics" added that either extends how much you can do per day (energy and hunger) and combat / hunting. I've outrun pretty much all hostile animals and I think you would really have to go out of your way to put yourself in any real danger - certainly in the early game. 

Simple but engaging. Bit of farming and fishing with mining and crafting. While good graphics, the colour palette between the game environment and the User Interface could do with some changes (it can be quite difficult to see white markers on yellow background for example). Good game (some would even suggest it's "Fair Dinkum" :)
Love it, relaxing and fun to be creative.

I'm in love! It's kinda like some parts of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley/Story of Seasons type games. It's got lots of stuff to do. I hope eventually some things get added like more intractable furniture in the world like chairs and stuff you can interact with so I can interact with my town a little bit more. I think some things could be reworked like the sounds for hitting stuff like stones as well as the animations for certain things. One thing that comes to mind is catching bugs, your character immediately jumps forward and shows of the catch in an unnatural way I guess. This is a really dumb nitpick, maybe I'm crazy. 
The map is... decent, as to say it could be a lot better. The world generation gets the job done but there's lots of annoying little useless continents on it, like the map gets unnaturally split into different islands and chunks because the rivers don't really form well, like I have lots of rivers cutting what would be really cool pretty land into awkward slices of land and sand that can't be really used for anything honestly.
The game has been really enjoyable and I've gotten a lot of fun and enjoyment out of it already and I'm barely scratching the surface of stuff to do in the game.

This is really an excellent and fun co-op farmcore game. I've seen it described as primarily an Animal Crossing/Stardew melding but I think it's honestly more Animal Crossing meets Minecraft with some Stardew elements thrown in. To me it seems like all of the best elements of each of those games combined, and the co--op so far has been pretty seamless and easy to manage. 

Unlike ACNH, where friends can only visit and marginally assist with your building and progression, the Dinkum co-op mode allows visitors to sleep on the island and help with day to day tasks more like Minecraft co-op. The fishing takes a little bit to get the hang of--I did not find the simplistic explanation from youtubers helpful at all, but once you figure out the rhythm of it, it's very satisfying as a minigame. Some of the positioning of RDR2, the tension reeling play of New World, and the bobber mechanics of ACNH. 

NPCs and town progression works closely to ACNH, so players familiar with that game will have an easier time intuiting what to hold on to while progressing and what to vendor for quick cash. 

I am just really loving it a lot and would recommend it to families and friends who want a chill multiplayer town building game to enjoy together.

I do like this game a lot. It's fun, it's entertaining, and it's like Animal Crossing except things try to kill you. I have three main complaints though and they're mostly mechanical.

1) I play the game using switch controllers. it makes it easier but none of the buttons match the commands so it was a huge trial and error to figure out what button did what. Not sure if its the same for all controllers but it did make things a little challenging. 

2) You can still get attacked while in the menus/ journals. It doesnt pause your time or creatures so you could pull up the journal, thinking its paused and come back 10 minutes later and a whole day passed or you got your nards chewed off by a croc and you're dead. The only way to pause is to pull up the actual pause in the settings and do it that way. 

3) The only way to save the game is to go to sleep and have a new day start. So either you finish out your day and call it good or stop where you are to exit and loose the whole day and have to start over. Its annoying for those times when you want/ need to stop in the middle of a day and cant save it where you are without loosing all your progress or have to sleep early just to save it and not loose anything.

Write a review for Dinkum
Please describe what you liked or disliked about this game and whether you recommend it to others.
Please remember to be polite and follow the Rules and Guidelines.

Most of my current play time for this game is from July 2022 when it was first released in Early Access.  I played with a small group of friends, and despite some early access jank we had a great time and didn't encounter any roadblocks or head-scratching design/gameplay moments.  In fact, coming from Animal Crossing: New Horizons, the integration of multiplayer and designing and building our town together was a breath of fresh air.  Things just worked.

The only irritation was that there is a bit of random grind with some rare key items that could only be found by digging up treasure.

After our initial ~50 hours of play, we decided to come back to it after it's received a few content updates.

From the first few hours, I can say this game is just plain fun. It's sort of as if Minecraft had a baby with Animal Crossing, I guess.

One thing I don't like about Dinkum (and why drawing a comparison to Minecraft might be a bad choice) is how very little you can dig into the ground, like, I think max depth is 5 blocks below sea level and you can't dig into cliff sides to make caves and such. All in all, a great game.

Yet the thought that went into the gathering of resources, creation of more advanced ones and the fighting system is something you really need to think about before you dive in head first. Not meant in a bad way at all, it is fun to have a game that challenges you to think before you act.

To simplify the game, it is Australian Animal crossing x stardew valley. However, the fishing system is annoying and difficult for no reason. It is not relaxing like AC fishing, more towards SV. It's like a 1 second time frame for you to click or else the fish goes away. I just find it extremely frustrating. Not just that, the farming is stupid. You have to worry about birds and kangaroos eating away your crops. If you had 10 crops, with no scarecrow, expect one or zero crops remain. I wish the chances of my crops getting eaten wasn't that high. Sure, I will make a scarecrow but the pumpkin used to make the scarecrow all got eaten. I personally think the first year is repetitive. I've been stuck in this area of unable to get more npc on my island due to constantly waiting for them to come back and have their heart only increasing a quarter or so. I can't expand my town nor go mining because I haven't unlocked certain crafting plans/npc. I enjoy this game but it's frustrating and boring to play sometimes.

Keep up the great work.

          - A bucket for water (so we dont have to dig from the ocean into the island to make a water spring or a

             other players to, and the holes in the soil make me really uncomfortable so maybe change the way it 
             looks?)
          - more than 4 people can join + more visitor houses 
          - more interactive options with npc's
               - npc's can accept gifts

               - more npc's ask to buy things off of you
               - relationship + marry npc's
               - sally can do makeup
          - design clothing
          - recharchable items (dirt printer etc.) dont break when reaching 0%
          - buy multiple from johns (like ore or tools)
          - plates as furniture (be able to cook food and place it on them)
          - furniture spacing is changed (furniture can be put together closer)
          - more decorative things (furniture, garden, town stuff)
               - tea set furniture
               - fish tanks/insect tanks for ourselves 
          - character has a bigger appetite (appetite is dependant on what food you eat)
          - lawn mower is easier to control (mows 4 fields at once not just one)
          - More things to get from Franklyn
                - bigger bombs (break bigger rocks)
                - more tools (ore detector, fossil detector, etc)
          - higher chance of getting wires / or npc to buy those things off
          - more island area (snow biom, etc, maybe somewhere to travel)
          - more fruit options
          - mine two floors where it gets harder
                - bigger bosses
                - more minerals
          - more animals (cats, flamingo, peacock)
          - more control over dogs (whistle, commands)
          - house can have rooms or be bigger (guest houses aswell)
          - be able to move the docs or customize it
          - bridge size adjustable (1-10 blocks wide and length bigger)
          - liscense to increase health or stamina
          - minigames to play with friends ingame
          - round fences/hedges
          - backpacks
i hope you dont think that this list is a list telling you the flaws of the game, its just a list made by 10 people on what they would like in the game.

What a fantastic game! You earn your money. It's not just given to you. It has Animal Crossing aspects and design. However, you aren't always stuck at some point with nothing to do. Just get the game, on sale or not, you won't regret it either way.

This is already an amazing game, and the creator is still adding things to it. It's similar to games like Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, but with an Australian feel. There's even a museum you can unlock to donate fish, bugs, and critters to. So, it's perfect for people who enjoy collections.

Pros:
-There is a lot to unlock and you can build pretty much anywhere.
-Money is pretty easy to come by in the game. It gets even easier the further you get into the game
-A lot of the animals are cute, and it is easy to get your friendship up with your farm animals.
-Vehicles can be unlocked, making travel across the island pretty quick.
-There are books that can be unlocked for fish and bugs that can make it pretty easy to find the ones you haven't caught yet, or just locate one you need for a side quest.
-For the most part, the game is pretty relaxing. Combat is the only time it isn't, but you really don't have to fight anything if you don't want to.
-The creator is still making improvements to the game and taking feedback into consideration. So, that's always a plus.

Cons:
-I've noticed that if I play for a while, spawns on my island for bugs, fish, and creatures seems to plummet. It's easy enough to fix by exiting to desktop and reopening the game.
-The villager quests can get pretty repetitive, whether it is on a bulletin board, or just a daily request. It's to be expected with these kinds of games, but why do so many people need me to catch flies for them?
-I haven't seen a way to move water to make a pond or anything. I have managed to make one by digging a path from the ocean to where I wanted a pond, but it was a bit of a hassle. I would love to see a tool like the dirt printer for water, or even just a water bucket or hose to move water.
-I don't really like that the people that move to the island only have their shops. They don't have houses. With all of the space for building, I would love to have a house for each of them too. This way I can have residential and shopping districts and make the town feel even more alive.

Overall, there is already a ton to do in this game, and the creator is adding more. So, if you love games full of crafting and building, I would highly recommend this game.

We keep it to friends only and play as a family.  I get motion sick easily from games, but I can play this one because I am able to choose how fast or slow my character moves.  It keeps my family's interest because there is enough variety of building a town, projects and quests to be done, and enough challenge to suit all of our various tastes.
This is a fun game to play as a family.  It is a fun town builder, simple enough for almost anyone to play.  Low system requirements make it playable on a laptop or older desktop.

Some things that I found while gaming:
Most of these are spoilers so read at your own caution, and is more or less a complain/improvement list. Some of these are addressed in Official discord.
- At this point, with the current mechanics I don't see much replayability potential.
- Singleplayer =150 fps, mp with 1person = 70 fps. After building a bit = 34 fps at certain spots.
- view/render distance is sort of limited, even with maxed out settings.
- slight direction adjustment on with keyboard+ mouse is very hard
- default minimap zoom is to close, there are QoL mods for this.
- your map is tied to your character. want to regenerate map, make new char( and all that comes with it)
- multiplayer progression is only for host, and only host can progress buildings. That is, host has to get 2/5 stars with NPC for it to move in. All Clients have no purpose to do so other than random blueprints or rewards, because the NPC seems to be tied to the map. Same for statistics of town only counts from host. As client you are more of a visitor with building rights and not much more progression wise ( you can progress your licenses tho)
- when fishing and casting line, you can adjust left/right, but no way to tell how much you have adjusted, the face of char seems to be looking a lot different angle than where the cast lands. Sometimes its 90 degree.
-in multiplayer, client using chairs/bed and host not using them will desync client occasionally requiring to restart game.

[spoiler]
- silo holds 200, but i have to click 200 times to fill it... why not hold to fill it, or sell 200 units bag.
- when harvesting trees, requires to click every tree to get the fruits on the ground then click again to collect them. Now you can hold and vacuum all fruits around by walking but you cant do that with trees, continious tree harvesting, same goes for large field. lots of clicking. this could be improved.
- no batch crafting. Want 200 nails? click 1 recipe and wait, click 1 recipe and wait, click and wait...
- when there is a row of trees, the camera is above the trees and i cant see which tree im clicking so i end up with half harvested trees, either above solution, or first person camera.
- when mining/chopping and aiming at the deposit/tree it will switch sideways 1 block and attack the wild animal if there is one. I have no intention harming doggos, now i have to slaughter it before it howls.
- the guitar does not always work, sometimes i have to spam it for half a minute.
- interacting with boat, the interaction area is very small, when fishing its very hard to start pedalin boat again because there is no precise controls. Waterscooter is a lot easier.
- game is ok for first play-through, but once you reach midgame(year 2?), you have more money than you know how to spend it.
- you need to do favors for residents/NPC to acquire blueprints... i got spinwheel in year 2 summer.
- favor /mission recipes are not on par with item requested. Bring me 30k worth fish and I will pay you 1k dinks.. LOL
- Sometimes NPC asks for things like cherry???( special holiday item)
- all seasons last 28 days,day 01 in new season you can still harvest last season veggy, but day 02, all your field turns to dead,including fertilizer, so you lose fertilizer, but this is not issue once you captured 50 roos and farm their poo.
- tractor is eh, Australian? it goes wrong direction in reverse,like any other machine in game.
- game it self lacks depth( for replay) and complexity for processing. Harvest,sell. thats about it. You got to buy seeds from NPC 99 at a time, trough 5 dialog boxes for each attempt.
- more than half of the food is not avail at first year ish, because you cant grow potat,onion,beans etc, and when you can they are not relevant anymore because game mechanics are quite easy/no need for special foods cus you got chainsaw,or drill. So deff some balance could be done there.
- there is build height limit, such as radio tower has to be on sea level as it is already at max height, building at higher altitude will yield you interesting results...
- chargable things dissapear once they discharge, such as drill, chainsaw,compactor, etc they also cost 300k ish which seems a lot at start, but you get lots of dinks from selling veggy/crops
- the special guy on ship that buys bulk only appears in rainy days which is fine, but you need bank, which is fine,but you need 1 mil in bank... And you can only sell for dinkums, and buy for license points. So not sure why the 1mil requirment. Once you have 1 mil you already have means to make tons of money and selling for double price in bulk is pointless cus there is no use for the millions you acquire.

[/spoiler]

Right now, I can't recommend it. 

It's been a ton of grinding and I can get money pretty easily, but I don't have something I'm shooting for. Once I'm used to the gameplay loop, I'm left thinking, "why am I still playing?" 

Ultimately I think it boils down to me not caring about the citizens. I make a new building when I can and force myself to talk to them so I can get hearts, but I just really don't care about what they have to say. They all have cookie cutter personalities. For example, the shopkeeper is all about work and money. Boring.

I think another part of the problem is going into the game trying to maximize what you are doing every single day. It leads to really long days where you are cooking at midnight for 10 real minutes because it takes no energy and you don't pass out. So why do it when the clock is ticking during the day? The days just feel too long.

Overall just an eh game. I'm hoping it gets more interesting content and QOL improvements down the road. It goes on the shelf for a while.

Combat is clunky and makes no sense when using certain weapons verse certain animals, economy isn't balanced and everything is one-click-tasked. meaning you must put one log to cut into one plank. there is no multi-crafting. (if you want to get 500 planks to build then you'll be here a while. same for all other crafting). 

 and there are many exploits that break the game. 

being invincible, unlimited items and money etc. not to mention if you reach max cash (2.1 billion) your money will go negative and you lose everything. their discord server does read your bug reports, but they do not work on them. most of the gamers here are young, so they do not understand what a game should be like. Early access or not, the developer needs to focus on bug fixes, the newest patch he is releasing has zero bug fixes and only additions to the game. eventually he will be overburdened by bugs and the game will be unplayable.

Love it!!! I was a bit put off at first by the art style(I thought the square heads were ugly, sorry, they've grown on me since, though). I finally decided to give it a shot and it is so much fun. I can absolutely see the inspiration taken from both animal crossing, with the citizens' voices, and bug catching, and filling the museum, and creating your own little town, and stardew valley, with the farming, and animal rearing, and day cycles, and mines(I hope the creator does not tire of these sorts of comments, I truly mean them as compliments). With almost 90 hours in the game, I still feel like I've barely scratched the surface of what there is available to explore. The game gives you plenty of goals to work towards, but often I find myself creating my own tasks to complete. It's fun to give yourself a little to-do list of things you want to do before it gets too late and you run out of energy, but I almost never feel like I NEED to rush to get things done. Very, very, very fun casual game. I love getting creative control over the entire island. I would've appreciated a little explanation of how the mines work before going down there the first few times, but a lot of the fun in the game is found in slowly uncovering all the little secrets of the island, so that's not /really/ a criticism. I'm struggling to come up with any criticisms of the game, other than that I wish there was a way to move the camera around my character without having to hold down shift all the time on mouse and keyboard. I'm pretty picky and I love putting in my two cents, so, coming from me, that is very high praise. This game is clearly a labor of love and I very much look forward to what is yet to come!!!!!!!

If you like Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, this is your Australia version of that joy.
Game is fun casual town management game, with farming, and light dungeon combat elements.
It's not really hard either, money is fairly easy to mass produce (giant orchard farms) though it takes a little time to get started proper.
There are issues with it as its still fairly early, seasons don't do much visually but have a major impact on fish, bugs, and what you can farm so I've caught myself trying to plan winter crops in summer.
Accuracy to Australia is a little off, while most of the larger wild life will try to kill you, bugs that should be an issue aren't I'd like to see some aggressive Spiders that can poison you and either sap max health/stamina or knock you out. Also moving some things to more natural environments (I'm told you should be finding huntsman spiders in caves instead of in the bush lands per my Australian friends.)

Multi-player is interesting as it's character importing, but seems if you don't save(sleep) and log off immediately, you can loose character progress (saw a friend loose a bunch of money after logging out from my world after selling stuff. This makes sense but would like an alert reminder "Hey if you leave now you'll loose all of today's progress."

Over all I would recommend this game as something worth playing especially with friends but be ready for the occasional weird jarring thing too.

If you look up information from other people it does help. I just have to figure out how to set up a town. I have found out that trying to get other people to live there is very hard. I also found out you can't delete other people you created in the game.

Dinkum is a 3D Stardew Valley / Minecraft hybrid.

Looking at the average score most people really like this game. Personally there are things in the basic gameplay that I don't like and it sort of ruins the game for me.

For one I spend half of my time running (slowly) back to my tent because I'm exhausted. Then I wake up, run back to those palm trees, cut down a few more and again run back to my tent to sleep. I really don't understand why this is necessary or fun. This is the biggest issue for me.

There are smaller issues like quests I can't do. Storage units that need to be organized like having a virtual sock drawer. No queues for production (at least at the point where I am). Small inventory that does get bigger as I buy upgrades but come on why can actual full size logs stack but butterflies can't? Also clumsy combat is something we see all the time in other games like this but.. why? If combat is a bit part of the game why make it so annoying?

Personally I don't mind having to grind materials a bit or hunt something a few times before I'm able to make progress but the gameplay has to feel fun. Dinkum is kinda fun, kinda not. I suppose since it's early access things can still change.

I'm thinking this game will appeal to some like they're handing out buckets for free and that's fine. Personally I'm not 100% convinced yet. Still Dinkum is a good game but perhaps not for everyone. I don't regret buying it but we'll see if I keep playing for a lot longer than this 3,5hrs.

Dinkum is a cutesy game that looks a bit like animal crossing while the core gameplay is that more like Stardew Valley but a tad less dark which I personally wish would change but I am of the type that likes more realism and such in games. That aside Dinkum is a fun and addicting game with an extremely active Dev who flat out kicks ass. This Dev appears to carefully monitor his bug discussion channel as his frequent hot fixes reflect major common issues players are having. For a one man team, that is pretty damn impressive. For an early access title, it has a considerable amount to do and very few severe bugs. I have only found a few that were either funny (like an npc hovering slightly) or a minor annoyance such as not being able to unequip (but you could swap it) a hat unless you restart the game. One of my favorite things about the game is being able to not only capture animals, but load them on a vehicle and airbus them back to base. That's just sick to me!
        The multiplayer works well and adds a very nice element to the game as when you are starting out there is a lot lot to be done and having a few spare hands makes this more manageable. 

I think the game is very worth the price and I am looking forward to seeing what else the Dev puts in. 
Also, I think the character Marvin is meant to be the Diabeetus guy Wilford Brimley.

A few things that I wish the developer would see and patch: 
-when you tag spots in the mine and then leave the mine, those spots stay on regular map. I have to manually untag each one (I tag my mine spots to remember which areas are cleared so I don't run in circles)
-make watering the crops count towards farm points. so far farming is the only skill that is under 20 with everything else being above 50
-there is a glitch after remodeling a house that either the wall or floor item in your inventory continues to "collect" stuff if you "use" it (if you have painted the walls from regular to let's say dainty, the regular wall will be dropped into your inventory and if you left click it, it will show it "collecting" that item over and over again).
A hidden gem

Dinkum is a fantastic relaxing game with some mechanics like growing crops, recruiting villagers, and laying out your town.  There is a progression system of sorts using licences you buy to gain access to better equipment and tools.  The game overall could use from further development to add more of everything that is already in the game.  The game is great but the minimal amount of villagers and things do make it feel slightly empty.

This is a decent experience. There is a decent variety of stuff to collect and do at the start of the game. It also feels very detailed because of the characters that you can get to move into town as well as the myriad of clothing and furniture items you can get.

The problem is that once time goes on, you really get stuck in a quite boring and lackluster loop of talking to everyone in your town and bringing them fish and butterflies without really making a lot of progress elsewhere. This is made worse further by not having the most used options further up in the conversation tree as well as not being able to navigate those with the keyboard. There is also just less and less to do the further you progress. What's also bad is that the sense of exploration is completely absent in this game, although the genre really lends itself to it. The map is completely open from the start, which is fine, but no matter where the biomes are, they feel very similar to each other and there are no secrets or mechanics to find or learn. 
There are also plentiful bugs to find, like houses that you can't enter after having them moved. 

In summary this seems like the basis for a charming game, but right now it could really use some bugfixing, a rebalancing and rethinking of progression and the main gameplay loop, and some late game content.

Yes it is very cutesy, but that makes it somewhat hard to get mad at the tassie devils and crocs. When they chew up all your tools and steal your money while leaving you face planted in the Australian outback...all alone with your regrets. There is a sense of loss and progression is set back. More than enough reason to not go out into the outback unprepared.

The hardened adventurer wipes away the tears, forges new tools, and continues making the dream a reality until they have a sprawling town with super nice neighbors and amazing shops which all leaves you with a huge sense of accomplishment.

Fun and simple. You may say it is similar to animal crossing, and for all intent of review that is what I'll be basing my review off of. Dinkum has many things some more mature players would enjoy more than if they were to play animal crossing, such as fishing, which is very much different in mechanics, and is actually quite enjoyable and a challenge. Trading is similar, but still very satisfying. Combat is relaxed but very interesting, as instead of having not many combatants, you really have to watch out for the wildlife around the game, and are able to hunt, capture, and do various things with them. These are some of the features, but overall I give it about a 9/10 for the sake of graphics being just OK, but the features are very much more than expected, such as vehicles, metal detectors, and other fun building quarks that lack in many other games like this. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys animal crossing, or likes to play relaxing survival/community games. Especially because of the multiplayer functions.

Updating my review because this game deserves it:
Dinkum is by all accounts an amazingly fun game. If you like Animal Crossing then this game, is at its core very similar. However it expands on ideas far better and makes new activities beyond just planting fruit trees. Sure you can still go around and collect and plant fruit trees, but you can also craft those fruits into food to manage your stamina and health. OH, a health bar? You're not just avoiding bee's, Hunting animals like crocodiles and fire-breathing... things? That's another occupation you can take up in this game to make money. Mining? Even has a small randomly generated mine to use that resets every day. Farming? 100% A valid way to make money and progress? Wanna just do all the things!? Go for it. 

The game also encourages you to expand your town, or in my case, a prison compound, wherein everyone that comes in gets lured in by my kind acts towards them only to be trapped for me to exploit their businesses to make copious amounts of DINKS (money). In all honesty, designing, decorating, and building up your town is an amazingly fun and rewarding experience in this game. Befriending the colorful cast of characters including literally Steve Irwin is amazing. Worth noting, that I learned this is very "Australian" in its inspiration though as a Japanese man who lives under a rock of anime and video games 99% of the references are lost on me. Like needing a liscence for literally everything. Apparently fairy bread is delicious in real life as well. (Dinkum official cookbook when?) 

Early game to end game progression is super fun- however subsequent play thrus wherein you know what you're doing and what to save early as you'll need it soon are super fun as well. The entire game feels surprisingly complete, well put together and fleshed out for something state to be in early access.

I do recommend this game because it is well made and does what it sets out to do, but I have a few suggestions to ease the actual playing of the game.

1. The save system. I have a busy life and sometimes cannot finish a day out in order to save. It's 2023 and it just makes so much more sense to save whenever you need to. I have cut short many days from this alone. 

2. The crafting. I find it clunky. My preference would be to allow the player to craft an item without having to craft the intermediate ingredients. For instance, it would ease the burden if instead of having to craft a fire pit and then craft a furnace, if I had the resources needed to do both I could just click to craft the furnace. So much easier.

If you liked "Animal Crossing: New Horizons", and you like the farming options from farm sims like "Stardew Valley" or "Harvest Moon". Not to mention, very chill Australian themes and style... You're probably going to like Dinkum. 

Most of the game mechanics themselves are very reminiscent of Animal Crossing, such as building up a little town, collecting tickets to unlock everything (like inventory slots, access to better tools, or authorization to use a vehicle or go hunting), a museum, villiger quests, and even the voices are right there with you. The game day is its own fixed length (20-ish minutes? 30-ish?) though, and like in Stardew, isn't tied to your system clock so a day can go by pretty fast.

Unlike in Stardew though; once you hit midnight (2 am in Stardew), you don't just pass out. Your clock display just changes to 'Late', you move a bit slower, and your stamina and max stamina bar gets drastically reduced. BUT providing you have enough food, you can theoretically play 'Late' for hours. I've not fully tested just straight-up blacking out that way, but I have spent a pretty long time cooking up meals and snacks after midnight. And even doing some mining, though I ran out of good food much faster that way. Better to just go to bed and continue whatever project you were on, the next day.

There's not a ton of combat in the game... But, you do have to defend yourself from Crocs, Cassowaries, Sharks, and a few other things; but even that's pretty chill. It's slightly more advanced than Stardew Valley mines, but only in that you have to actually try to dodge attacks. Fortunately, all your foes have obvious tells, and you can even deal with some of the tougher ones, with something basic like a scythe.

I only have a few complaints so far in the game... One is that there is tool decay (like I said, VERY reminiscent of New Horizons) but at least I understand that. In a small world with renewable resources, it doesn't hurt to encourage a player to go out and get more resources. I've just never liked tool decay in any game I've ever played that had it.

The other thing, is that there's no easy way to pause. There's no hotkey for it. There's no main-screen button for it. It doesn't even pause while in menus, or when you "Tab Out" or de-focus the game. Technically there IS a way to pause the game and prevent it from advancing time, and marching towards midnight... but it's hidden behind TWO menu options, and doesn't even pause while in THAT menu, until you hit the actual button. I think that MIGHT be tied to the fact that it has multiplayer capabilities. But I've not messed around enough with that to 'get' it. It should be a thing whenever in single player.

Who knows, it IS early access, maybe they'll add it in a future update. But frankly that doesn't matter ALL that much, because it's a very fun and chill game you can unwind with, if that's what you wish. If you ever wanted to play something like Animal Crossing, but on your own Steam account (instead of having to buy an entirely new console that you can't afford *looking at own budget*) this title is certainly worth picking up. You'll get your money's worth. :)

[b]10/10 Highly Recommend![/b]

I'd say this is probably the most invested game time I've ever had, and I really enjoyed it as it has similarities to playing [i]Animal Crossing[/i], [i]Harvest Moon[/i], [i]Stardew Valley[/i], and [i]Minecraft[/i] combined. I would really like to look forward to their development in terms of story progression and NPC tasks that are not repetitive. And for the time being, there are still more things to be fixed, like zooming in on characters so that they can take a photo close-up (more like a selfie) and improving the landscape mode camera to emphasize your town further. And aside from the current "[b]Austrailia[/b]" theme, I hope we'll get more maps to experiment with different types of town building vibes, as well as more animals to discover!

And their growing community on Discord is [b]*chefs kiss*[/b] the most responsive people. They all take the feedback seriously and are more willing to improve your experience. So far I haven't really tried co-op mode as I have always been a solo gamer, but I think it is much better playing it with a friend as you can do a lot of teamwork when working on your growing town (if you're not looking into the progression side of your own character). So much so, I have seen many creative players doing experiments to make their towns vibrant, which is very engaging for me as I also want to make a functional and aesthetically pleasing town. Kudos to JB for making this game such a wonderful experience!

Australian animal crossing

I spent a long time trying to find a game in a very specific niche. I wanted something like Animal Crossing, but with more to do. I wanted a PC version of Farmville. I wanted something like Stardew Valley that wasn't 2D. Something where I could take my time and design a layout with decorations, different types of paths, etc. DINKUM. Dinkum is literally all of this and more. I've played almost 50 hrs now and there are STILL things I haven't even unlocked yet. There is so much to do, but it's never overwhelming. It's a really relaxing game overall, with just the right amount of customization options, crafting recipes, colorful characters, and progression lines/skill trees. 

No matter what kind of mood you're in, there's something waiting to be enjoyed on your island. One morning you might wake up and water all your crops, feed the animals, milk your vombat, sheer your pleep, and walk along the beach collecting shells to sell to John. Another day you might spend the entire day running around the tropics trying to catch a Fly because your relationship with Raine is almost a full five-hearts and a Fly is what she asked you for this morning. Or you might go underground and spend the day mining, fighting off bats and Glow-crocs trying to find enough iron to finish building your windmill. The sheer variety of activities is just amazing, and the fact that the ENTIRE game was developed by one person makes it even more incredible.

My whole family loves, Dinkum. They also love Animal Crossing. This game is a cross between Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley but leaning more towards Animal Crossing gamestyle. They've started to play Dinkum more than Animal Crossing as they say, "there is more to do." They reference "more to do" as interacting with animals, fighting enemies, interactive daily NPC tasks, deep cave mining and several others that keep a day in Dinkum never the same.

The occasional fighting in game is complex enough there is a learning curve and adults will find themselves with a slight challenge, but basic enough kids can eventually figure it out (very young kids might get frustrated). 

Our biggest complaint is the game only saves if you end the day and sleep. We wish there was another way you could save up to that very moment in the day. Stamina drains fairly quickly and wish there was a way to permanently craft items to increase base amount each day. I can see a lot more animals and interacting with the environment being implemented that would really make exploring even more exciting. Also animal feed seems to disappear sometimes when placed in feeder or inventory. "Where did all my feed go?!"

On the Store Page it says partial controller support, but I've only run into one issue while changing my keybindings. All gameplay with controller has been fluid and responsive. It would also be nice if it was compatible with Linux.

Crafting and gathering is fun and not super tedious but enough work has to be put forth to complete some quests/tasks before the end of the day (how fast the day goes by could be considered a negative). The tasks seem overall rewarding, depending on your location, and current exploration into that aspect of the game. Fishing also takes a small learning curve but once you figure it out the time it takes to catch fish pays off in the beginning of the game at least. 

A huge positive is there are no loading screens!! I can go in/out of a house/shop and it is instant! Thank you!

The local multiplayer has been flawless but I do hope this continues to grow and be developed. Going from your friends to your island on the fly would be nice. It is great to be able to transfer items into a storage area in Main base that carry over to your game/map if your inventory becomes full. I like that your single player map can also be your multiplayer.  No need to start fresh just because you want to play with others--just host your game and let them join that previously single player game you were on. 

I have bought multiple copies of this game and will continue to buy more as I feel it is a great social game for any friends/family that want to play single or multiplayer. Even in Early Access this game has plenty to keep you occupied for hours. The developer seems to be very open and communicates well with community. Gives me hope this game will be a top game throughout the years to come.
The game is super fun and relaxing. well worth the small cost.

Dinkum is everything Animal Crossing needed to evolve into. 

I remember playing hours of Animal Crossing for the DS and eventually reaching my saturation point from a lack of adventure and stuff to do. I understand AC has always included the chill vibe but as the Switch iteration dropped I found almost no joy in playing it like I had the past ones. It felt like Nintendo didnt put enough into the game as an emerging title to the collection. Sure there was some barebones construction stuff but, quicker than before, I found myself bored and not in a charmed happy-to-be-a-chill-villager way.

That's rather specific but that is where Dinkum comes in. It's only been a couple of weeks but by myself, and with my partner, I have found my love for this style of game once more. The myriad activities that one does are infused within one another. A day decorating and a day fighting radioactive crocodiles in self-placed mine both have equal place and measure in Dinkum and the lack of pressure from an overarching massive plot (like AC) provide an experience that will make both sweatlords (Think Stardew min/max) and casual gamers alike happy.

So; what can you do?
-You can trap an animal then throw four of his caged animal friends on your Jet Ski and ride around as they await being sent off for research.

-You can have basically Steve Irwin water your pumpkins

-You can fish while your partner can't (Love you! <3)

-You can recycle pants. PANTS!

-You can get a ruby out just before the radioactivity murders your face.

-You can build a building for a bunch of wonderful ingrates that won't hang out with you until you help them with stuff. Though they might teach you how to make a fountain and honestly I don't know what I would be without that fountain. I think about it at night.

-Speaking of night the Late night mechanic that restricts energy but doesn't force you to end a day is legit and I love it.

This game is definitely a "one-more-day" game. Definitely a game I recommend for you and your partner(s) to play together. If you don't like AC I think there is more here but there is still a barrier to this game. Pure action seekers probably would be bored but if you like a little crafting, a little building, a little fighting, a little trapping, a little hunting, and a lot of Australian chill vibes..... GET THIS GAME

DO IT

Dinkum reminds me of Harvest Moon... Even though the only thing remotely similar between the two is that you can plant and harvest crops in this game, and even THAT kind of gameplay is not similar to Harvest Moon at all (Or Story of Seasons). It's like Eco in terms of graphics and how you can terraform the land, but saying they are similar is like saying cheese looks like butter. They both are yellow and made from the same thing but are used for different purposes.
What I am trying to say here is that Dinkum feels familiar, and at the same time it isn't. It gives you this very simple looking dish, but when you've taken your first bite you realized it is something completely high level and new to your palate. It triggers nostalgia, but it gives you a brand new experience.
If you are into Stardew Valley, well, sorry but Dinkum offers little content at the moment (But is entirely playable and enjoyable at its current state) and if you are into city building or town management games, the smashing of both of these genre of gameplay is something pleasant and very enjoyable indeed. For the farming simulator players out there, go try this one out!

One of the most relaxing, enjoyable and fun games I've ever played. Wasn't sure what to expect when I bought this game, I liked Animal Crossing on the Switch for a day or two to kill time but it soon got boring. This game however has everything that you'd wish animal crossing had from farming crops and animals to vehicles and a camera you can actually control from the body view. I've got 15 hours playtime so far and I plan on making it a hell of a lot more.

Awesome game, really good if you're looking for an 'alternative' to Stardew/Animal Crossing.

Pros:
Great multiplayer, the only downside is that your friend can't progress the island, but it's not too big of a deal since you're together. Getting money is reasonable and it took me an hour to get to 1 million dinks from 40k. Easy to progress and the mobs are not too difficult to fight. The game is very cute, the mobs look nice, and the overall game play is satisfying. Lots of customisation, though I'd like more urban choices, so I could make the island into a city. 

Cons: Mostly glitches.
Couple of glitches with boats and fishing and rendering, but nothing game breaking. I have been flung halfway across the map with the jetski, lost my rowboat due to uneven water rendering (was able to get it back after re-rendering the map), and had fishes turn into other fishes when they bite. It doesn't happen often and when it does it's just funny. 
John has appeared outside of the shop, and never went inside after 8 AM. He sold you stuff from outside. Fixed after sleeping. 
If you leave crates/furniture inside your tent and upgrade it to a house, they can glitch and get stuck inside.

Game aspects I personally didn't like:
Dying is a little frustrating since you loose your money and your items loose a lot of 'health'.
John has low stock, a little annoying when you're playing with others and you both need to buy something. 
You cannot craft the basic tools, you have to buy them. 
Fishing. 

Overall a solid 7.5/10 for me.

It keeps an amazing feeling of realism while also importing a wonderful feeling of mystical challenges such as glowing crocodiles and enemies. If you want a fast moving game, then (in my opinion) this probably isn't your thing. Areas that I find awkward include the way the game handles bug catching (your camera spins around and celebrates, even if you are being chased by a crocodile), how fishing works in general, tool repair (which is both a little weird, but also game unbalancing), and the UI for buying and selling isn't great. Still, I'm over 30 hours into the game and having fun.

I heard a lot of people saying the game is a crossover of games like Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing. I thought that sounded like an awesome game so I tried it out. The people were right and this game is incredibly addictive! If you like starting from scratch and slowly building up a town, meeting characters and getting wealthy this game delivers! 

The game is surprisingly in depth, with lots of little mechanics that you learn naturally the more you play. The first few days you spend exploring and gathering items, and getting familiar with your surroundings, but quickly you realise your passion and the way that you want to make money in the game. 

This game is fantastic to learn on your own, so I would recommend not to go online and learn about the "optimal" way to play. Just play at your own pace, doing the activities you enjoy.

I wish the multiplayer was true co-op, but regardless it is still very fun to play with friends, gathering resources, fishing, exploring!

Dinkum is what you get when you take some of the best parts of Animal Crossing New Horizons and Stardew Valley and put them together. It is an early access game, but it feels like a full release, I think. That being said, there are a few typos in some of the dialogue (which is pretty well documented on the Discord for Dinkum). I'd imagine that a majority of the issues will be fixed by the time the game actually is fully released. Additionally, there is a co-op in this game, which I personally haven't tried, but it sounds like it works rather well. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who has played either ACNH or Stardew (or both) and enjoyed them.

The framework for a good game is there. 
It's an enjoyabke demo but it's not worth buying at this point.

So this is actually a cross between a harvestcrossing game and Minecraft but in Australia.

Problem a: everything is super-grindy. Buying a house may put you 200k in debt. Selling a bug is 600-800.
One manually cooked meat like 1200. Day pass to the iron mine costs 25k. All you do is selling flowers and shipping animals all day. Crocodile is like 9500 per catch.
There could be an NPC who farms wood or rocks for you but you do all the work, pay for the housing and bring the materials.
Unlocking NPCs is tedious, they show up every few days and then you have to do quests several times.
Optimal would be to make a huge tree farm and boringly optimze the money income.

Problem b: unlike MInecraft this game has stamina and mandatory sleep. Paving your town with stone path is a crazy grind because you farm all that stone with your stamina. Unlike modded MC there's no machine automation at least 20 hours in. You cook single fruits or ingots by placing them manually.

There are also dozens of cosmetic clothing items which do nothing. No bonus and no armor.
Finally you spend a lot of time in the menu because the UI has issues. There's no pause button on the controller. It's hidden in the menu.
FInding a building in the wild that requires items doesn't like list those in your log, you need to screenshot it.
Oh and long walks at least until you finally unlock vehicles (way way out there).

A refreshing mix of Animal Crossing and Minecraft set on an Australian island! After I had a rough start with this game (because of some details I simply did not know and the game did not tell me) I learned to love it and simply can not put it down the last few days.
The art style is refreshing and the game content is endless; you can tend your farms, care for your animals, decorate and expand your town in you own pace, level friendships with the townsfolk, hunt, fish, catch bugs, terraform and even fly a plane later on.
I like these options a lot, since you can unlock them at your own pace so nothing gets overwhelming.
Maybe watch a few "before you start" guides and a delightful adventure awaits!
Dinkum? More like I sinkum hours into this game every day and can't stop, please send help
Like Minecraft?  Like StarDew Valley? Want to experience the dangers of Australia?  This game rocks.  Fun graphics, addictive gameplay, plenty of depth to keep you coming back.

Honestly, get it right now if you like Animal Crossing. This is not a direct copy but the inspiration is super heavy.

But one thing I will warn you: if you're a player like me who simply can't chill... consider. There will be frustration about some of the mechanics in the game. First let me explain what it means you have to chill with this game: you can't do everything in one day, you simply can't (except I can but it drives me insane) You have to think okay today I will only do fishing, tomorrow I might plant some flowers, the day after is for decorating... because you will struggle to do everything and that's the point of the game. There is NO hurry.

But that's where comes the frustration for players who can't play like that. I have to do a lot in a day. I don't want to stand in front of a grinder all day feeding it stone and wait for each one by one. It's making me insane. I hope this mechanic will be changed because it's absolute torture to craft things like that. I don't understand why can't you just drop like 10 wheat in the mill and get 10 out. What is that ruining? The game will go too fast? No it won't ruin it. I'm begging you, add bulk crafting or at least remove the waiting times like stone goes in, 2 seconds, stone comes out. Please. Maybe make it a license??

Personally in the game I have now reached a point in 57 hours that I have very little less to achieve or do... and it was fun to get here but also extremely annoying too because you get nothing fast. I'm starting to feel like I don't want to play anymore (yes it's my own fault for getting things fast) I love the game to death and will be glad to see more content added but I don't know if I would have bought it knowing it's mechanics.

But yeah. It's cute, it's fun, there's a lot to do to a point (but updated seem to be coming regularly)... overall depending on the person I absolutely will recommend this game.

As far as I can tell, this isn't anything more than just another crafting/farming game. It's very similar to animal crossing and I couldn't really find many ways where this game makes itself unique. That could of course be just because I haven't played enough. I will however not be playing anymore because there are a couple things that bugged the hell out of me.

First of all, it only saves the game when you sleep. And although I know for some games this is a perfectly sensible game-mechanic, in this game to me at least it just feels kinda annoying and restrictive.
The game gets repetitive and boring really fast. Want to make copper bars? Throw some ores in the furnace. Oh no wait, can only make 1 bar at the time. The same goes for making planks. So need to make 10 of them? Yeah be prepared, we'll be here a while, just waiting and throwing in logs in the saw machine. 1... at... a... time... YAWN.

And then there's the thing that convinced me to immediately close this game and not ever give it a try again. The fishing. Yes, you read that right, the fishing, which according to google is just easy peasy, managed to chase me away 100%. For those who think, oh I've played dozens of farming games, I'm sure it's nothing new. Yeah well, it is... Or rather, it's not intuitive. After trying a couple times, looking all over the screen for some kind of bar and just not figuring out what to do, I googled it. And turns out, when a fish bites (and it can either nibble or bite) you immediately click. If you click a second later, too bad, fish is gone.
So you click and then the fish will do it's absolute best to swim away. You have to wait. Once it calms down, you can reel it in. Until it starts trashing again. Then you let it go. Until it's calm, and then reel it in again.

Made sense, so I thought, how hard can it be right? Well as it turns out, VERY hard. Because the game isn't really giving you a lot of indicators. So you're stuck watching that fish and as soon as it turns around, let go of the mouse again and watch it swim away. That's not the worst part though. No, the worst part is where the fish just breaks loose without you even doing anything. Or, where you reel it in but doubt you can get it fully in before it has a temper tantrum again so you let go of the mouse to let it swim away for a bit only the game sees this as 'oh oops, too late, should've tried harder' aaaand now it's gone again.

I really do not have time for this kind of ridiculous gameplay. If I wanted something challenging and impossible and boring I probably could've found some game less expensive. I have no clue why all reviews are so ridiculously positive. Normally I love this genre, but this game really doesn't do anything for me.

A charmless game with super questionable controls. It forces you into having repeated interactions just to accomplish what should be done in one go. For example, you can only sell one item at the store at a time, at which point the menu closes and you have to restart the whole process with the NPC. Even with crafting stations, the early ones I got required repeated use for every single item produced rather than being able to stock materials and go on your merry way as they're processing. I'm not expecting factory-level efficiency here, but this is super tedious busywork for not much reward. A lot of the menus in this game and just the way it plays make me think of a cheap mobile or Nintendo game. 

And a word of warning for people seeking to play coop exclusively - you won't be able to from the start until you create a character and play for a few minutes (15 or so?) on your own, figuring out the ropes. The main quest seems to not be shared with the person joining your world, which means that there's at least a certain amount of time they'll have to spend doing stuff in their own world. All in all, pretty annoying, especially if you're just looking to try it out and see if you and your friend both like it.

I will say it's a very simple and forgiving game if you want to play it with a child or a gaming-impaired adult.
