Pros:
+ it's like Stardew Valley in pretty much every way
+ adorable graphics
+ intuitive controls
+ digging for treasure is just plain and simple fun
+ mini-boss fights (alpha predators) have surprisingly engaging mechanics

Room for Improvement - this section is mostly feedback for the creators:
- A bit short, but hey, it's still early access, and there's a lot of content already considering that. But there isn't really any sort of endgame. There isn't much to do in the mines (beyond looking for chests / red crystals) and the whole map is unlocked from the very start, so there's not really a sense of "unlocking more things to do" as you progress. The game could benefit from more mine levels or more dangerous biomes that you can't survive without better tools and equipment.
- Farming progression feels a bit off. I was almost level 12 in mining and had unlocked the deep mine before I planted any crops at  all. The reason being that keeping your crops safe from birds requires a scarecrow, but crafting a scarecrow requires a watermelon or pumpkin, both of which you can only get by planting them yourself and letting them grow for several days. I hovered near my watermelon seeds for the better part of the summer season, which was quite boring to be honest, only to have them all snatched up by a bird the one time I quickly ducked into the trader or tried to do my other daily tasks. In the end the only reason I managed to progress farming at all was because I was able to buy a scarecrow off the Christmas special vendor. I think scarecrows should be easier to make, or at least add a temporary one that requires daily repairs or something.
- Animal husbandry also progresses a bit weirdly. I had the third license very quickly and was technically allowed to raise a whole number of animals, but Irwin only seems to sell chickens in his temporary store, so I was never able to actually purchase the others. I built a bunch of empty pens for them.
- Getting merchants to apply for a permanent residence takes a bit too long in my opinion. I think friendship gain per quest should be adjusted, or we should be given the option to do multiple quests for them when they visit. I very quickly got to a point where I had exhausted most of the other daily content (was stuck on farming as mentioned above, and didn't need any more cash or resources). It's not exactly fun to do one quest for a visitor, then skip any days without that visitor by going back to sleep immediately until they show up again. If there's a different way to speed up this process, then it's not well explained. I did also always chat with the merchants and spent quite a bit of cash at their temporary stores. Except for Irwin, because once you buy 2 birds, 1 feeder and can make your own feed from seeds, there's no _reason_ to spend any cash at his store.
- The bats in the mine are annoying. They're really hard to hit with any of the weapons and they drop almost nothing. It's more efficient to just ignore them and just madly dash around the mine looking for crystals with a huge cloud of bats and other critters trailing behind, not sure that's the intended mechanic.
- Animal spawns seem broken (maybe just in multiplayer, not sure). But generally we noticed the world quickly depopulating with hardly any animals or bugs left, only to return to normal when we quit and relaunched the game. It's easily fixed that way, but a bit annoying.
beware.. addicting..

I. Love. Dinkum.

See I've always been the kinda person who REALLY wanted to like animal crossing, but the restrictive real time clock infuriated me to no end and I was too scared of messing up my devices to time travel. However, I've always wanted that kind of experience, but with a game that wasn't so anal retentive about time.

Now, this game has room for improvement - there does need to be some things added, and I would appreciate some villagers who weren't there just to be shop keeps as well - but I can say that everything GOOD about it shines through. 

The game's super forgiving with your items if you happen to die (Like me), the only draw back being a minus to your tool's health but you know what? I'll take a half broken shovel over loosing the butterfly that got me mauled by crocodiles. I do agree that the mines are a bit difficult, but again, any real complaints I have are either slated to be fixed or so minor that they do not bother me. (Except maybe the aggro on crocodiles I think they should calm down a little)

The music is wonderfully infectious, the setting is never bland, and even though characters tend to repeat each other, they're different enough to keep things lively and fun. 

A minor suggestion is that I think the machine manual should be a free gift from John or Fletch once you start the crafting side of things, because lord knows how long it took me to figure out that you can make tin plates by running them through the table saw. Other than that, the game does a wonderful job at mixing what it tells you vs what it lets you find out, the art style is adorable and I cannot wait to see where this developer goes with Dinkum - and I'll be there to see it!

Cons

- Extremely grindy, hard to get money. I was constantly in debt without any feasible way to pay it out. 
- Characters are shallow and befriending them gives nothing. Their requests are boring: blue moon butterflies and flies - it‚Äôs all you need 
- Deep mines are annoying and enemies are attacking every second. My god I hated it. Locked areas have chests with useless items. So anticlimactic to get a couple of used slingshots locked behind two doors. But copper ore is scarce so I had to go to the mines so I found a mod online to disable the enemies to be able to continue playing this game 
- Some mechanics seem too time consuming on purpose to keep you in the game. No auto feeder for animals and basic watering can covers one tile wtf
- Killing kangaroos and turkeys was sad since they are cute and try to run away. I am not a fan of killing animals in a cozy game 
- There‚Äôs no story in this game 
- Why the heck can‚Äôt I use items from my storage boxes directly when crafting? 
- Why the heck fishing is so tedious? 
- Why do crops grow so slowly? 
- Why are all machines so expensive?
- Why there‚Äôs no pause in the game and save only at the end of the day? 
 
I played it enough to say that it got boring pretty fast and I didn‚Äôt even get to the good part with all quality of life improvements, but I stopped enjoying watering one tile at a time and doing same thing over and over again to earn some money just to add another store I already gathered ingredients for. 200k for a fucking store wtf

[h1] A Life-Sim that gets it right. [/h1]
This game is seriously well thought out with so much to do. 
Of course in the Early Access state there's still room for improvement.

[b] The story [/b] is pretty typical for the genre. After getting fed up with the grey boring city livin' you're given the opportunity to move out to greener pasture. A nice old lady with a blimp takes you to her old hometown island [i] (basically Australia). [/i] You get to customize your character a bit, pick a name for yourself and the new town and off you go. 

[b] Not much hand-holding. [/b] You get a nice short and sweet tutorial and some of the basics and then your free to blaze your own trail. The [u] core gameplay loop [/u] consists of making enough money to build new buildings to invite permanent residents. How you get to that goal is up to you. Logging, Fishing, Hunting, Mining, Farming, Trapping, Scavenging, Foraging, and more. So many occupational options. I haven't found which is the most profitable yet, but Fishing and Hunting are so far the most fun to me.

[b] Be prepared to grind. [/b] Income is slow to start out. Be ready to spend the first couple weeks (in game) doing tasks to get new licenses to unlock all the activities. Slowly growing relationships with Granny and John as well as the newcomers to the town to try and convince them to stay. It takes a while, but the journey there is fun. I don't know how in depth the relationship system goes as I haven't seen many fruits from that labor, but I am eager to see how it plays out.

[b] Design the town, and your house [/b] however you like. [i] (As far as money and resources permit) [/i] You can place whatever building you want, anywhere you want on level ground. Want a grid layout city? Go for it. Rather have it feel like a hobbit villiage? No problem. With lots of decorations, pathways, and such make your town how you please. This is another one of my favorite features, but I haven't gotten too deep into designing my town as of yet because I'm shooting for efficiency. I was slightly displeased when I found out it takes a good bit of coin to move buildings after they've been placed, so think a little before plopping down buildings.

[h1] Pro+ Con- [/h1]
+ Lots to do
+ Good Audio design and Music
+ Fishing is more than just a mini-game
+ Island is a good size. Not so big that it feels empty, but not so small that you feel cramped.
+ Vehicles
+ Lots of NPC's to interact with and get to know.

- Very Grindy
- I'm not a huge fan of the Animal-Crossing / Minecraft - Esk artstyle personally, but it fits the theme. [i] this is just my opintion [/i]
- Tools break extremely quick early game which adds to the grindyness because you have to buy tools in the beginning. This is less of a problem the farther you get.
- Terra-forming is a pain the rear. The shovel can only move 1 dirt tile at a time so when deciding where you want to build make sure it's already fairly flat.

[i] Suggestions [/i]
~ Maybe a vehicle that lets you terraform better?
~ More enemy types, maybe certain ones that only come out at night to make the game feel more dangerous? I'm not sure how "grounded" the game is suppose to be, but cryptids could definitely be a thing. Skinwalkers, Jackalopes, Zombies, Etc would be neat to fight.
~ Fishing could be more in depth, bait types, fighting the fish by pulling Left or Right depending on how the fish swims away, currently the fish swims directly away from you.
~ Character customization could be more in depth
~ Seeing a preview of the article of clothing in the inventory would be nice
~ Expand the museum to have a spot for rare artifacts found in the mines or other places. I'm thinking like a Dinosaur skeleton that you have to reconstruct piece by piece.

Anyways, overall I really enjoy the game, and would recommend it to anyone who is even remotely a fan of the genre.
Especially at such a reasonable price-point it's hard to pass up.

This game is no Stardew Valley.  Stardew Valley is one of my most favorite games.  You're drawn into the world with the beautiful village, the interesting people, and the starting premise.

I personally hate Animal Crossing.  I hate this game.  Know what you're getting into when you buy this game:  Animal Crossing, NOT Stardew Valley.

Great game until one of your favorite game features is fishing and you can't catch a gosh dang thing. I understand the concept, you reel when they're not splashing, stop when they are; but it doesn't matter. No matter how hard you try, you will never catch a fish unless it is godsend luck. The moment the fish swims out of reach, doesn't matter if you follow the rules, you dont catch it. It is super flawed, it looks like they tried combining ac fishing with a different mechanic, but all it did was create rage.
Anyway, aside from my huge frustration to the fishing, its great, Animal crossing meets my time at portia, stardew valley, plus better multiplayer and has other cool stuff like hunting and actual hostile mobs. But until they nerf the fishing, im not recommending it, because if you can't even catch a fish 1/5 of the time you will never complete the museum.

Edit: OKAY, so i am an idiot. To fish, you let it swim away when its splashing, then reel it in when it stops, HOWEVER, you need to click, not hold down, if you click repetitively instead, it doesn't affect the rod stamina.

Yo, I've only played for a short while, but I'm absolutely loving this game! I see it as a mix of Animal Crossing and Minecraft (definitely the blocky style and music give me Minecraft vibes). I've heard that it's also got aspects of Stardew Valley in it too, but I haven't played it so I can't say myself. And hearing that this was made by a singular person too just blows my mind!

I love how they took all the quality of life aspects that Animal Crossing was lacking and implemented them here. Going in and out of buildings doesn't result in a transition, long loading screen and another transition. It's instantaneous. There's an icon on the ground indicating where you're facing and what tiles on the ground would be effected if you're, say, digging or placing an item. That's something I absolutely wished Animal Crossing had. Just everything seems faster and more intuitive in this game whereas Animal Crossing felt so unnecessarily slow and bogged down by the UI and game mechanics.

There are a lot of features that differentiate this from Animal Crossing though to make this more unique, but I don't want to give them away (and I'm also finding out more as I go along too!). So far I definitely recommend this to anyone who wants their Animal Crossing fix for PC.

Great game! Totally addictive. Easy to learn. One of those games where you look up at the clock and realize you've been playing for 5 hours. Some of the mechanics take a little bit of figuring out, and TBH I was fortunate to have my kids, both of whom are vets at this type of game (they have dozens of hours into Animal Crossing) to help me out. 

The multiplayer aspect of the game was pretty seamless to get into as well. We were all 3 able to join each others games with little problem. 

There were a few minor glitches: one happened when we were all 3 in my son's instance of the game. My daughter decided to mess w/him by taking his row boat all the way out to sea and then quitting the game. This resulted in the rowboat staying all the way out in the ocean so they had to create another one to go out and get it once she signed back in again. When they went out to fetch it, there was a ghost image of her character permanently hovering over the water. 

The second was inexplicable: somehow her character appeared to be swimming on dry land. No matter where we went on land she "swam" there! we discovered that this was only on my screen - on both of the other screens she was walking as normal. It was pretty funny though. 

All in all a really enjoyable game. Highly recommended and I definitely intend to continue playing.

Great game, a mixture of Animal Crossing with Stardew Valley. Didn't think I'd spend close to 50 hours within a week but here we are. 

I stopped playing tho because I feel it got too grindy. Like the iron bars needed to make any useful tool is just a lot and to mine iron ore you have to spend time in the Deep Mine which is also a lot of money needed to get to that point (plus a Mine Pass for every time). 

A lot of this game boils down to, I choose X as project, and for X I need to do A. But to do A first, I need materials for A. To find materials for A I also need money, and since I'm low in money I have to ditch all my stuff prior and earn some money first. And the day goes by fast and with stamina you keep refilling your stamina bar, but you need to have farmed a decent amount of fruits (and cook them) to have those items ready. And at the end of the day your stamina is 1/10th because of sleep deprivation so you can't even work more, you're forced to sleep and start the next day.

And with the next day, comes a new task. Pet the animals, feed the animals, collect resources from animals. Then you have your small farm (because to get automated sprinklers, you need A LOT of farming XP, and farming only gets you XP once you harvest every 6-7 days..) for the small farm you need to water everything as well. Then there's micro-management with the residents.

In short, there is a million little tasks to do, and everytime I try to tackle one project at a time, I'm ALWAYS forced to ditch the project for awhile and spend time on collecting/farming something required.

I really enjoyed the game and for the price is well worth it, it's early Access but honestly it feels and plays like a finished game. Sure there are tweaks that can be done/added, but never had a bug. 

Just be aware that you it requires a lot of time and grinding, so if you're low on time every week, you might not enjoy it as much because the progress will feel a lot slower. I'm glad I played this during a Xmas break so abundance of time there, but like Animal Crossing on Nintendo consoles, it's to be played in short bursts, but to get to the cool stuff (the big farms, automated sprinklers, vehicles, automated tools like jackhammer/dirt landscaper) you'll be grinding soooo much. 

Iron Ore is  by far the most annoying resource to farm as there are little in the overworld so you're forced in the Deep Mines, and without a Jackhammer to quickly drill ores (whilst avoiding being attacked by bats every turn) you'll be busy for a long time manually pickaxing iron ores.. I spent about 10 hours just to get the jackhammer materials so I could do an easy run of the Deep Mines, but after completing it, I'm like okay I still need a gazillion Iron Ore just to get some decent farming ready to have automated sprinklers so I don't have to manually water plants every damn day.

A suggestion for the devs: please increase the spawn rate of Iron Ores in the overworld, or make the Iron Bar quantity requirements lower because I shouldn't have to spend close to 50 hours in the game just to get to the cool stuff I wanted to do once I saw the first youtube video on this game..

As I write this mere hours out of 2022 ending, I felt like this one sneaked in this year for me as one of the best games I played in this year. 

Dinkum is what I would call the perfect alternative to Animal Crossing. However whilst not quite a clone of the the top tier Nintendo title, Dinkum certainly sets itself apart and stand on it's on two feet. The best I can describe this game would be using a the Family Guy meme of the two guys crashing and accidentally inventing peanut butter and chocolate. Except in this the meme would be Animal 'Crossing-over' with Stardew Valley albeit set in Australia. This is a welcome setting for myself as an Australian, it isn't very common a game will use Aus as it's worldly inspiration. 

Dinkum is fun, relaxing and addicting and I could not imagine just how good this game must be on the Steam Deck. (I cannot wait for the device to launch in Australia for this game alone now.)

Dinkum can be enjoyed with friends in a fully co-op world where you can work together to build and survive. This is a very welcome addition to the game and I wouldn't fault the game without this at all.

All said, this is the perfect game to pick up if you're a fan of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley and I am absolutely going to sneak this in to my top 5 games of 2022, perhaps top 3. 

The story behind the creation alone reminds me of Eric Berone's story of Stardew Valley and I cannot wait to see how far this game could possibly go with more marketing, console releases, mobile ports and expanding features. 

All this, and it's in early access as of the time of writing this.

Dinkum is 1 part jackaroo, 2 parts wild diggo, and 6 parts fun. A blend of adorable stylized art, great story telling, a voxel world full that is of silly but isn't dumb, and gameplay which seems to be inspired by Harvest Moon, Stardew Valley, and Animal Crossing. Lighthearted comedy keeps the story fun and appropriate for all ages. There is plenty do as you build your town, one thing I haven't run into is lack of things to do but the game doesn't feel rushed or imperatively linear.

I look forward to wasting far too many hours playing this. Dinkum is in early access at the time of this writing, and is still receiving balancing adjustments as new content and features are introduced.

Absolutely in-love with this game and has been something I've been waiting for for some time. Something that scratches that itch for a game that has a combination of sandbox-like and harvest moon/stardew mechanics. The fact that it tosses animal crossing-like features into it is also a major plus!

My fiance got the game shortly after I did and we've been playing side by side as it seems co-op is more akin to animal crossing's multiplayer at the moment. We did try it to see how well it would work for us and made new characters specifically for a co-op. Sadly, as he was the host, I was barred from the story stuff, thus I would never get certain recipes, such as nails or a crate. Sure, he could make them for me and I could gather the resources for such.. but it kinda defeats the purpose of us being able to fully work together. While we were a tad disappointed, we decided to hold off on co-op to see where the dev takes it later on. For now, we just get jealous over what recipes we each get that the other doesn't have, or neat clothing haha.

The game does seem to get a little buggy the longer we play, sometimes forcing us to close the game after a save and relaunch. So far, the most annoying bug is dealing with getting pictures for an NPC via the request board. After playing for a while, if I pick up one of those quests, it will not register on the quest that I've gotten a picture of what the NPC wants. No matter how many I take, what angle it's in, or time of day.. just wouldn't work. But, after reloading the game, it worked fine.

Another is where animals just start to vanish, or move further and further away from your town. Making hunting or capturing a lot more difficult. (Edit: After I made this review, I did find out you can damage the more hostile critters before capturing them. They won't escape then.) I don't know if that is intentional or a bug though.

All in all, it's a great game! I don't normally write reviews, but felt compelled to do so for this one.
I look forward to more!

Ofcourse it's Early Access, so there's still some stuff that needs to get added before it's a full game. If you plan to play a full game, wait a little bit. I feel like the game is nearly finished with how much you can do already.

Now for the game itself. At its core Dinkum is Animal Crossing with the time passing added from regular farming games. A day will net you about half an hour IRL, give or take depending on how much you pause ofc. Multiplayer is sadly also exactly like Animal Crossing, so you can only visit someone else's island. However from what I've experienced so far there's a LOT you can do on another's island, so it might be worth it to just keep on visiting the one island and work on it together.

But Dinkum is more than Animal Crossing. Every character you add to the town brings with them another feature. You don't just get a new villager, you get a hairdresser, a scientist, a well-known Australian crocodile enthusiast. The villagers have daily requests of you that you can complete to become friendly with them, and getting friendly with them will bring you new goodies and blueprints. They also interact with the town a lot more than AC villagers do, like watering your crops and petting your animals to keep them happy. Sadly the fixed villagers also means that you don't have hundreds of villagers to randomly get to your island; you just get the same few others get as well. You do however have the option to build more empty houses, so maybe that will change at a later date.

What Dinkum lacks in variety of villagers, it makes up in variety of building options. The shops the villagers bring to your island are very diverse, and they look really nice together. There's a ton of different fence, floor, and decoration options, with some of the decorations automatically locking into fences which look just SO good. To craft these you often need multiple working stations, which requires farming multiple resources like different trees, ores, plants, and leftover mechanical devices like CDs and keyboards. So that's what you'll spend most of your time doing. Gathering resources, crafting stuff, selling valuables, and building your town.

There's also combat (hunting), and sometimes you'll be requested to take out an alpha creature which has some raid mechanics. It feels smooth, but it's definitely not the main part of the game.

If you're a casual gamer looking for a chill game to play and build in, this game is for you.

I'm really loving this game so far! It has similarities to both animal crossing (one of my favorite series) and Stardew Valley, which I had trouble getting into. But unlike Stardew Valley, this game has features that I enjoy more. Creating a town from scratch is fun, but in some games the gameplay turns out to be boring, but Dinkum keeps it fresh with a great artstyle and tons to do every day. Another issue I had with Stardew Valley was the overwhelming amount of stuff that is all thrown at you at once, but this game lays out everything in a more comprehensible way. That's not to say it's a perfect game, and it could use quite a few more features before the game officially releases. Some new biomes and foliage could be interesting, as well as some more animals to give insentive to explore more. I also feel like backpacks would be great if they continue to add many more items (although I'm not far enough in to know if they have already). Overall, this game really hits that scratch that I couldn't find in any other game, and it's been great so far!

UPDATE:::

Started a new save and haven't had any crashing yet. Haven't tried to pull up the old broken save, since I'm just continuing with the new save. Xmas event is fun and the decorations are cute. Seems like it's more stable now than earlier. Lots to do & a fun game. I'll recommend it now, but keep up my old review below to emphasize it's still early access.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For the first 24 hours I played it was a JOY. It was so much fun and there was always a ton to do. I couldn't wait to play more and get into the meat of the game with raising animals and going to the mines and building out the town.

Just one problem. Now, it will freeze and stop responding after a few minutes of play. Sometimes by moving the camera, sometimes moving items into storage or around my inventory, sometimes when I'm doing nothing at all. There's no consistency in what i'm doing but it will always crash before i can do much at all. 

I've tried everything to get it to work from reinstalling, updating my BIOS + drivers, virus and malware scans, repairing windows libraries, lowering graphics settings, using local saves instead of cloud saves, sleeping immediately to see if it was an issue with that particular day in-game. Nothing works. My computer has an intel 10th generation i7 2.6ghz, 16gb ram & a RTX 2060 so specs shouldn't be an issue at all.

The game has AMAZING potential and loved playing it, but now it's unplayable for me. Recommend if it'll work for you - I know a lot of people who haven't has issues - but if you're one of the unlucky ones that get this crashing, I can't recommend. Based on my game experience alone, I'll have to not recommend and wait until the next update to see if it fixes the crashing issue.

I absolutely love this game.
If you're into the cozy game genre at all, you're sure to love this game as well.
Some of the best parts of Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley, and a hint of Minecraft (mostly the semi blocky terrain) are present in this game, with a few improvements. This fits neatly into the same genre without feeling like a knock-off.
The areas of advancement can be exhausted relatively quickly, which is not to say they're easy, just that you'll run out of things to achieve after putting in enough play time. That said, I get the impression that the developers have far more in store (because early access) and offer regular updates. As I write this, I'm enjoying some extra items and quests from a winter holiday update. 

Even if you grind morning till night, and obtain all the furniture, clothes, and advancements the game has to offer, there are mods available to keep it interesting even if another update never drops (which I doubt). Still, I'm optimistic to see what else the devs have in store as time goes on. Sale, or full price, you'll get your money's worth out of this game, and then some.

So if you're a cozy game enthusiast, you're missing out if you don't own this game. I look forward to seeing the community that is already developing around this game.

Dinkum is honestly one of the best games I have played. It really is a hybrid of Animal Crossing, Stardew Valley & Minecraft. Block style elements when terraforming, short days like Stardew & cute characters and play style like Animal Crossing.
If you want a cosy game with a good medium level difficulty of grinding to complete - this is for you!

PS: Learning Australian phrases and foodstuff is so cool and educational too!

Amazing.  This game takes Animal Crossing New Horizons as a base, and then it combines elements of Minecraft, and Stardew Valley.  It's a huge game that will take a lot of your time, and honestly feels so good to play, it's almost as if it's a sequel to Animal Crossing.  It's well done, but it's not quite enough to make me think it's flat out better than any of the aforementioned games.  I still would love to play those others, and they have their advantages over this, but Dinkum is like a combined package.  This is great because with updates, this game can continue to evolve.  

I will say, I wish you could have the option to create the lowest level of tools.  It seems you have to purchase them, and it's a big inconvenience when your store is limited to one per day.  Also, ores above ground seem to be limited?  I'd love to keep mining but I feel like I'm forced to go underground at this point.

I bought Dinkum a little while after it launched in EA, and I haven't caught up with the very latest updates. But, as someone relatively new to the life sim genre, I played for 14 hours on my first day. 

Dinkum is a lovely experience that I found far less intimidating than Stardew Valley, and it has much the same character as Animal Crossing (minus, of course, the animal villagers). It addresses the biggest problem I had with ACNL when I played it: Dinkum is not tied to the real-world clock. The Australian setting is novel and shines through various aspects of the game: not just the environments, but the writing and overall 'culture' of the game as well. It has made me curious about a continent that I regrettably haven't had much time to learn about.

In games that offer it, I dislike farming as a system. In Dinkum, as in many other games, it is slow (and your growth in the associated skill is tied to harvests). But it's not something you have to do to make money. You can catch bugs, fish, hunt and trap animals, or beachcomb for shells and discarded technology via metal detector (the latter is a great source of money and my favorite thing to do.

While there isn't a design tool for custom clothing or patterns, I have seen a lot of really cool options so far. I was and am excited to continue building up my house and slowly adding villagers. The graphics initially weren't my cup of tea but they have grown on me, and now I can't walk past a Diggo without internally aww-ing. They really are too cute to kill... crocodiles on the other hand can keep handing their meat over.

At the end of my major stint in Dinkum I was about to unlock the mines, and I hear that they're pretty challenging and that there's potential for grind there, so I'll probably have to pace myself as I build up a nest egg of Dinks and begin shifting focus to customization/island planning. But this is not something I view with trepidation. I recently spent about 12 hours in Kynseed, another recent life sim, and didn't enjoy it very much, yet that experience prompted me to write this review. Dinkum is 'simple' in some respects, yes, and it takes after Animal Crossing for the basic loop, but I almost got through my first year in a day. This is a game that it's easy to get lost in, and fun to spend time in.

My Switch Lite is buried in moving boxes, and while there are things I miss about ACNL, I vastly prefer Dinkum not only because it's on PC, but because of its character. The sole dev has put a lot of heart into it and it shows. Dinkum is a homely, welcoming place despite the outback's repute for dangerous wildlife (and believe me, those Wary Mu ARE dangerous...). If you turn down a villager's daily request, they don't berate or penalize you. It sounds silly, but was actually mildly therapeutic for me.

Looking forward to seeing what's to come in the future of this game.

TL;DR

Buy this game if:

--You wish there was an Animal Crossing game that didn't run in realtime
--You have a soft spot for the Australian outback, or are curious about it
--You thought Stardew Valley was good/great but wish it was more focused with less of a farming emphasis
--Or, you like the general type of game Stardew is but prefer them in 3D rather than 2D

Don't buy this game if:

--You would rather wait for full release
--The idea or concept of something like Animal Crossing doesn't sound entertaining to you
--You are dead set on multiplayer (it exists, but I've heard it needs to be fleshed out a bit more.)

It's worth the asking price and will give you many hours of fun, satisfaction and relaxation if you're a fan of the genre. If you're newer to it, like me, Dinkum is an excellent starting point.

The game is on the whole good, but there is a lack of polish in a number of aspects that deeply impact the experience.
1. Facing and targeting: The tile cursor-like approach to designating the direction of an action of its intended location is very, very imprecise, laggy and very often requires several attempts to get the right facing or messing around with trying to look at a tile form several angles before getting the cursor to lock on correctly.  In the mni boss-like fights in the game, this is a massive nuisance, and a deep pain point in the mines where you need to (try) and perform hit and run attacks and dodges. Too often you'll just entirely miss because the cursor hasn't 'caught up' yet.
2. Heading change lag: Self explanatory. 
3. Unpredictable resource scarcity. I'm not sure what kind of resource respanwing logic this game uses, but I've scoured the map some weeks without a node of a certain resource to be found anywhere.

Apart from this, which is mostly combat-oriented, the rest of the game does well, but to have added a combat element to the game with this poor a means to do so and questionable aim is a bit frustrating.

Farming + Hunting + Gathering Life Simulator/Town Builder in EA

Personal Score (9/10)

Pro Aspects:

+ Terraform with your own resources and map the town/orchard/farm yourself by placing buildings that towny NPCs you invited can live in.
+ 3rd Person character play of an arguably Open-world of hunting(via combat)/fishing/logging/mining/bug-catching
(the instance changes between worlds are only gradual that don't feel noticeable)
+ Seasons/Time of the day dependent spawns that randomize every day in-game
+ Complete assignments(whether daily or with a set due date) requested by your townies
+ Active Discord community
+ Lots of clothing options even now (at least 120+ items) that can be earned in the game
+ Updates planned for the EA phase (as of posting this now)

Neutral Aspects:
* Slow Dialogue Speed set at default that can be manually enhanced in the settings to make the game much more playable.
* Slower in-game speed of time (compared to Stardew VAlley for example). I am at around 48hour real-time mark but still haven't gotten around 1 year mark in-game yet. This also means that more can be done in one day.

Less appealing aspects in the EA phase:
- Shallow dialogues (many interactions between all the NPCs speak in the same cookie-cutter set phrases or are simply interrupted by a *Text* blurp)

The game feels highly replayable even at this stage, although less so as the number of new kinds of collectibles slowly diminish. The terraforming aspect provided in the base game definitely gives more freedom, something that might feel more pronounced coming from other farming titles with non-redisignable towns, which might've always felt more restricting.

Recommended.

The similarities to Animal Crossing are of course pretty obvious. This game copied so much from AC, it basically is a PC clone for it. However it adds much more options to the game and removed much really annoying grind features (as well as unskippable animations on crafting/catching bugs etc.). Dinkum improved alot of lacking features in AC - I would go so far to call it an evolved Animal Crossing 2.0, without the overexpensive Nintendo license of course.

Given that this game is classified early access, I don't feel any of this. I've never run into a bug or glitch, the game runs smooth as pie, the graphics look nice and well designed. Of course some sounds and music could or should be added, but AC as a final product doesn't offer much more as Dinkum.

The only downside is that the Multiplayer feature is - unfortunetaly - also a copied version from Animal Crossing. You can't build together or run an island together. You have your own island and friends can basically just visit you and don't do much there. When I was looking with my girlfriend for a game we can play together, we saw the reviews regarding the so-called "Multiplayer" and almost didn't buy the game. Now we're both playing on our own island while sitting next to each other and simply both enjoy the game being played as Singleplayer.

When we checked the player stats on steam charts I was alarmed when seeing the low player count of Dinkum, but I can assure anyone out there, that this game is worth every cent times 10.

An absolute gem of a game. Dinkum is (if explained far too simply) Animal Crossing set in Australia. It distinguishes itself however, with different mechanics, chores, environments, wildlife, everything. It is not a soulless clone in any sense whatsoever, but a game that takes all of the best things about animal crossing, and puts a delightful twist on them, plus adding countless features that aren't possible in AC; truly making you feel like you're surviving, crafting, and building your town from the ground up in the weird and wonderful Outback. $28.95aud may be a tall order to some, but if you can afford it or catch it on sale, and enjoy the Animal Crossing/survival-crafting style of gameplay, you will absolutely love Dinkum.

I'd give 50% (and mind it's EA, so it may tremendously improve yet!), considering there's a lot of positive reviews, allow me to explain my problem with the game. At the moment, it's a big sandbox where I can expand, but I lack incentive to. These games are usually driven forward by something to reach. Now if I get a copper bar, I can improve my axe and get that hardwood so I can build...

The gameplay is at the moment oddly unrewarding. I have a small camp and I can gather stuff to sell and buy a new building that will sell me something... I don't have much use for. The buildings are unlocked with money - a lot of money, so everything you sell yields a lot, making the basic items comparatively cheap. Making money is thus more of a chore with very little reward. Crafting recipes unlock rather randomly and most of them are decorative. A lot of what I can build was never built, because it just didn't serve any purpose.

There's very little story. Very little incentive to explore. If you enjoy sandbox play with no goal, go for it, you're going to have fun, but if want something to aim for and try to achieve, wait till the game is developed further. After some six hours, you're gonna get bored and a chance to catch a new butterfly when walking further from your base won't help. I think it might be a good game for kids, but don't expect Stardew Valley, at least not yet.

Also, pet peeve - developers please, stop producing super excited dialog lines of "Oh thank you, you're helping me so much, I don't know what I'd do without you!" after we walk five steps and pitch a tent ;)

When I purchased this, I wasn't expecting much but a love letter to Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing. However, for an Early Access game, it offers quite a bit of content. I can't recommend it more for $20. 

There are plenty of activities (a la Animal Crossing) to gather and raise money. Then you have a bunch of others (a la Stardew) to create long-term money makers, such as farming and animal husbandry. Plenty of crafting and decorating options, as well as ways to customize your entire island, including buildings and decor. 

The best feature is the multiplayer, where you can team up to help each other actually customize your islands. I remember being disappointed in AC:NH when I could not help my friends decorate or terraform. No worries - we can truly co-op in Dinkum!

I can't wait to dive deeper into this game and discover everything else that's waiting for me.

Note *Early Access Review*

Lifestyle, wildlife, culture. Dinkum encapsulates the quintessence of the wild Australian outback, refining it into a relaxing, yet engaging simulation experience.

Despite being an 'Early Access Game', Dinkum has already solidified itself as one the greatest farming simulator games, alongside the likes of fan favourites, Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley.

Dinkum perfectly blends the stereotypical farming/life sim-esque elements of gathering, farming and crafting, topped with a touch of survival. From scavenging for carcinogenic trash to pay off insane debts to joyriding on emus and fending off glow-in-the-dark fungi crocs, Dinkum is plentiful in content, enough to satiate the desires of any life sim genre diehard.

However, with the good, comes the not so good.

For those who enjoy the 'co-op' experience, the game in its current state may not provide you the full package. Dinkum currently does not have shared progression i.e. the opportunity to complete the same quests and the ability to unlock items/buildings. Simply put, friends of the host are limited to only helping the host progress, unable to benefit themselves. Hopefully this is a feature that can, and will be refined/altered in future updates.

With that being said, I can't wait to see which direction the developer chooses to progress from here, but from what we've seen so far, it's bound to be great. Happy Dinkum gamers!

Hugely impressive game for a one man team. A blend of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, with a coat of dusty outback paint. A surprising amount of content for early access, which makes me optimistic about the game's ongoing development.

Big ups to the dev for the nice little quality-of-life touches, like a certain number of planks turning into a single stack as you run logs through the table saw. Would love an option to queue processing of logs and ore - not sure if these come later as upgrades to the furnace and table saw though, as I'm still pretty early on.

Updated: new content only improving the game!

A fascinating look at a different interpretation of the Animal Crossing formula. 

Dinkum approaches many aspects of the formula in ways I wholeheartedly welcome, such as the day/night timekeeping, terrain manipulation, and combat. These are a breath of fresh air and made the game thoroughly enjoyable. 

There are a small handful of downsides, most of which I imagine will get resolved as the game progresses through its early access period. The main angle that I'm not sure will be addressed is largely a matter of personal taste - the NPCs being human and within this art style makes the game less visually appealing in my mind, and the NPCs are largely forgettable by comparison to Animal Crossing NPCs.

Overall, if you want an AC-like game on PC, this is it. If you want AC that doesn't force you to stick with real-time mechanics and punish you for passing time, this is it. However, if you want the cutesy animal NPCs of AC, or a 100% peaceful game with no combat nor hunger mechanics... this probably isn't for you.

Okay solo, more fun in multiplayer. Very repetitive though and no real reason to ever restart. 

One thing I find a lot of games lacking nowadays is replayability. I find myself playing them for a few hours and then just not wanting to play because "I've done what I wanted to do". This is one of those games. It's not like Captain of Industry, Anno, Timberborn, or other similar games where you could try something new or the map changed so there's a reason to play again. 

And, before you say anything, I know the maps are different each time, but that's not variety, that's just adding an extra level of "oo look at this" while not actually being different.

I also wish that it was easier to have visitors. Like knowing who's coming or being able to determine who comes (like inviting them to the island). And finding out what the different levels of licenses do before you unlock them so you don't spend thousands of points and then wish you hadn't.

A super chill and satisfying marriage of concepts from games like Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, but with an Australian twist. Enjoyable game play. Great mix of obvious with discovery and exploration. The music is relaxing with satisfying nature sounds. The deep mine is such a surprise every time and though I was originally concerned about the price to enter, I understand that it gives a real feeling of "risk it for the biscuit" mentality. 

There are similarities to Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing, however it gives more freedom and self directed game play. The relationships with townfolk is not as deep and needs more in that respect. There are no challenging characters like original Animal Crossing (were some just straight up hate you) and I don't think you can marry and have children like in Stardew Valley.

I just love the colourful skies, sun rise and sun sets. The fishing is so fun with the way the fish hide and swim along the shore. The Aussie theme is a real blast to see in a game, and carries well in the dialog of the townfolk.

I have seen people build amazing townships and it is inspiring and challenging to create my own builds. It is not easy to build like in minecraft but I find it just as satisfying all the same.

Whether or not you feel like using another game to compare is or isn't a great idea, I'd say this is an australian animal crossing. Decent gameplay loops with farming/animal keeping, map layout(roads, *landscaping*[e w], building placement), and combat(not super complicated, which works well for the game's atmosphere). Would recommend, tho multiplayer is a little odd and the game still could use some polish but it's still in development so I think it has a very bright future.

No, I do not recommend this game. It's pretty much Minecraft, Stardew, & Animal Crossing mushed together with limited functionality. Meaning, there was an attempt to combine awesome games into one, but failed miserably as it doesn't even come close to having any of the same features. It's probably the worst time consuming glitchy game I've played this year. The game has it's appeal in creativity & cuteness, however, that will be short lived due to all the annoyances that come with it. Not to mention the lack of crafting variety & building materials/options makes this game a bit drab.

The multi-player mode is okay if you have someone you trust like close friends or family, but you only make progress on one island - with the exception of keeping the progress made on villagers. If you'd like to make new friends then you could always open your world up to public - which I'd highly recommend if you want some random person in a bat suit joining with bombs and  blowing up your island.

If that doesn't convince you, it's a solo dev subpar game that has been worked since 2017 & is still not finished. The bugs in the game will be slow to fix, new features slow to introduce, & maybe slight functionality  with added features available over a couple (or more) of long years. The community in discord is predominately Australians with elitist type mods - there also seems to be a bit of a nationalist vibe going on. It's a very strict & Australian time-zone type discord. So, if you need help & you're not in that time zone - good luck...you'll be waiting until they're available. 

Only started playing this game to spend time with my sister...I like it less every time I play it. Especially since my favorite part of the game is fishing which is extremely bugged...love having two fish bite my bait just to disappear entirely. All in all, don't waste your time - like I did.

Animal Crossing meets Stardew Valley meets Minecraft meets Portal Knights, meets Australia.

It's got everything you'd want in a game of this type. including a gradual progression to unlock more residents of your island, more buildings, more blueprints to craft items, fixtures, furnishings and stuff! 

On-top of that, It even has Co-op! a Survival System (Eating to restore health and tiredness), Swimming, Hunting, Insect Catching, Fishing, a Local Wildlife Museum Donation, Farming, Trapping, Animal Husbandry, Metal Detecting, Housing, Building, Landscaping, Mining, Player-NPC Relations, Seasons - and the list goes on... The short version is that there is much to do on your island. You can have more than one character, so if you don't like the layout of your island or something early on, you can always make another one!

I'm still learning, still experimenting and still very much on my journey in Dinkum, but jeez, I'm hooked on this game! I really like how you don't have to rush around doing things most the time, you can go at your own pace more or less and, whilst there is nothing specifically wrong with the soundtrack of Dinkum, I do like to put on the chill soundtracks from the Elder Scrolls, Zelda: Ocarina Of Time and Stardew Valley games in the background when I'm playing occasionally just to help myself get lost in this game for more hours than I realize everyday!

My favourite item is definitely the "Roo Poo" for sure (Yes, they have Kangaroos and they poo when you're not looking). You really thought of everything, James! I salute you. 

I look forward to putting more hours into Dinkum, and can't wait for future updates.
